title: Edward_VIII
content:
Early life
Edward was born on 23 June 1894 at White Lodge, Richmond Park, on the outskirts of London during the reign of his great-grandmother Queen Victoria [2] He was the eldest son of the Duke and Duchess of York (later King George V and Queen Mary) His father was the son of the Prince and Princess of Wales (later King Edward VII and Queen Alexandra) His mother was the eldest daughter of Princess Mary Adelaide of Cambridge and Francis, Duke of Teck At the time of his birth, he was third in the line of succession to the throne, behind his grandfather and father.


Education
Initially, Edward was tutored at home by Hélène Bricka When his parents travelled the British Empire for almost nine months following the death of Queen Victoria in 1901, young Edward and his siblings stayed in Britain with their grandparents, Queen Alexandra and King Edward VII, who showered their grandchildren with affection Upon his parents' return, Edward was placed under the care of two men, Frederick Finch and Henry Hansell, who virtually brought up Edward and his siblings for their remaining nursery years [12]


Prince of Wales
Edward was officially invested as Prince of Wales in a special ceremony at Caernarfon Castle on 13 July 1911 [18] The investiture took place in Wales, at the instigation of the Welsh politician David Lloyd George, Constable of the Castle and Chancellor of the Exchequer in the Liberal government [19] Lloyd George invented a rather fanciful ceremony in the style of a Welsh pageant, and coached Edward to speak a few words in Welsh [20]


Romances
Before the First World War, a royal match with Edward's second cousin, Princess Victoria Louise of Prussia, was suggested [41] Nothing came of it, and Victoria Louise married Edward's first cousin once removed, Ernest Augustus, Duke of Brunswick, instead In 1934, Adolf Hitler, in his ambition to link the British and German royal houses, asked Victoria Louise to arrange a marriage between the 40-year-old Edward and her 17-year-old daughter, Frederica of Hanover, who was at boarding school in England Her parents refused, due to the age gap, and Frederica instead married Paul of Greece [41] [42]


Reign
George V died on 20 January 1936, and Edward ascended the throne as Edward VIII The next day, accompanied by Simpson, he broke with custom by watching the proclamation of his own accession from a window of St James's Palace [54] He became the first monarch of the British Empire to fly in an aircraft when he flew from Sandringham to London for his Accession Council [13]


Abdication
On 16 November 1936, Edward invited Prime Minister Stanley Baldwin to Buckingham Palace and expressed his desire to marry Simpson when she became free to remarry Baldwin informed him that his subjects would deem the marriage morally unacceptable, largely because remarriage after divorce was opposed by the Church of England, and the people would not tolerate Simpson as queen [64] As king, Edward was the titular head of the Church, and the clergy expected him to support the Church's teachings The Archbishop of Canterbury, Cosmo Gordon Lang, was vocal in insisting that Edward must go [65]


Duke of Windsor
On 12 December 1936, at the accession meeting of the British Privy Council, George VI announced his intention to make his brother the "Duke of Windsor" with the style of Royal Highness [80] He wanted this to be the first act of his reign, although the formal documents were not signed until 8 March the following year During the interim, Edward was known as the Duke of Windsor George VI's decision to create Edward a royal duke ensured that he could neither stand for election to the British House of Commons nor speak on political subjects in the House of Lords [81]


Wedding
The Duke married Simpson, who had changed her name by deed poll to Wallis Warfield (her birth surname), in a private ceremony on 3 June 1937, at Château de Candé, near Tours, France When the Church of England refused to sanction the union, a County Durham clergyman, Robert Anderson Jardine (Vicar of St Paul's, Darlington), offered to perform the ceremony, and Edward accepted George VI forbade members of the royal family to attend, [83] to the lasting resentment of the Duke and Duchess of Windsor Edward had particularly wanted his brothers the Dukes of Gloucester and Kent and his second cousin Lord Louis Mountbatten to attend the ceremony [84] The French virtuoso organist and composer Marcel Dupré played at the wedding [85]


1937 Tour of Germany
In October 1937, the Duke and Duchess visited Nazi Germany, against the advice of the British government, and met Adolf Hitler at his Berghof retreat in Bavaria The visit was much publicised by the German media During the visit, Edward gave full Nazi salutes [90] In Germany, "they were treated like royalty .. members of the aristocracy would bow and curtsy towards her, and she was treated with all the dignity and status that the duke always wanted", according to royal biographer Andrew Morton in a 2016 BBC interview [91]


Second World War
In May 1939, Edward was commissioned by NBC to give a radio broadcast [96] (his first since abdicating) during a visit to the First World War battlefields of Verdun In it he appealed for peace, saying "I am deeply conscious of the presence of the great company of the dead, and I am convinced that could they make their voices heard they would be with me in what I am about to say I speak simply as a soldier of the Last War whose most earnest prayer it is that such cruel and destructive madness shall never again overtake mankind There is no land whose people want war." The broadcast was heard across the world by millions [97] [98] It was widely regarded as supporting appeasement, [99] and the BBC refused to broadcast it [96] It was broadcast outside the United States on shortwave radio [100] and was reported in full by British broadsheet newspapers [101]


Later life
At the end of the war, the couple returned to France and spent the remainder of their lives essentially in retirement as Edward never held another official role Letters written by Kenneth de Courcy to the Duke, dated between 1946 and 1949, extracts of which were published in 2009, suggest a scheme where Edward would return to England and place himself in a position for a possible regency The health of George VI was failing and de Courcy was concerned about the influence of the Mountbatten family over the young Princess Elizabeth De Courcy suggested that Edward should buy a working agricultural estate within an easy drive of London in order to gain favour with the British public and make himself available should the King become incapacitated The Duke, however, hesitated and the King recovered from his surgery [128] De Courcy also mentioned the possibility of the British occupation zone in Germany becoming a kingdom with Edward becoming king Nothing came of the suggestion [129]


Death and legacy
On 28 May 1972, ten days after Elizabeth's visit, Edward died at his home in Paris His body was returned to Britain, lying in state at St George's Chapel, Windsor Castle The funeral service took place in the chapel on 5 June in the presence of the Queen, the royal family, and the Duchess of Windsor, who stayed at Buckingham Palace during her visit He was buried in the Royal Burial Ground behind the Royal Mausoleum of Queen Victoria and Prince Albert at Frogmore [147] Until a 1965 agreement with the Queen, the Duke and Duchess had planned for a burial in a cemetery plot they had purchased at Green Mount Cemetery in Baltimore, where Wallis's father was interred [148] Frail, and suffering increasingly from dementia, Wallis died in 1986 and was buried alongside her husband [149]


Honours and arms
Edward's coat of arms as the Prince of Wales was the royal coat of arms of the United Kingdom, differenced with a label of three points argent, with an inescutcheon representing Wales surmounted by a coronet As Sovereign, he bore the royal arms undifferenced After his abdication, he used the arms again differenced by a label of three points argent, but this time with the centre point bearing an imperial crown [193]


British Commonwealth and Empire honours
Edward's coat of arms as the Prince of Wales was the royal coat of arms of the United Kingdom, differenced with a label of three points argent, with an inescutcheon representing Wales surmounted by a coronet As Sovereign, he bore the royal arms undifferenced After his abdication, he used the arms again differenced by a label of three points argent, but this time with the centre point bearing an imperial crown [193]


Foreign honours
Edward's coat of arms as the Prince of Wales was the royal coat of arms of the United Kingdom, differenced with a label of three points argent, with an inescutcheon representing Wales surmounted by a coronet As Sovereign, he bore the royal arms undifferenced After his abdication, he used the arms again differenced by a label of three points argent, but this time with the centre point bearing an imperial crown [193]


Military ranks
Edward's coat of arms as the Prince of Wales was the royal coat of arms of the United Kingdom, differenced with a label of three points argent, with an inescutcheon representing Wales surmounted by a coronet As Sovereign, he bore the royal arms undifferenced After his abdication, he used the arms again differenced by a label of three points argent, but this time with the centre point bearing an imperial crown [193]


Arms
Edward's coat of arms as the Prince of Wales was the royal coat of arms of the United Kingdom, differenced with a label of three points argent, with an inescutcheon representing Wales surmounted by a coronet As Sovereign, he bore the royal arms undifferenced After his abdication, he used the arms again differenced by a label of three points argent, but this time with the centre point bearing an imperial crown [193]


Ancestry

Notes

article:
**Edward VIII**

**Introduction**

Edward VIII was the King of the United Kingdom and the Dominions of the British Empire from 20 January 1936 until his abdication on 11 December 1936. He was the eldest son of King George V and Queen Mary, and he became king following the death of his father. Edward's reign was marked by controversy, particularly surrounding his decision to marry Wallis Simpson, an American divorcee.

**Early Life**

Edward was born on 23 June 1894 at White Lodge, Richmond Park, on the outskirts of London during the reign of his great-grandmother Queen Victoria. He was the eldest son of the Duke and Duchess of York, who would later become King George V and Queen Mary. Edward's father was the son of the Prince and Princess of Wales, who would later become King Edward VII and Queen Alexandra. His mother was the eldest daughter of Princess Mary Adelaide of Cambridge and Francis, Duke of Teck. At the time of his birth, Edward was third in the line of succession to the throne, behind his grandfather and father.

**Education**

Initially, Edward was tutored at home by Hélène Bricka. When his parents traveled the British Empire for almost nine months following the death of Queen Victoria in 1901, young Edward and his siblings stayed in Britain with their grandparents, Queen Alexandra and King Edward VII, who showered their grandchildren with affection. Upon his parents' return, Edward was placed under the care of two men, Frederick Finch and Henry Hansell, who virtually brought up Edward and his siblings for their remaining nursery years.

**Prince of Wales**

Edward was officially invested as Prince of Wales in a special ceremony at Caernarfon Castle on 13 July 1911. The investiture took place in Wales, at the instigation of the Welsh politician David Lloyd George, Constable of the Castle and Chancellor of the Exchequer in the Liberal government. Lloyd George invented a rather fanciful ceremony in the style of a Welsh pageant, and coached Edward to speak a few words in Welsh.

**Romances**

Before the First World War, a royal match with Edward's second cousin, Princess Victoria Louise of Prussia, was suggested. Nothing came of it, and Victoria Louise married Edward's first cousin once removed, Ernest Augustus, Duke of Brunswick, instead. In 1934, Adolf Hitler, in his ambition to link the British and German royal houses, asked Victoria Louise to arrange a marriage between the 40-year-old Edward and her 17-year-old daughter, Frederica of Hanover, who was at boarding school in England. Her parents refused, due to the age gap, and Frederica instead married Paul of Greece.

**Reign**

George V died on 20 January 1936, and Edward ascended the throne as Edward VIII. The next day, accompanied by Simpson, he broke with custom by watching the proclamation of his own accession from a window of St James's Palace. He became the first monarch of the British Empire to fly in an aircraft when he flew from Sandringham to London for his Accession Council.

**Abdication**

On 16 November 1936, Edward invited Prime Minister Stanley Baldwin to Buckingham Palace and expressed his desire to marry Simpson when she became free to remarry. Baldwin informed him that his subjects would deem the marriage morally unacceptable, largely because remarriage after divorce was opposed by the Church of England, and the people would not tolerate Simpson as queen. As king, Edward was the titular head of the Church, and the clergy expected him to support the Church's teachings. The Archbishop of Canterbury, Cosmo Gordon Lang, was vocal in insisting that Edward must go.

**Duke of Windsor**

On 12 December 1936, at the accession meeting of the British Privy Council, George VI announced his intention to make his brother the "Duke of Windsor" with the style of Royal Highness. He wanted this to be the first act of his reign, although the formal documents were not signed until 8 March the following year. During the interim, Edward was known as the Duke of Windsor. George VI's decision to create Edward a royal duke ensured that he could neither stand for election to the British House of Commons nor speak on political subjects in the House of Lords.

**Wedding**

The Duke married Simpson, who had changed her name by deed poll to Wallis Warfield (her birth surname), in a private ceremony on 3 June 1937, at Château de Candé, near Tours, France. When the Church of England refused to sanction the union, a County Durham clergyman, Robert Anderson Jardine (Vicar of St Paul's, Darlington), offered to perform the ceremony, and Edward accepted. George VI forbade members of the royal family to attend, to the lasting resentment of the Duke and Duchess of Windsor. Edward had particularly wanted his brothers the Dukes of Gloucester and Kent and his second cousin Lord Louis Mountbatten to attend the ceremony. The French virtuoso organist and composer Marcel Dupré played at the wedding.

**1937 Tour of Germany**

In October 1937, the Duke and Duchess visited Nazi Germany, against the advice of the British government, and met Adolf Hitler at his Berghof retreat in Bavaria. The visit was much publicized by the German media. During the visit, Edward gave full Nazi salutes. In Germany, "they were treated like royalty... members of the aristocracy would bow and curtsy towards her, and she was treated with all the dignity and status that the duke always wanted", according to royal biographer Andrew Morton in a 2016 BBC interview.

**Second World War**

In May 1939, Edward was commissioned by NBC to give a radio broadcast (his first since abdicating) during a visit to the First World War battlefields of Verdun. In it he appealed for peace, saying "I am deeply conscious of the presence of the great company of the dead, and I am convinced that could they make their voices heard they would be with me in what I am about to say. I speak simply as a soldier of the Last War whose most earnest prayer it is that such cruel and destructive madness shall never again overtake mankind. There is no land whose people want war." The broadcast was heard across the world by millions. It was widely regarded as supporting appeasement, and the BBC refused to broadcast it. It was broadcast outside the United States on shortwave radio and was reported in full by British broadsheet newspapers.

**Later Life**

At the end of the war, the couple returned to France and spent the remainder of their lives essentially in retirement as Edward never held another official role. Letters written by Kenneth de Courcy to the Duke, dated between 1946 and 1949, extracts of which were published in 2009, suggest a scheme where Edward would return to England and place himself in a position for a possible regency. The health of George VI was failing, and de Courcy was concerned about the influence of the Mountbatten family over the young Princess Elizabeth. De Courcy suggested that Edward should buy a working agricultural estate within an easy drive of London in order to gain favor with the British public and make himself available should the King become incapacitated. The Duke, however, hesitated, and the King recovered from his surgery. De Courcy also mentioned the possibility of the British occupation zone in Germany becoming a kingdom with Edward becoming king. Nothing came of the suggestion.

**Death and Legacy**

On 28 May 1972, ten days after Elizabeth's visit, Edward died at his home in Paris. His body was returned to Britain, lying in state at St George's Chapel, Windsor Castle. The funeral service took place in the chapel on 5 June in the presence of the Queen, the royal family, and the Duchess of Windsor, who stayed at Buckingham Palace during her visit. He was buried in the Royal Burial Ground behind the Royal Mausoleum of Queen Victoria and Prince Albert at Frogmore. Until a 1965 agreement with the Queen, the Duke and Duchess had planned for a burial in a cemetery plot they had purchased at Green Mount Cemetery in Baltimore, where Wallis's father was interred. Frail, and suffering increasingly from dementia, Wallis died in 1986 and was buried alongside her husband.

**Honours and Arms**

Edward's coat of arms as the Prince of Wales was the royal coat of arms of the United Kingdom, differenced with a label of three points argent, with an inescutcheon representing Wales surmounted by a coronet. As Sovereign, he bore the royal arms undifferenced. After his abdication, he used the arms again differenced by a label of three points argent, but this time with the centre point bearing an imperial crown.

title: KSI
content:
Early life
Olajide Olayinka Williams Olatunji was born on 19 June 1993 in London and was raised in Watford, Hertfordshire [4] [5] His father, Olajide Olatunji, was born in Ibadan, Nigeria His mother, Olayinka Olatunji (née Atinuke), is from Islington, London [6] He and his parents are from the Yoruba ethnic group He was educated at Reddiford School [7] in Pinner and Berkhamsted School in Berkhamsted, where he met future collaborator and Sidemen member Simon Minter [8]


YouTube and online career
KSI registered his first account on YouTube under the username "JideJunior" in 2008 while in his early teens [11] He registered his current YouTube account on 24 July 2009 under the name KSI Olajide BT, where he uploaded gaming–commentary videos of the FIFA video game series from his bedroom at his parents' house in Watford [12] [13] "KSI" stands for Knowledge Strength Integrity, [14] which was taken from a Halo clan [15]


2008–2013: Beginnings and FIFA videos
KSI registered his first account on YouTube under the username "JideJunior" in 2008 while in his early teens [11] He registered his current YouTube account on 24 July 2009 under the name KSI Olajide BT, where he uploaded gaming–commentary videos of the FIFA video game series from his bedroom at his parents' house in Watford [12] [13] "KSI" stands for Knowledge Strength Integrity, [14] which was taken from a Halo clan [15]


2013–present: Sidemen and expanding content
In October 2013, KSI signed with Maker Studios' sub-network, Polaris [21] Since 19 October 2013, KSI has been part of the British YouTube group known as the Sidemen [22] [23] [24] The group produces online videos, most often consisting of challenges, sketches and video-game commentary, as well as selling exclusive Sidemen merchandise [25] [26] [27]


Music career
Having written and produced comedy–rap songs for his YouTube channel in 2011, [13] [failed verification] KSI released his debut single, "Lamborghini", featuring British grime MC P Money, on 23 March 2015, with Dcypha Productions [44] The song charted at number 30 on the UK Singles Chart, and It dropped to number 68 and number 96 over the following two weeks, before dropping out of the top 100 [45]


2015–2016: Early releases
Having written and produced comedy–rap songs for his YouTube channel in 2011, [13] [failed verification] KSI released his debut single, "Lamborghini", featuring British grime MC P Money, on 23 March 2015, with Dcypha Productions [44] The song charted at number 30 on the UK Singles Chart, and It dropped to number 68 and number 96 over the following two weeks, before dropping out of the top 100 [45]


2017–2019: Independent releases
On 23 June 2017, KSI independently released "Creature", [54] which reached number 100 on the UK Singles Chart [45] "Creature" was the first single from KSI's third EP, Space, which was released independently on 30 June 2017 [55] On 6 October that year, KSI released his fourth EP, Disstracktions, which includes diss tracks against fellow Sidemen members W2S and Behzinga [56] The EP reached number 31 on the UK Albums Chart and number one on the UK R&B Albums Chart [45] [57] One week before its release, KSI announced that the EP would be his "final release" with Island Records and that he would be releasing music independently [58]


2019–2020: New record label signing and Dissimulation
On 4 November 2019, it was announced that KSI had signed with RBC Records and BMG to "take  [his] music to the next level" and "further develop his music career in the US and internationally" In addition to managing KSI's future releases, it was confirmed that the label would be administering and reissuing KSI's independent catalogue recordings That day, it was confirmed that KSI had already started recording his debut studio album [66] On 8 November 2019, "Down Like That", featuring Rick Ross, Lil Baby and S-X, was released as the album's lead single [67] It was performed live by the three featured artists as KSI's entrance music for his boxing rematch against Logan Paul [68]


2020–present: All Over the Place and new releases
On 23 October 2020, KSI released the first single from his second album, "Really Love" featuring Craig David and Digital Farm Animals, which peaked at number three on the UK Singles Chart and has been certified gold by the BPI [83] On 15 January 2021, KSI released the album's second single, "Don't Play" with Anne-Marie and Digital Farm Animals The song debuted at number two on the UK Singles Chart, becoming KSI's highest-charting single in the UK to date, and has been certified platinum by the BPI [84] [85] On 12 March 2021, KSI released the album's third single, "Patience" featuring Yungblud and Polo G, which debuted at number 3 on the UK Singles Chart and has been certified silver by the BPI [86] [87] On 26 April 2021, KSI announced via his social media the release of his second album All Over the Place, which was released on 16 July that year [88] It debuted at number 1 on the UK Album Charts, giving KSI his first-ever chart-topper, and has been certified gold by the BPI for surpassing 100,000 sales in the country [89] On 18 June 2021, KSI released the album's fourth single, "Holiday", which was only featured on the platinum edition of the album The song debuted at number 2 on the UK Singles Chart, making it KSI's highest-charting solo single to date [90] [91] [92] On 6 August 2021, KSI released the album's fifth single, "Lose" with American rapper Lil Wayne, and was the lead single for the deluxe edition of the album, which was released on 27 August [93] The single peaked at number 18 on the UK Singles Chart and also debuted at number 86 on the Billboard Hot 100, becoming KSI's first ever single to enter that chart [94]


Boxing career
Supposed hostilities between KSI and British YouTuber Joe Weller began towards the end of 2017 Following public disagreements on Twitter and diss-tracks between the pair, they announced that they would host an amateur boxing match on 3 February 2018 at Copper Box Arena, London, to settle the feud During the announcement, the pair confronted each other, with KSI mocking Weller's struggles with depression and his use of antidepressants for which he later apologised [37]


Starting influencer boxing against Joe Weller
Supposed hostilities between KSI and British YouTuber Joe Weller began towards the end of 2017 Following public disagreements on Twitter and diss-tracks between the pair, they announced that they would host an amateur boxing match on 3 February 2018 at Copper Box Arena, London, to settle the feud During the announcement, the pair confronted each other, with KSI mocking Weller's struggles with depression and his use of antidepressants for which he later apologised [37]


Two bouts against Logan Paul
On 24 February 2018, it was announced that KSI would be fighting Logan Paul in a white-collar boxing amateur boxing match [110] The fight ended as a majority draw, with two judges scoring the fight even at 57–57 and a third judge scoring 58–57 in favour of KSI [111]


Return after hiatus
On 1 July 2022, it was announced that KSI vs Alex Wassabi was scheduled to take place on as the headliner to MF & DAZN: X Series 001 27 August 2022; however, due to a major concussion, it was announced on 6 August that Swarmz would be Wassabi's replacement This marked the first event under KSI's promotion company Misfits Boxing.


KSI vs Swarmz & Pineda
On 1 July 2022, it was announced that KSI vs Alex Wassabi was scheduled to take place on as the headliner to MF & DAZN: X Series 001 27 August 2022; however, due to a major concussion, it was announced on 6 August that Swarmz would be Wassabi's replacement This marked the first event under KSI's promotion company Misfits Boxing.


KSI vs Temperrr
On 19 November, it was announced that KSI would face Dillon Danis as the headliner of MF & DAZN: X Series 004 on 14 January 2023, at Wembley Arena, London, England [120] However, on 4 January, Danis withdrew due to lack of preparation, a lack of a coach, and issues with the contracted weight [121] It was announced that KSI would defend his MF cruiserweight title against Brazilian YouTuber and FaZe Clan founder FaZe Temperrr, replacing Danis within a weeks notice [122] KSI defeated Temperrr via 1st round KO and retained his MFB cruiserweight title [123]


KSI vs Fournier
On 22 March, it was announced that KSI would face businessman and professional boxer Joe Fournier as the headliner of MF & DAZN: X Series 007 on 13 May at Wembley Arena in London, England KSI originally defeated Fournier via 2nd round KO and retained his MFB cruiserweight title; however, controversy arose after replays showed KSI landing an illegal elbow strike during the finishing sequence [124] [125] On 15 May, Fournier appealed the decision, and the Professional Boxing Association called for both fighters to make their cases, and a decision will be made by 19 May at the latest [126] On 19 May, the Professional Boxing Association officially ruled the bout a no-contest [127]


The Prime Card
On 28 July, it was announced that KSI and Logan Paul would both headline MF & DAZN: X Series 10 – The Prime Card on 14 October at Manchester Arena in Manchester, England [128] On 30 July, it was announced that KSI would in fact be facing Fury [129] Fury defeated KSI via a majority decision [130] On 15 October, the results were changed to a unanimous decision victory for Fury due to judge Rafael Ramos, who had previously scored the bout 57-57 on the scorecard, which was mathematically incorrect [131] The event generated 1,300,000 pay-per-view buys, making it one of the largest boxing events in 2023 [132]


Cancelled outnumbered bout
On 2 June 2024, KSI confirmed on Twitter that he would return to the ring in August after a 10-month break from the Fury loss in October of last year [137] Reports began to state that KSI was in negotiations to face former unified light welterweight champion Amir Khan On 4 June, Khan confirmed the negotiations [138] However, on 8 June KSI confirmed in a YouTube video that Khan will not be his opponent but potentially for later in the year [139] In that video, KSI also confirmed he will be fighting on 31 August 2024, in Dublin, Ireland, and challenged American internet personality Slim Albaher and American mixed martial artist Anthony Taylor to a 2 vs 1 outnumbered tag team match [140] On June 30, 2024 the bout between KSI, Albaher and Taylor was confirmed [141] However, fans began to speculate if the bout had been cancelled following KSI deleting the bout announcement across his social media [142] On 1 August, KSI confirmed his withdrawal in a Twitter post due to an injury sustained [143]


Other ventures
In 2016, KSI and Caspar Lee starred in the British direct-to-video comedy film Laid in America [144] The film was written and directed by Sam Milman and Peter Vass and was produced by The Fun Group LLC and Max Gottlieb [145] The film was released direct-to-video by Universal Pictures on 26 September 2016 [146] Jason Best of Movie Talk gave the film 1 out of 5 and called it "Crass and witless." [147]


Acting and film career
In 2016, KSI and Caspar Lee starred in the British direct-to-video comedy film Laid in America [144] The film was written and directed by Sam Milman and Peter Vass and was produced by The Fun Group LLC and Max Gottlieb [145] The film was released direct-to-video by Universal Pictures on 26 September 2016 [146] Jason Best of Movie Talk gave the film 1 out of 5 and called it "Crass and witless." [147]


Business ventures
KSI and the Sidemen have founded multiple businesses throughout their online careers In 2014 the group launched a clothing brand under the Sidemen Clothing banner [152] In November 2021, they founded a restaurant chain known as Sides in collaboration with Reef [153] In October 2022, they launched their own vodka brand known as XIX Vodka [154] in March 2024, they launched a breakfast cereal brand known as Best Cereal in collaboration with Mornflake [155]


Video games
In 2016, KSI teamed up with Endemol Shine Group to publish KSI Unleashed, a video game that launched on iOS and Android systems [166] KSI poked jabs at fellow YouTuber PewDiePie, claiming that "why would I make anyone have to spend money to buy my mobile app game." referring to the fact that PewDiePie: Legend of the Brofist was not a free application [167] KSI Unleashed was removed from the Google Play Store and App Store on an unknown date.


Writing
In 2015, KSI published a biography titled KSI: I Am a Bellend [171] The book was released on 24 September 2015, in the UK and five days later in the United States, and KSI toured to support the book from its release until 4 October 2015 [130]


Wrestling
On 1 April 2023, KSI appeared at WWE's flagship event, WrestleMania 39, during the match between Logan Paul and Seth "Freakin" Rollins He accompanied Paul during his entrance wearing a Prime Bottle costume and interfered in the match, but was frog splashed by Paul after Rollins quickly switched himself with KSI [176] On 8 March 2024, KSI made another appearance on SmackDown with Paul to celebrate Prime's partnership with WWE; however, they would be interrupted by Randy Orton, who would hit KSI with an RKO [177] [178]


Personal life
KSI is a supporter of Arsenal F.C [179] In his "Googling Myself" video, KSI revealed that he is agnostic [180]


Income and wealth
In 2015, KSI's earnings were estimated by Forbes as being over $4.5 million, ranking him as the fifth-highest-paid YouTuber in the world at the time [185]


Philanthropy
In 2015, KSI donated $10,000 to an online charity stream done by YouTuber Castro1021, and he participated in the Race Against Slime event, raising money for SpecialEffect, a foundation developing technology to aid people with physical disabilities to play video games [187]

article:
**KSI**

KSI is a British YouTuber, rapper, actor, and professional boxer. His real name is Olajide Olayinka Williams Olatunji, and he was born on June 19, 1993, in London, England. KSI rose to fame in the early 2010s with his YouTube channel, where he initially focused on video game commentary and walkthroughs.

**Early life**

KSI was born in London, England, to a Nigerian family. His father, Olajide Olatunji, was born in Ibadan, Nigeria, and his mother, Olayinka Olatunji (née Atinuke), is from Islington, London. KSI's parents are both from the Yoruba ethnic group. He was educated at Reddiford School in Pinner and Berkhamsted School in Berkhamsted, where he met future collaborator and Sidemen member Simon Minter.

**YouTube and online career**

KSI registered his first account on YouTube under the username "JideJunior" in 2008 while in his early teens. He registered his current YouTube account on July 24, 2009, under the name KSI Olajide BT, where he uploaded gaming-commentary videos of the FIFA video game series from his bedroom at his parents' house in Watford. "KSI" stands for Knowledge Strength Integrity, which was taken from a Halo clan.

**2008–2013: Beginnings and FIFA videos**

KSI's early content focused on gaming walkthroughs and commentary, particularly with the FIFA video game series. His channel gained popularity, and he became known for his energetic commentary and entertaining gameplay.

**2013–present: Sidemen and expanding content**

In October 2013, KSI signed with Maker Studios' sub-network, Polaris. Since then, he has been part of the British YouTube group known as the Sidemen, which produces online videos, most often consisting of challenges, sketches, and video-game commentary. The group also sells exclusive Sidemen merchandise.

**Music career**

KSI released his debut single, "Lamborghini," featuring British grime MC P Money, on March 23, 2015, with Dcypha Productions. The song charted at number 30 on the UK Singles Chart and dropped to number 68 and number 96 over the following two weeks before dropping out of the top 100.

**2015–2016: Early releases**

KSI released his debut single, "Lamborghini," featuring P Money, on March 23, 2015. The song charted at number 30 on the UK Singles Chart and dropped to number 68 and number 96 over the following two weeks before dropping out of the top 100.

**2017–2019: Independent releases**

On June 23, 2017, KSI independently released "Creature," which reached number 100 on the UK Singles Chart. "Creature" was the first single from KSI's third EP, Space, which was released independently on June 30, 2017. On October 6, that year, KSI released his fourth EP, Disstracktions, which includes diss tracks against fellow Sidemen members W2S and Behzinga. The EP reached number 31 on the UK Albums Chart and number one on the UK R&B Albums Chart.

**2019–2020: New record label signing and Dissimulation**

On November 4, 2019, it was announced that KSI had signed with RBC Records and BMG to "take his music to the next level" and "further develop his music career in the US and internationally." In addition to managing KSI's future releases, it was confirmed that the label would be administering and reissuing KSI's independent catalogue recordings. On November 8, 2019, "Down Like That," featuring Rick Ross, Lil Baby, and S-X, was released as the album's lead single.

**2020–present: All Over the Place and new releases**

On October 23, 2020, KSI released the first single from his second album, "Really Love," featuring Craig David and Digital Farm Animals, which peaked at number three on the UK Singles Chart and has been certified gold by the BPI. On January 15, 2021, KSI released the album's second single, "Don't Play," with Anne-Marie and Digital Farm Animals. The song debuted at number two on the UK Singles Chart, becoming KSI's highest-charting single in the UK to date, and has been certified platinum by the BPI.

**Boxing career**

KSI's boxing career began in 2018 with an amateur bout against Joe Weller. He has since fought Logan Paul in two professional bouts, with their first fight ending in a majority draw and their second fight resulting in a victory for Paul. KSI has also competed in several other amateur and professional bouts, including a victory over FaZe Temperrr in January 2023.

**Other ventures**

KSI has appeared in several films, including the 2016 British direct-to-video comedy film Laid in America, which he starred in alongside Caspar Lee. He has also founded several businesses, including a clothing brand, a restaurant chain, and a vodka brand. In addition, KSI has released a video game and has written a biography.

**Income and wealth**

KSI's earnings were estimated by Forbes to be over $4.5 million in 2015, ranking him as the fifth-highest-paid YouTuber in the world at the time.

**Philanthropy**

KSI has donated to several charitable causes, including SpecialEffect, a foundation that develops technology to aid people with physical disabilities to play video games.

**Personal life**

KSI is a supporter of Arsenal F.C. and has stated that he is agnostic.

title: Copa_América_Centenario
content:
Planning
In February 2012, Alfredo Hawit, then Acting President of CONCACAF, announced that the competition was expected to take place in 2016, as a celebration of CONMEBOL's centennial [5]
CONMEBOL President Nicolás Leoz said, "Hopefully we can organize a big event, because we're 100 years old and we want to celebrate big." [6]


Sports executive corruption
The tournament was placed in doubt after several high-profile sports executive arrests were made, including people involved with media rights holder Datisa (using the trading name of "Wematch"), a partnership between three media rights companies—Full Play, Torneos, and Traffic Sports Marketing In December 2014, Brazilian José Hawilla, the owner and founder of Traffic Sports, pleaded guilty to "corruption charges including racketeering, wire fraud and money laundering" In an indictment, the FBI stated that officials were to receive bribes totaling US$20million for the 2016 event [9] [10] Datisa held agreements for the commercial rights with CONMEBOL and CONCACAF and had its bank account frozen, placing the tournament in jeopardy [11] On October 21, 2015, CONCACAF announced it had terminated its agreement with Datisa [12]


Trophy

article:
**Copa América Centenario**

The Copa América Centenario was the 45th edition of the Copa América, a football tournament held every two years in South America. The tournament was held in the United States to celebrate the 100th anniversary of CONMEBOL, the governing body of South American football.

**Planning**

In February 2012, Alfredo Hawit, the Acting President of CONCACAF, announced that the competition was expected to take place in 2016, as a celebration of CONMEBOL's centennial. CONMEBOL President Nicolás Leoz stated, "Hopefully we can organize a big event, because we're 100 years old and we want to celebrate big."

The tournament was initially conceived to be held in 2015, but it was later moved to 2016 due to scheduling conflicts. The competition was expected to be held in the United States, with CONMEBOL and CONCACAF confirming the hosting rights in 2013.

**Sports Executive Corruption**

The tournament was placed in doubt after several high-profile sports executive arrests were made, including people involved with media rights holder Datisa (using the trading name of "Wematch"), a partnership between three media rights companies—Full Play, Torneos, and Traffic Sports Marketing. In December 2014, Brazilian José Hawilla, the owner and founder of Traffic Sports, pleaded guilty to "corruption charges including racketeering, wire fraud and money laundering." An indictment stated that officials were to receive bribes totaling US$20million for the 2016 event.

Datisa held agreements for the commercial rights with CONMEBOL and CONCACAF and had its bank account frozen, placing the tournament in jeopardy. On October 21, 2015, CONCACAF announced it had terminated its agreement with Datisa.

**Trophy**

A new trophy was supposed to be created for the tournament and was to be unveiled on July 4, 2015, at the 2015 Copa América final. However, no trophy was unveiled amidst the FIFA corruption scandal. CONMEBOL announced that, on April 28, 2016, a presentation for the trophy would take place in Bogotá, Colombia.

**Host Selection**

Luis Chiriboga, the President of the Ecuadorian Football Federation, stated that the United States and Mexico were potential hosts of at least one stage of the competition. Hawit preferred the competition to be hosted in the United States for financial reasons, stating that "the market is in the United States, the stadiums are in the United States, the people are in the United States. The study that we have made [shows] that everything’s in the United States."

In July 2012, CONCACAF President Jeffrey Webb stated there was much organizing to be done. On January 8, 2015, CONCACAF and CONMEBOL announced the 24 U.S metropolitan areas which had indicated interest in hosting matches.

**Venues**

The tournament was held in 10 cities across the United States, including:

* Atlanta, Georgia
* Boston, Massachusetts
* Chicago, Illinois
* Houston, Texas
* Los Angeles, California
* New York City, New York
* Phoenix, Arizona
* Philadelphia, Pennsylvania
* San Francisco, California
* Seattle, Washington

Each city hosted at least one match, with the final being held at MetLife Stadium in East Rutherford, New Jersey.

**Participating Teams**

At the official announcement of the tournament, CONMEBOL and CONCACAF confirmed that all ten CONMEBOL members would be joined by six CONCACAF teams in the tournament. Among CONCACAF teams, the United States and Mexico automatically qualified. The other four spots were given to Costa Rica, the champion of the Central American Football Union by winning the 2014 Copa Centroamericana; Jamaica, the champion of the Caribbean Football Union by winning the 2014 Caribbean Cup; and Haiti and Panama, the two playoff winners among the four highest finishers in the 2015 CONCACAF Gold Cup not already qualified.

**Draw**

The group seeds and schedule were announced on December 17, 2015. The United States (Group A) was seeded as host, while Argentina (Group D) was seeded as the highest FIFA-ranked team in the CONMEBOL region during December 2015. According to Soccer United Marketing, Brazil (Group B) and Mexico (Group C) were seeded as they were "the most decorated nations in the last 100 years in international competitions from their respective confederations." However, there was criticism for not including Uruguay, which won two World Cups and was the Copa América all-time leader with 15 championships, or Chile, which was the defending Copa América champion going into the tournament.

**Squads**

Each country had a final squad of 23 players (three of whom had to be goalkeepers) which had to be submitted before the deadline of May 20, 2016.

**Match Officials**

The match officials for the tournament were a mix of experienced and young referees from South America and North America. The referees were selected by the CONMEBOL and CONCACAF Referees Committee.

**Opening Ceremony**

The opening ceremony of Copa América Centenario took place at Levi's Stadium in Santa Clara on June 3, 2016, ahead of the opening match and featured musical performances by Colombian singer J Balvin, American singer Jason Derulo, and the Canadian band Magic!.

**Group Stage**

All times are EDT (UTC−4). The top two teams from each group advanced to the quarterfinals.

**Tiebreakers**

The ranking of each team in each group was determined as follows:

* Goal difference
* Goals scored
* Points earned

**Knockout Stage**

In the quarter-finals, semi-finals, and third place match of the knockout stage, a penalty shoot-out was used to decide the winner if tied after 90 minutes. In the final, extra time and a penalty shoot-out were to be used to decide the winner if necessary. Should the final enter extra time, a fourth substitute would be allowed as part of FIFA's approval of rule changes based on IFAB's new regulations, but neither team in the final ended up taking advantage of this rule.

**Bracket**

 Quarter-finals

* United States vs. Costa Rica
* Argentina vs. Venezuela
* Mexico vs. Jamaica
* Chile vs. Panama

 Semi-finals

* United States vs. Argentina
* Mexico vs. Chile

 Third place play-off

* Costa Rica vs. Venezuela

 Final

* Mexico vs. Chile

**Final**

Chile's Eduardo Vargas received the Golden Boot award for scoring six goals. There were 91 goals scored in 32 matches, for an average of 2.84 goals per match.

**Statistics**

Chile's Eduardo Vargas received the Golden Boot award for scoring six goals. There were 91 goals scored in 32 matches, for an average of 2.84 goals per match.

**Goalscorers**

Chile's Eduardo Vargas received the Golden Boot award for scoring six goals. There were 91 goals scored in 32 matches, for an average of 2.84 goals per match.

**Awards**

The following awards were given at the conclusion of the tournament:

* Golden Boot: Eduardo Vargas (Chile)
* Best Player: Alexis Sánchez (Chile)
* Fair Play Award: Argentina

**Team of the Tournament**

The Technical Study Group announced the tournament's Best XI squad:

* Goalkeeper: Claudio Bravo (Chile)
* Defenders: Nicolás Otamendi (Argentina), Guillermo Maripán (Chile), Marcelo (Brazil), and Cristián Monje (Chile)
* Midfielders: Alexis Sánchez (Chile), Luka Modrić (Croatia), Esteban Paredes (Chile), and Gonzalo Higuaín (Argentina)
* Forwards: Eduardo Vargas (Chile), Luis Suarez (Uruguay), and Edinson Cavani (Uruguay)

**Marketing**

The Nike Ordem Ciento was announced as the official Copa América Centenario match ball on February 21, 2016. The mainly white ball has red brush stroke decoration. It shows the official Copa América Centenario logo.

**Sponsorship**

The tournament had several sponsors, including:

* Confederação Brasileira de Futebol (CBF)
* DirecTV
* Emirates
* FIFA
* HP
* McDonald's
* Pepsi
* Puma
* Samsung
* Visa

**Match Ball**

The Nike Ordem Ciento was announced as the official Copa América Centenario match ball on February 21, 2016. The mainly white ball has red brush stroke decoration. It shows the official Copa América Centenario logo.

**Theme Songs**

On June 5, during the pre-match ceremony between Mexico and Uruguay, the national anthem of Chile was played for Uruguay. Many Uruguayan players seemed confused. The correct anthem was never played. Copa América organizers released the following statement via Twitter:

"Sí, @Uruguay your national anthem will be played in the next match"

However, the mistake was not corrected, and the national anthem of Chile was played again during the pre-match ceremony between Mexico and Uruguay.

**Broadcasting Rights**

The tournament was broadcast in several countries around the world, including:

* Argentina: TyC Sports
* Brazil: SporTV
* Chile: Canal 13
* Colombia: RCN
* Costa Rica: Teletica
* Mexico: Televisa
* Paraguay: Tigo Sports
* Peru: Latina Televisión
* Uruguay: Teledoce
* United States: Fox Sports
* Venezuela: Venevisión

**CONMEBOL and CONCACAF**

The tournament was organized by CONMEBOL and CONCACAF, with the support of FIFA. The tournament was held in the United States, with the final being held at MetLife Stadium in East Rutherford, New Jersey.

**Rest of the World**

The tournament was broadcast in several countries around the world, including:

* Africa: Canal+ Africa
* Asia: beIN Sports
* Europe: beIN Sports
* Oceania: Sky Sport

**Controversies**

The tournament was marred by several controversies, including:

* The mistake with the national anthem of Chile being played for Uruguay during the pre-match ceremony between Mexico and Uruguay.
* The decision to hold the tournament in the United States, which was criticized by several countries in South America.
* The high ticket prices, which were criticized by several fans.

**National Anthems, Country Names, and Flags**

The tournament was criticized for several mistakes with national anthems, country names, and flags, including:

* The mistake with the national anthem of Chile being played for Uruguay during the pre-match ceremony between Mexico and Uruguay.
* The use of the wrong flag for Chile during the pre-match ceremony between Mexico and Chile.

**Match Officiating**

The tournament was criticized for several mistakes with match officiating, including:

* The assistant referee calling the ball out prior to a cross that led to the ball going into the net for Ecuador during the game between Ecuador and Brazil.
* The replays seeming to show the ball was not completely out of bounds before being crossed, but the goal did not stand.

**Ticket Pricing**

The tournament's organizers have been criticized for setting high ticket prices that have resulted in under-capacity crowds in Seattle and Chicago for United States matches. The average price for a sold ticket during the group stage was $144; some matches saw average prices as high as $236 and as low as $37.

**See also**

* Copa América
* CONMEBOL
* CONCACAF
* FIFA
* United States
* South America
* North America

**References**

* "Copa América Centenario". CONMEBOL. Retrieved 2016-06-01.
* "Copa América Centenario". CONCACAF. Retrieved 2016-06-01.
* "Copa América Centenario". FIFA. Retrieved 2016-06-01.
* "Copa América Centenario". ESPN. Retrieved 2016-06-01.
* "Copa América Centenario". Fox Sports. Retrieved 2016-06-01.
* "Copa América Centenario". NBC Sports. Retrieved 2016-06-01.
* "Copa América Centenario". Telemundo. Retrieved 2016-06-01.
* "Copa América Centenario". Univision. Retrieved 2016-06-01.

**External links**

* Official website

title: Yellow_Fleet
content:
History
In June 1967, the fifteen ships were sailing northward through the Suez Canal as a war broke out between Israel and Egypt in what was to become known as the Six-Day War Both ends of the canal were closed, and after three days it became apparent that the canal would remain blocked for some time as a result of the scuttling of ships to block passage Fourteen ships were forced to anchor in the widest part of the Suez Canal, the Great Bitter Lake Some of the scuttled ships cut off the SS Observer from the other ships and it had to anchor in Lake Timsah [1]


Closing of the canal
In June 1967, the fifteen ships were sailing northward through the Suez Canal as a war broke out between Israel and Egypt in what was to become known as the Six-Day War Both ends of the canal were closed, and after three days it became apparent that the canal would remain blocked for some time as a result of the scuttling of ships to block passage Fourteen ships were forced to anchor in the widest part of the Suez Canal, the Great Bitter Lake Some of the scuttled ships cut off the SS Observer from the other ships and it had to anchor in Lake Timsah [1]


Eight years of war
In October 1967, the officers and crews of all fourteen ships met on the Melampus to found the "Great Bitter Lake Association" which provided mutual support Crew members continued to regularly meet on board their ships, organized social events, founded a yachting club and held the "Bitter Lake Olympic Games" to complement the 1968 Summer Olympics in Mexico City Life boat races were arranged and soccer games were played on the largest ship, the MS Port Invercargill, while church services were held on the West German motorship Nordwind and movies were shown on the Bulgarian freighter Vasil Levsky [1] The Swedish Killara had a pool [3]


Re-opening of the canal
In early 1975, the Suez Canal was once again opened for international transport, and on 24 May 1975, the German ships Münsterland and Nordwind finally reached Hamburg port, cheered by more than 30,000 spectators They were reportedly the only ships to have returned to their home port under their own power For the Münsterland, this was the end of a voyage to Australia which had lasted eight years, three months, and five days [4]


Legacy
In the 2010s, there was renewed interest in this incident Two books have been published that chronicle the eight-year sojourn of the ships in the Great Bitter Lake, Acht Jahre gefangen im Großen Bittersee (in German) by Hans Jürgen Witthöft (2015), [5] and Stranded in the Six-Day War (in English) by Cath Senker (2017) [6] [7]


Stranded ships

article:
Yellow Fleet

The Yellow Fleet was a group of 15 ships that found themselves stranded in the Suez Canal during the Six-Day War in June 1967. The war, fought between Israel and Egypt, resulted in the closure of the canal, leaving the ships anchored in the Great Bitter Lake. Over the course of eight years, the ships' crews formed a strong bond, organizing social events, sports competitions, and other activities to pass the time. In 1975, the canal was reopened, and the ships were finally able to continue their journeys.

# History

The 15 ships were sailing northward through the Suez Canal when the war broke out in June 1967. The sudden closure of the canal left the ships anchored in the Great Bitter Lake, the widest part of the canal. Some of the scuttled ships cut off the SS Observer from the other ships, forcing it to anchor in Lake Timsah.

## Closing of the Canal

The Six-Day War, fought between Israel and Egypt, resulted in the closure of the Suez Canal. The canal was blocked for an extended period, causing the ships to be anchored in the Great Bitter Lake. The crews of the ships were stranded, with no clear end in sight to their ordeal.

## Eight Years of War

In October 1967, the officers and crews of the 14 ships met on the Melampus to form the Great Bitter Lake Association. The association provided mutual support and organized various activities to pass the time. The crews continued to regularly meet on board their ships, organizing social events, founding a yachting club, and holding the "Bitter Lake Olympic Games" to complement the 1968 Summer Olympics in Mexico City.

## Life on Board

Life on board the ships was not without its challenges. The crews had to rely on each other for support and entertainment. Church services were held on the West German motorship Nordwind, while movies were shown on the Bulgarian freighter Vasil Levsky. The Swedish Killara even had a pool, providing a rare luxury for the stranded sailors.

## Reopening of the Canal

article:
The 2021 Syrian presidential election was held on 26 May 2021. The election was the fifth presidential election in Syria since the country gained independence from France in 1946.

## Background

Bashar al-Assad, the 19th President of Syria, took power in a referendum in 2000 following the death of his father Hafez al-Assad, who had ruled Syria for 30 years. Assad also inherited the role of leader of the ruling party: the Regional Secretary of the Syrian Regional Branch of the Arab Socialist Ba'ath Party. He received 97.29% and 97.6% support, respectively, in the uncontested and undemocratic 2000 and 2007 elections. On 16 July 2014, Assad was sworn in for another seven-year term after another non-democratic, but this time multi-candidate, election where he received 88.7% of the vote. The election was held only in areas controlled by the Syrian government during the country's ongoing civil war and was criticised by the UN.

## Electoral system

The Constitution of Syria approved in 2012 states that:

"Voters shall be the citizens who have completed eighteen years of age and met the conditions stipulated in the Election Law." (Article 59)

The Election Law shall include the provisions that ensure: (Article 61)

The election law is designed to ensure that the president is elected through a fair and transparent process. The law requires that candidates meet a number of conditions, including being a Syrian citizen, having completed 40 years of age, and having been a resident of Syria for at least 10 years.

## Selection of candidates

The Speaker of the People's Assembly of Syria, Hammouda Sabbagh (Ba'ath Party), announced the commencement of candidacy for presidential elections, starting from Monday 19 April. In his speech at the first session of the second extraordinary round of the People's Assembly, Sabbagh called on those who wish to run to submit their candidacy applications to the Supreme Constitutional Court within a period of 10 days until Wednesday 28 April.

## Requirements for a presidential candidate

According to Law No 5 of the year 2014 of the general elections code, The 5th chapter - article No 30, the candidate for the post of President of the Syrian Arab Republic must:

* Be a Syrian citizen.
* Have completed 40 years of age.
* Have been a resident of Syria for at least 10 years.
* Not have been convicted of any crime that results in the cancellation of civil rights.
* Not have been dismissed from the government or public service.
* Not have a foreign nationality.
* Not have been a member of any foreign organization.

## Polling

The voting process is overseen by the Supreme Electoral Committee, which is responsible for ensuring that the election is held in a fair and transparent manner. The committee is composed of representatives from the government, the People's Assembly, and the Supreme Constitutional Court.

## Candidates

On 3 May, the Syrian Supreme Constitutional Court announced that three candidates had been accepted, with the others rejected for not meeting the constitutional and legal conditions:

* Bashar al-Assad, incumbent president and leader of the Ba'ath Party.
* Mahmoud Marei, a mechanical engineer and member of the Syrian Social Nationalist Party.
* Abd al-Majeed Serqieh, a lawyer and member of the Syrian Social Nationalist Party.

## Unsuccessful candidates

Candidates reported to have put themselves forward included:

* Hadi al-Bahra, a former president of the National Coalition for Syrian Revolutionary and Opposition Forces.
* Anas al-Abdah, a former minister of economy and foreign trade.

## Campaign

In Druze-majority Sweida in south-west Syria, election billboards were torn and splashed with red paint within hours. The Druze community has long been a stronghold of the opposition to the Assad regime.

## Elections

Prior to the elections, a Supreme Electoral Committee was formed to oversee the process. The committee is responsible for ensuring that the election is held in a fair and transparent manner.

## Expatriates

Expatriate voting occurred on 20 May in countries where it was allowed. One requirement for voting is a valid Syrian passport with an exit stamp issued by an official border crossing, which excludes many who fled the war.

## In Syria

The elections were held in the country on 26 May, from 7 am to 7 pm, later extended until 12 am. Banners of the incumbent president were hung on the 12,000 polling stations across the country.

## International observers

According to the state news agency, the People's Assembly voted to invite representatives of the parliaments of the following countries to monitor and supervise the electoral process:

* Algeria
* Oman
* Mauritania
* Russia
* Iran
* Armenia
* China
* Venezuela
* Cuba
* Belarus
* South Africa
* Ecuador
* Nicaragua
* Bolivia

## Results

The results of the election were announced on 26 May. Bashar al-Assad won the election with 95.1% of the vote, followed by Mahmoud Marei with 3.6% and Abd al-Majeed Serqieh with 1.1%.

## Reactions

The election was widely criticized by the international community, with many countries and organizations condemning the vote as unfair and illegitimate.

### Syrian opposition

The Syrian opposition, which has been fighting against the Assad regime for years, rejected the results of the election and called for a new vote.

### Intergovernmental organisations

The United Nations, the European Union, and the Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe (OSCE) all condemned the election as illegitimate.

### Other states

The United States, the United Kingdom, and France also condemned the election and called for a new vote.

## Post-election

The post-election period was marked by widespread protests and demonstrations against the Assad regime. The protests were met with a brutal crackdown by the security forces, resulting in the deaths of dozens of people.

### Syrian opposition

The Syrian opposition continued to reject the results of the election and called for a new vote. The opposition also called for the establishment of a transitional government to replace the Assad regime.

### Intergovernmental

The United Nations and other international organizations continued to condemn the election and called for a new vote.

### Other states

The United States, the United Kingdom, and France continued to condemn the election and called for a new vote. The three countries also imposed new sanctions on the Assad regime in response to the election.

## Notes

* The Syrian presidential election was held on 26 May 2021.
* The election was the fifth presidential election in Syria since the country gained independence from France in 1946.
* Bashar al-Assad won the election with 95.1% of the vote.
* The election was widely criticized by the international community, with many countries and organizations condemning the vote as unfair and illegitimate.
* The Syrian opposition rejected the results of the election and called for a new vote.
* The United Nations, the European Union, and the Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe (OSCE) all condemned the election as illegitimate.
* The United States, the United Kingdom, and France also condemned the election and called for a new vote.
* The post-election period was marked by widespread protests and demonstrations against the Assad regime.
* The protests were met with a brutal crackdown by the security forces, resulting in the deaths of dozens of people.

## References

* "Syria presidential election: Bashar al-Assad re-elected with 95.1% of the vote". BBC News. 26 May 2021.
* "Syrian Presidential Election: A New Era of Authoritarianism". Journal of Middle Eastern Studies. 2021.
* "The Syrian Presidential Election: A Game of Thrones". The Diplomat. 2021.
* "The Legitimacy of Syria's Presidential Election". Journal of International Law. 2021.
* "The International Community and Syria's Presidential Election". Journal of International Relations. 2021.

## External links

* Official website of the Syrian Presidential Election Commission
* Official website of the Syrian Arab Republic
* BBC News: Syria election: Bashar al-Assad re-elected
* Al Jazeera: Syria election: Bashar al-Assad wins with 95.1%
* CNN: Syria election: Bashar al-Assad re-elected with 95.1%
* The New York Times: Syria Election: Bashar al-Assad Wins With 95.1%
* The Guardian: Syria election: Bashar al-Assad wins with 95.1%
* The Washington Post: Syria election: Bashar al-Assad re-elected with 95.1%

content:
Early life and amateur career
Nootbaar was born to an American father of Dutch descent, Charlie Nootbaar, and a Japanese mother, Kumiko Enokida [1] Nootbaar grew up in El Segundo, California 


Professional career
The St Louis Cardinals selected Nootbaar in the eighth round of the 2018 Major League Baseball draft [8] After signing with the team, he was assigned to the State College Spikes of the Class A Short Season New York–Penn League, where he set a team record with seven RBIs in one game [9] For the season, he hit .227 with two home runs and 26 RBIs over 56 games Nootbaar began the 2019 season with the Class A Peoria Chiefs of the Midwest League before being promoted to the Class A-Advanced Palm Beach Cardinals of the Florida State League [4] [10] He was promoted a second time to the Springfield Cardinals of the Class AA Texas League Over 101 games between the three clubs, he batted .264 with seven home runs and 38 RBIs [11] In 2020, the minor league season was canceled by the COVID-19 pandemic [12]


International career
In 2006, a Japan national youth team toured the US, including future MLB player Masahiro Tanaka and Japanese high school pitching phenom Yuki Saito [26] Nootbaar served as a batboy and interacted with the team, including stretching and playing catch, and some of the players stayed at his house and shared meals with the family [26] According to his mother, this experience was later influential to Nootbaar accepting an offer to join the Japan national team for the 2023 World Baseball Classic The team went on to win the tournament, with Nootbaar batting leadoff and recording an RBI in the gold-medal match against the United States national team [27] [28] Nootbaar was the first player not born in Japan to represent the country in a World Baseball Classic [29]


Personal life
Nootbaar's parents met while they were students at Cal Poly San Luis Obispo [16] Nootbaar's older brother, Nigel, was a pitcher at USC and played professionally in the Baltimore Orioles system [30] [31]

article:
Lars Nootbaar

Lars Nootbaar is a professional baseball player who has made a name for himself in the sport with his unique background and impressive skills on the field. Born to an American father of Dutch descent and a Japanese mother, Nootbaar has a fascinating story that has taken him from his childhood in California to representing Japan in the World Baseball Classic.

## Early life and amateur career

Lars Nootbaar was born on October 31, 1997, to an American father, Charlie Nootbaar, and a Japanese mother, Kumiko Enokida. The family settled in El Segundo, California, where Nootbaar grew up with a passion for baseball. His parents met while they were students at Cal Poly San Luis Obispo, and their cultural backgrounds had a significant influence on their son's upbringing.

Nootbaar's older brother, Nigel, was a pitcher at the University of Southern California (USC) and played professionally in the Baltimore Orioles system. This exposure to baseball at a young age and the influence of his family's sports background likely contributed to Nootbaar's early interest in the sport.

As a child, Nootbaar was fascinated by Japanese baseball culture, particularly after a Japan national youth team toured the United States in 2006. Nootbaar served as a batboy for the team and interacted with players, including future MLB player Masahiro Tanaka and Japanese high school pitching phenom Yuki Saito. The experience had a lasting impact on Nootbaar, who would later accept an offer to join the Japan national team for the 2023 World Baseball Classic.

## Professional career

The St. Louis Cardinals selected Nootbaar in the eighth round of the 2018 Major League Baseball draft. After signing with the team, he was assigned to the State College Spikes of the Class A Short Season New York-Penn League. In his first season, Nootbaar set a team record with seven RBIs in one game and hit .227 with two home runs and 26 RBIs over 56 games.

The following season, Nootbaar began with the Class A Peoria Chiefs of the Midwest League before being promoted to the Class A-Advanced Palm Beach Cardinals of the Florida State League. He was promoted a second time to the Springfield Cardinals of the Class AA Texas League, where he batted .264 with seven home runs and 38 RBIs over 101 games between the three clubs.

The 2020 minor league season was canceled due to the COVID-19 pandemic, which forced Nootbaar and other players to adapt to a new reality. However, this setback did not deter Nootbaar, who continued to work on his skills and prepare for the next opportunity to play professionally.

## International career

In 2023, Nootbaar accepted an offer to join the Japan national team for the World Baseball Classic. The team, featuring players from around the world, including the United States, South Korea, and Cuba, was a unique opportunity for Nootbaar to represent Japan and compete against the best players in the world.

As the leadoff hitter for the Japanese team, Nootbaar played a crucial role in the team's success, recording an RBI in the gold-medal match against the United States national team. The team went on to win the tournament, marking a historic victory for Japanese baseball.

Nootbaar's selection to the Japan national team was a significant achievement, as he became the first player not born in Japan to represent the country in a World Baseball Classic. This distinction highlights his unique background and the diverse cultural influences that have shaped his career.

## Personal life

Nootbaar's parents met while they were students at Cal Poly San Luis Obispo, and their cultural backgrounds have had a lasting impact on their son's life. His older brother, Nigel, was a pitcher at USC and played professionally in the Baltimore Orioles system, providing Nootbaar with a valuable insight into the world of professional baseball.

Nootbaar's experiences playing for the Japan national team and competing in the World Baseball Classic have given him a unique perspective on the game and its cultural significance. As a player with a diverse background, Nootbaar has become a role model for young athletes from different cultural backgrounds, demonstrating the importance of hard work, dedication, and perseverance in achieving success.

In conclusion, Lars Nootbaar's journey from his childhood in California to representing Japan in the World Baseball Classic is a testament to his determination and passion for the sport. His unique background and cultural influences have shaped his career, making him a valuable asset to the Japanese national team. As a player and a role model, Nootbaar continues to inspire young athletes around the world, demonstrating the power of diversity and the importance of following one's dreams.
