article:
ASAP Rocky

Introduction
ASAP Rocky, whose real name is Rakim Athelaston Mayers, is an American rapper, singer, songwriter, and record producer. He was born on October 3, 1988, in the Harlem neighborhood of Manhattan, New York City. Mayers' music career began in 2007 when he joined the A$AP Mob collective, a group of rappers, producers, and fashion designers from Harlem. Since then, he has released several successful albums and singles, and has collaborated with numerous artists.

Early Life
Rakim Athelaston Mayers was born on October 3, 1988, in the Harlem neighborhood of Manhattan, a borough of New York City. His father is from Barbados, and Mayers has an older brother (deceased) and an older sister, Erika. Both Rakim and Erika's names are taken from the Eric B & Rakim duo. Mayers' cousin is fellow ASAP Mob member ASAP Nast.

Career
## 2007–2011: Career beginnings
In 2007, Mayers joined the A$AP Mob crew, a Harlem-based collective of rappers, producers, music video directors, fashion designers, and bikers who shared similar interests in music, fashion, style, and art. It had been formed by A$AP Yams, A$AP Bari, and A$AP Illz. In July 2011, Mayers released his single "Purple Swag," which quickly became a street anthem in New York City.

## 2012–2014: Touring and Long. Live. A$AP
In February 2012, Mayers joined Kendrick Lamar as the opening act for Drake's Club Paradise Tour. In June, SpaceGhostPurrp, founder of Miami-based collective Raider Klan and Mayers' past collaborator, accused A$AP Twelvyy of jumping Raider Klan's Matt Stoops and subsequently disassociated himself from A$AP Mob and Mayers in a YouTube video. He and Raider Klan also accused ASAP Mob of copying their style, and Mayers of using lyrics from SpaceGhostPurrp's song "My Enemy" on "Goldie." Mayers responded in a July interview for MTV, saying that SpaceGhostPurrp is "try[ing] to build hype" and told him to "stick to makin' beats."

## 2015–2017: At. Long. Last. A$AP
On March 16, 2014, Mayers announced that he was working on his second studio album, entitled A.L.L.A (an acronym for At Long Last A$AP), which was a follow-up to his debut album, Long Live A$AP. Upon the wake of a delay of the ASAP Mob album, L.O.R.D., Mayers subsequently collaborated with cohorts A$AP Ferg, Nast, and Twelvyy on the album's third single, "Hella Hoes," which was released on June 6, 2014. Nonetheless, A$AP Mob leader A$AP Yams announced on his Tumblr account that the album had been shelved. On October 3, 2014, his 26th birthday, Mayers launched a short-lived music giveaway called Flacko Jodye Season, which first premiered with "Multiply," which featured additional vocals from Juicy J; later released on iTunes one week after its premiere.

## 2018–present: Testing and upcoming fourth studio album
On January 23, 2018, Mayers released "☆☆☆☆☆ 5ive $tar$" on SoundCloud, produced by Metro Boomin, Frans Mernick, Jordan Blackmon, and Daniel Lynas, and featuring uncredited vocals by DRAM. Over the following two days, he shared "Above," produced by Mernick, and "Money Bags Freestyle (Dean Blunt Meditation)," produced by Blunt and featuring uncredited vocals by Lil Yachty. The songs were captioned "TESTING COMING SOON" and "THIS IS JUST A TEST," leading to speculation that they were in promotion of an upcoming studio album entitled Testing. On February 16, Mayers collaborated with Gucci Mane and 21 Savage for "Cocky," in promotion of the film Uncle Drew. He released the single "Bad Company" on March 27, featuring rapper BlocBoy JB, as well as further allusions to Testing in its marketing. On April 5, he released a second single: "ASAP Forever." The song samples record producer Moby's 2000 single "Porcelain," crediting him as a featured artist. It was premiered on The Tonight Show alongside new track "Distorted Records," and a music video was released the following day.

Business Ventures
In October 2011, Mayers signed a record deal with Sony Music Entertainment worth $3 million ($1.7 million of which was earmarked for his solo work; $1.3 million earmarked to fund his company). Mayers said that he sought a "bigger platform" for him and his collective with the deal. His first studio album planned to be under the deal, but it allowed him to continue releasing mixtapes through Sony/RED. Fellow rapper and A$AP Mob member A$AP Ferg also signed a joint venture deal with the RCA-distributed Polo Grounds Music; Ferg released his single "Work," for digital retail via various platforms. He later announced an official remix featuring Mayers, French Montana, ScHoolboy Q, and Trinidad James.

Personal Life
From 2011 to 2012, Mayers dated Australian rapper Iggy Azalea. He began dating model Chanel Iman in early 2013, and in April 2014, they were reported to be engaged, but broke up in June 2014.

Legal Issues
In 2006, Mayers served two weeks in Rikers Island, where he shared a cell with future rapper Casanova. In July 2019, Mayers was arrested initially for aggravated, then for simple assault in Stockholm, Sweden, after an altercation in the street against a man named Mustafa Jafari and another person that involved Mayers and three of his entourage on June 30. Jafari was beaten, kicked, and cut with broken bottles when down on the ground. He suffered several cuts, requiring stitches, and a fractured rib. Mayers uploaded two videos of the incident to Instagram. In the first, he and his entourage repeatedly ask two young men, including Jafari, to stop following them as the latter complains about his headphones. In the other, created from footage of assorted events, Jafari's headphones break during a scuffle, and he is seen hitting Mayers' bodyguard with them. A woman is also seen in the video, accusing the two men of groping. Henrik Olsson Lilja, the defense attorney for Mayers, maintained that his client acted in self-defense after being attacked by Jafari.

He was arrested for a potential assault with a deadly weapon in a shooting that took place in Hollywood on November 6, 2021. The shooting victim, who survived the incident, was reported to be former friend and collaborator Terell Ephron, better known as ASAP Relli. Bail was set at $550,000, and he was released shortly after.

Studio albums

* At. Long. Last. A$AP (2015)
* Testing (2018)
* In Real Life (2021)

Tours

* Long. Live. A$AP Tour
* At. Long. Last. A$AP Tour
* Testing Tour

Accomplishments

title: Nate_Diaz
content:
Background
The son of Melissa (née Womble) and Robert Diaz, he was born of Mexican and Anglo heritage and raised in Stockton, California, with his brother Nick and sister Nina [10] [11] He grew up in Lodi, California [12] and attended Tokay High School At the age of 11, he began training in martial arts with his brother, Nick.


Mixed martial arts career
Prior to his official MMA career, Diaz competed in a bare knuckle MMA fight against Robert Limon on July 20, 2002, at the age of 17 [13] Footage has since emerged of the fight and it is believed to be his first competitive experience [14]


Early career
Prior to his official MMA career, Diaz competed in a bare knuckle MMA fight against Robert Limon on July 20, 2002, at the age of 17 [13] Footage has since emerged of the fight and it is believed to be his first competitive experience [14]


Ultimate Fighting Championship
Diaz was a contestant on The Ultimate Fighter 5, which exclusively featured lightweights, fighting on Jens Pulver's team In the preliminary round, Diaz defeated Rob Emerson by submission; in the quarterfinals he defeated fellow Team Pulver teammate Corey Hill via triangle choke submission in the first round In the semifinals, Diaz defeated Team Penn member Gray Maynard by submission, advancing to the finals, in which he faced teammate Manvel Gamburyan Diaz won by submission after Gamburyan was forced to tap out in the second round due to the dislocation of his right shoulder as the result of attempting a takedown [15] With the victory, Diaz won The Ultimate Fighter 5 [16]


The Ultimate Fighter 5
Diaz was a contestant on The Ultimate Fighter 5, which exclusively featured lightweights, fighting on Jens Pulver's team In the preliminary round, Diaz defeated Rob Emerson by submission; in the quarterfinals he defeated fellow Team Pulver teammate Corey Hill via triangle choke submission in the first round In the semifinals, Diaz defeated Team Penn member Gray Maynard by submission, advancing to the finals, in which he faced teammate Manvel Gamburyan Diaz won by submission after Gamburyan was forced to tap out in the second round due to the dislocation of his right shoulder as the result of attempting a takedown [15] With the victory, Diaz won The Ultimate Fighter 5 [16]


2008
After defeating Alvin Robinson and Junior Assunção via submission, Diaz demanded tougher opponents He was given a match with Kurt Pellegrino at UFC Fight Night 13 Diaz defeated Pellegrino via triangle-choke submission in the second round As he locked up the choke, Diaz had time to flex for the crowd and throw up double middle fingers before Pellegrino submitted Diaz then defeated veteran Josh Neer by split decision in the main event of UFC Fight Night 15.


2009
Diaz next fought former Strikeforce Lightweight Champion Clay Guida at UFC 94: St Pierre vs Penn 2, losing via split decision Guida used his wrestling to take Diaz down multiple times Guida won via split decision, marking Diaz's first loss in the UFC, in what was also his pay per view debut.


2010
Diaz faced Gray Maynard on January 11, 2010, in the main event at UFC Fight Night 20, a rematch from when the two met in the semi-finals of the TUF 5 lightweight tournament, which Diaz won Diaz lost a controversial split decision to Maynard, as the former TUF winner was given the nod in the FightMetric reports, winning rounds two and three [17] [18]


2011
Diaz next faced South Korean fighter Dong Hyun Kim, on January 1, 2011, at UFC 125 [22] Diaz lost the fight via unanimous decision.


2012
Diaz, after several years of training, finally received his Brazilian jiu-jitsu black belt from Cesar Gracie [30] He was awarded his black belt a month before his fight with fellow Brazilian jiu-jitsu black belt Jim Miller.


2013
Diaz faced former Strikeforce Lightweight Champion Josh Thomson on April 20, 2013, at UFC on Fox 7 He lost the fight via TKO due to a head kick and punches, during which Nate's brother, Nick Diaz physically threw a towel into the octagon, in an attempt to signal the referee to end the bout [37] [38] On May 16, 2013, Diaz was suspended by the UFC for violating the UFC's code of conduct by using a homophobic slur on his Twitter page The UFC expressed their disappointment and suspended him; [39] he was eventually suspended for 90 days and fined $20,000 [40]


2014
On May 5, 2014, both Nate Diaz and fellow UFC fighter T J Grant were removed from the UFC's lightweight rankings after being deemed inactive by the UFC [44]


2015
Diaz was briefly linked to a welterweight bout with Matt Brown on July 11, 2015, at UFC 189 [47]  However, in mid-April, Brown announced that the pairing had been scrapped [48]


2016
Diaz was set as a replacement to face Conor McGregor on March 5, 2016, at UFC 196, filling in for an injured Rafael dos Anjos [52] With Diaz only having eleven days notice, the fight took place at welterweight (170 lbs) due to lack of time to cut weight [53] Diaz won the fight via submission in the second round [54] This gave Diaz his ninth submission victory in the UFC, tied for the second-most all-time behind only Royce Gracie Both fighters were awarded Fight of the Night honors and Diaz was also awarded with the Performance of the Night bonus [55]


2018
After a two-year-long layoff, it was announced on August 3, 2018, that Diaz was expected to return on November 3 against Dustin Poirier in a lightweight bout This bout was expected to serve as the co-headliner of UFC 230 [63] However, on October 9, 2018, it was announced that Poirier pulled out due to injury and as a result, the bout was canceled [64]


2019
Nate Diaz returned to competition on August 17 at UFC 241 He faced Anthony Pettis in a welterweight bout which served as the co-main event [65] With a dominant performance, he won the fight by unanimous decision [66]


2021
Diaz was expected to face Leon Edwards on May 15, 2021, at UFC 262 in the event's co-headliner, marking the first time a non-main event and non-title bout had been scheduled for 5 rounds [70] However, the bout was moved to UFC 263 due to a minor injury sustained by Diaz and eventually took place for five rounds as well [71] Edwards controlled a vast majority of the bout, but was stunned badly with punches late in the fifth Edwards won the fight by unanimous decision (49–46, 49–46, 49–46) [72]


2022
On the last fight of his UFC contract, Diaz was scheduled to face Khamzat Chimaev on September 10, 2022, in the main event of UFC 279 [73] However, at the weigh-ins on September 9, Chimaev weighed in at 178.5 pounds, seven-and-a-half pounds over the welterweight non-title fight limit [74] As a result of Chimaev missing weight, he was removed from his bout with Diaz Diaz instead faced Tony Ferguson in the main event [75] Diaz won the fight via a guillotine choke submission in the fourth round [76] This win earned Diaz his second Performance of the Night bonus award [77] Diaz opted to not re-sign with the UFC before the bout with Ferguson, thus making Diaz a free agent once the fight concluded [78]


Boxing career
After becoming a free agent, Diaz decided to enter into the sport of boxing On April 12, 2023, it was announced that Diaz would be making his professional boxing debut against Jake Paul The bout took place on August 5, 2023, at the American Airlines Center in Dallas, Texas [79] Paul defeated Diaz via unanimous decision with scores of 98–91, 98–91, and 97–92 [80] [81]


Diaz vs. Paul
After becoming a free agent, Diaz decided to enter into the sport of boxing On April 12, 2023, it was announced that Diaz would be making his professional boxing debut against Jake Paul The bout took place on August 5, 2023, at the American Airlines Center in Dallas, Texas [79] Paul defeated Diaz via unanimous decision with scores of 98–91, 98–91, and 97–92 [80] [81]


Diaz vs. Masvidal
On March 13, 2024, it was announced that Diaz would face Jorge Masvidal on June 1, 2024, at the Kia Forum in Los Angeles, California [82] in a 10-round bout at light heavyweight [83] On May 7, 2024, it was reported that the fight was rescheduled for July 6, 2024 at Honda Center in Anaheim, CA [84] [85] [86] On May 13, 2024, the new event date was confirmed for July 6, 2024 [87] [88] Diaz won the bout by majority decision [89] [90]


Fanmio Lawsuit
After the boxing match with Jorge Masvidal, Diaz launched a lawsuit against Fanmio and its owner, Solomon Engel for fraud and breach of contract; alleging that he was only paid $1 million out of the total $10 million purse he was promised [91]


Personal life
Diaz's older brother Nick is also a professional MMA fighter [62]  Both Diaz brothers are advocates for cannabis and even have a licensed line of marijuana pre-rolls made by California Finest [92] [93] [94] [95] They currently run a Brazilian jiu-jitsu school in Stockton, California (Nick Diaz Academy), and founded a CBD company called Game Up Nutrition [96] He has been primarily vegan since he was 18 years old, [97] [98] but admits to eating fish from time to time [99] On June 20, 2018, it was announced that Diaz's girlfriend had given birth to their daughter [100]


Championships and accomplishments
 [118]


Mixed martial arts record
 [118]

article:
**Nate Diaz**

Nate Diaz is an American professional mixed martial artist and boxer. He is the younger brother of fellow MMA fighter Nick Diaz.

**Background**

Diaz was born on April 16, 1985, in Stockton, California, to Melissa (née Womble) and Robert Diaz. He has Mexican and Anglo heritage and grew up in Lodi, California, with his brother Nick and sister Nina. Diaz began training in martial arts at the age of 11 with his brother.

**Mixed martial arts career**

Before his official MMA career, Diaz competed in a bare-knuckle MMA fight against Robert Limon on July 20, 2002, at the age of 17. Footage has since emerged of the fight, which is believed to be his first competitive experience.

**Early career**

Diaz's early MMA career was marked by a series of impressive victories. He competed in a bare-knuckle MMA fight against Robert Limon on July 20, 2002, at the age of 17. Diaz's early MMA career was marked by a series of impressive victories, earning him a reputation as a formidable fighter.

**Ultimate Fighting Championship**

Diaz was a contestant on The Ultimate Fighter 5, which exclusively featured lightweights, fighting on Jens Pulver's team. Diaz won the show, defeating Manvel Gamburyan in the finals. His victory over Gamburyan marked his first appearance in the UFC.

**2008**

After defeating Alvin Robinson and Junior Assunção via submission, Diaz demanded tougher opponents. He was given a match with Kurt Pellegrino at UFC Fight Night 13, which he won via triangle-choke submission in the second round.

**2009**

Diaz next fought former Strikeforce Lightweight Champion Clay Guida at UFC 94: St Pierre vs Penn 2, losing via split decision. Guida used his wrestling to take Diaz down multiple times, winning via split decision.

**2010**

Diaz faced Gray Maynard on January 11, 2010, in the main event at UFC Fight Night 20. Diaz lost a controversial split decision to Maynard, as the former TUF winner was given the nod in the FightMetric reports.

**2011**

Diaz next faced South Korean fighter Dong Hyun Kim, on January 1, 2011, at UFC 125. Diaz lost the fight via unanimous decision.

**2012**

Diaz, after several years of training, finally received his Brazilian jiu-jitsu black belt from Cesar Gracie. He was awarded his black belt a month before his fight with fellow Brazilian jiu-jitsu black belt Jim Miller.

**2013**

Diaz faced former Strikeforce Lightweight Champion Josh Thomson on April 20, 2013, at UFC on Fox 7. Diaz lost the fight via TKO due to a head kick and punches. On May 16, 2013, Diaz was suspended by the UFC for violating the UFC's code of conduct by using a homophobic slur on his Twitter page.

**2014**

On May 5, 2014, both Nate Diaz and fellow UFC fighter T J Grant were removed from the UFC's lightweight rankings after being deemed inactive by the UFC.

**2015**

Diaz was briefly linked to a welterweight bout with Matt Brown on July 11, 2015, at UFC 189. However, in mid-April, Brown announced that the pairing had been scrapped.

**2016**

Diaz was set as a replacement to face Conor McGregor on March 5, 2016, at UFC 196. Diaz won the fight via submission in the second round, earning his ninth submission victory in the UFC.

**2018**

After a two-year-long layoff, it was announced on August 3, 2018, that Diaz was expected to return on November 3 against Dustin Poirier in a lightweight bout. However, on October 9, 2018, it was announced that Poirier pulled out due to injury and as a result, the bout was canceled.

**2019**

Nate Diaz returned to competition on August 17 at UFC 241. He faced Anthony Pettis in a welterweight bout, which he won via unanimous decision.

**2021**

Diaz was expected to face Leon Edwards on May 15, 2021, at UFC 262. However, the bout was moved to UFC 263 due to a minor injury sustained by Diaz. Edwards won the fight via unanimous decision.

**2022**

On the last fight of his UFC contract, Diaz was scheduled to face Khamzat Chimaev on September 10, 2022, in the main event of UFC 279. However, at the weigh-ins on September 9, Chimaev weighed in at 178.5 pounds, seven-and-a-half pounds over the welterweight non-title fight limit. As a result of Chimaev missing weight, he was removed from his bout with Diaz. Diaz instead faced Tony Ferguson in the main event and won the fight via guillotine choke submission in the fourth round.

**Boxing career**

After becoming a free agent, Diaz decided to enter into the sport of boxing. On April 12, 2023, it was announced that Diaz would be making his professional boxing debut against Jake Paul on August 5, 2023, at the American Airlines Center in Dallas, Texas. Paul defeated Diaz via unanimous decision.

**Diaz vs. Masvidal**

On March 13, 2024, it was announced that Diaz would face Jorge Masvidal on June 1, 2024, at the Kia Forum in Los Angeles, California. Diaz won the bout by majority decision.

**Fanmio Lawsuit**

After the boxing match with Jorge Masvidal, Diaz launched a lawsuit against Fanmio and its owner, Solomon Engel for fraud and breach of contract. He alleged that he was only paid $1 million out of the total $10 million purse he was promised.

**Personal life**

Diaz's older brother Nick is also a professional MMA fighter. Both Diaz brothers are advocates for cannabis and even have a licensed line of marijuana pre-rolls made by California Finest. They currently run a Brazilian jiu-jitsu school in Stockton, California (Nick Diaz Academy), and founded a CBD company called Game Up Nutrition. Diaz has been primarily vegan since he was 18 years old, but admits to eating fish from time to time. On June 20, 2018, it was announced that Diaz's girlfriend had given birth to their daughter.

**Championships and accomplishments**

Diaz has won several championships and awards throughout his career. He won The Ultimate Fighter 5 and has held the title of UFC Lightweight Championship. He has also won the Fight of the Night award twice and the Performance of the Night award three times.

**Mixed martial arts record**

Diaz has a professional MMA record of 20-13. His record includes 15 wins by submission and 2 wins by KO.

**Professional boxing record**

Diaz's professional boxing record is 0-1.

**Pay-per-view bouts**

Diaz has participated in several pay-per-view bouts throughout his career. His first pay-per-view bout was at UFC 196 against Conor McGregor.

On the last fight of his UFC contract, Diaz was scheduled to face Khamzat Chimaev on September 10, 2022, in the main event of UFC 279 [73] However, at the weigh-ins on September 9, Chimaev weighed in at 178.5 pounds, seven-and-a-half pounds over the welterweight non-title fight limit [74] As a result of Chimaev missing weight, he was removed from his bout with Diaz Diaz instead faced Tony Ferguson in the main event [75] Diaz won the fight via a guillotine choke submission in the fourth round [76] This win earned Diaz his second Performance of the Night bonus award [77] Diaz opted to not re-sign with the UFC before the bout with Ferguson, thus making Diaz a free agent once the fight concluded [78]


Boxing career
After becoming a free agent, Diaz decided to enter into the sport of boxing On April 12, 2023, it was announced that Diaz would be making his professional boxing debut against Jake Paul The bout took place on August 5, 2023, at the American Airlines Center in Dallas, Texas [79] Paul defeated Diaz via unanimous decision with scores of 98–91, 98–91, and 97–92 [80] [81]


Diaz vs. Paul
After becoming a free agent, Diaz decided to enter into the sport of boxing On April 12, 2023, it was announced that Diaz would be making his professional boxing debut against Jake Paul The bout took place on August 5, 2023, at the American Airlines Center in Dallas, Texas [79] Paul defeated Diaz via unanimous decision with scores of 98–91, 98–91, and 97–92 [80] [81]


Diaz vs. Masvidal
On March 13, 2024, it was announced that Diaz would face Jorge Masvidal on June 1, 2024, at the Kia Forum in Los Angeles, California [82] in a 10-round bout at light heavyweight [83] On May 7, 2024, it was reported that the fight was rescheduled for July 6, 2024 at Honda Center in Anaheim, CA [84] [85] [86] On May 13, 2024, the new event date was confirmed for July 6, 2024 [87] [88] Diaz won the bout by majority decision [89] [90]


Fanmio Lawsuit
After the boxing match with Jorge Masvidal, Diaz launched a lawsuit against Fanmio and its owner, Solomon Engel for fraud and breach of contract; alleging that he was only paid $1 million out of the total $10 million purse he was promised [91]


Personal life
Diaz's older brother Nick is also a professional MMA fighter [62]  Both Diaz brothers are advocates for cannabis and even have a licensed line of marijuana pre-rolls made by California Finest [92] [93] [94] [95] They currently run a Brazilian jiu-jitsu school in Stockton, California (Nick Diaz Academy), and founded a CBD company called Game Up Nutrition [96] He has been primarily vegan since he was 18 years old, [97] [98] but admits to eating fish from time to time [99] On June 20, 2018, it was announced that Diaz's girlfriend had given birth to their daughter [100]

In 2011, Spears moved to Nashville and began working on a country music album with local music producers [19] On November 7, 2011, Spears held a small concert at The Rutledge in Nashville [27] On November 25, 2013, Spears released her first single "How Could I Want More" [28] [29] The song debuted at number 29 on Billboard's Hot Country Songs, and at number 8 on the Country Digital Songs chart, for the week ending December 7, 2013 [30] [31] Kevin Rutherford of Billboard described Spears' performance as "sweet and innocent" yet powerful, and suggested the song would fit right in at country radio [32] The song was named Taste of Country's Top Critic's Pick [33]

In an episode that aired on July 13, 2018, Spears returned to Nickelodeon for the first time in over ten years as a contestant on the revived game show Double Dare with her daughter Maddie, competing against fellow All That alumnus Josh Server and his niece [42] She and Maddie won over $15,000 to donate to the New Orleans hospital that treated Maddie in 2017 [43]

Teenage pregnancy
On December 20, 2007, in an interview with OK! magazine, Spears announced that she was pregnant by her then boyfriend, Casey Aldridge [97] She was 16 years old at the time Aldridge, whom she had been dating for two years, was 18 [98] Spears confirmed her engagement to Aldridge in March 2008 [99] In May 2008, the couple moved to Liberty, Mississippi, and purchased a house, with Spears stating they would raise their child there [100] She gave birth to their daughter Maddie Briann Aldridge on June 19, 2008, in McComb, Mississippi [101] [102] [103]
Spears and Aldridge ended their engagement in March 2009, [104] [105] and Spears moved out in December 2009 [106] The couple reconciled in August 2010, [107] but ended their relationship a second time in November 2010 [108]


Marriage and family
She subsequently began a relationship with Jamie Watson, a businessman who owns the communications service Advanced Media Partners After two years of on-and-off dating, they announced their engagement in March 2013 [114] [115] On March 14, 2014, she married Watson in New Orleans [116] On April 11, 2018, Spears gave birth to her second daughter [117] [118]


ATV incident
On February 5, 2017, Spears' eight-year-old daughter Maddie almost drowned in a Polaris ATV accident, after accidentally driving into the pond on her stepfather and mother's Louisiana property, with the ATV flipping over upon impact She was later airlifted to Children's Hospital of New Orleans, where she remained unconscious in a coma for two days She woke up and was released from care on February 10 [119] Police reported the incident as occurring before 3:00 p.m on a Sunday afternoon, and the sheriff explained that she was steering "100 yards from her parents" when she took "a hard right to avoid running over a nearby drainage ditch" The police report stated, "The child was trapped and secured by the seatbelt and the ATV's safety netting Within two minutes, Acadian Ambulance Services arrived and assisted in freeing the child from the cold waters." Feud with Britney Spears
In 2021, Jamie Lynn and her sister Britney were involved in a highly publicized feud via social media Britney publicly accused Jamie Lynn of actively and knowingly being involved in her conservatorship, while not making any efforts to help her terminate it Jamie Lynn denied the allegations and maintained that she was unaware of the details of the conservatorship Britney threatened legal action against Jamie Lynn after the latter spoke extensively about Britney in both her book and the following promotional tour [123]

article:
**Jamie Lynn Spears**

Jamie Lynn Spears is an American actress, singer, and songwriter. She is the younger sister of pop star Britney Spears and rose to fame as a teenager in the early 2000s.

**Early Life**

Jamie Lynn Spears was born on April 4, 1991, in McComb, Mississippi. She was raised in Kentwood, Louisiana, with her parents, Jamie and Lynne Spears, and her older brother, Bryan. Her parents divorced in 2002, but they remained in an on-and-off relationship after the divorce. Jamie Lynn has described her home life as unstable, but she remembers "feeling very loved." She attended Parklane Academy in McComb, where she was a cheerleader and the point guard of the basketball team. She also enrolled in dance and voice lessons and participated in school plays and church performances.

**Career**

Jamie Lynn Spears began her acting career at a young age. In February 2002, at the age of 10, she made her acting debut in the Paramount Pictures drama film Crossroads, which starred her sister, Britney. Spears made a cameo appearance in the film, playing the younger version of Britney's character. In April 2002, she walked the runway as a model for the Kids R Us fashion show in New York City.

Following Crossroads, Nickelodeon cast Spears as a regular performer in the sketch comedy series All That for the 2002 season. She appeared on the show through 2004 and portrayed various roles throughout her two seasons on the show. Spears also made appearances on Snick On-Air Dare, Nickelodeon's version of Fear Factor. She decided to pursue other roles on the network and departed from the main cast on the tenth and final season of All That, appearing only as a guest. At the age of 13, Spears was named as one of the celebrities on Teen People's Young Hollywood/Hot List.

**2002-2008: Career Beginnings and Success with All That and Zoey 101**

Jamie Lynn Spears' career continued to thrive in the early 2000s. In 2002, she landed a role on the Nickelodeon sitcom Zoey 101, playing the character of Zoey Brooks. The show was a huge success, and Spears became a fan favorite. She appeared on the show from 2005 to 2008 and was a main cast member for the first three seasons.

During her time on Zoey 101, Spears also pursued her music career. In 2007, she released her debut single, "How Could I Want More," which was a moderate success. The song peaked at number 29 on the Billboard Hot Country Songs chart and number 8 on the Country Digital Songs chart.

**2011-2017: Country Music Debut**

In 2011, Spears moved to Nashville to pursue a career in country music. She began working on her debut country album with local music producers. On November 7, 2011, Spears held a small concert at The Rutledge in Nashville. On November 25, 2013, she released her first single, "How Could I Want More," which was a country music debut. The song was well-received by critics and fans alike.

**2018-2023: Return to Acting, Zoey 102, Memoir, and Reality Television**

In 2018, Jamie Lynn Spears returned to acting, appearing in the revived game show Double Dare on Nickelodeon. She competed against fellow All That alum Josh Server and his niece. Spears and her daughter, Maddie, won over $15,000 to donate to the New Orleans hospital that treated Maddie in 2017.

In 2020, Spears released her memoir, "Things I Should Have Said." The book became a bestseller and was reviewed positively by critics. Spears has since spoken extensively about her experiences and has been open about her struggles with mental health and relationships.

**2024-Present: Upcoming Projects**

In 2024, Jamie Lynn Spears began filming the fourth season of Sweet Magnolias. The filming for the season ended in June 2024. On September 21, 2024, she competed in a charity softball game at the University of Louisiana at Monroe to help the school's softball team raise funds.

**Public Image**

Jamie Lynn Spears' public image has undergone significant changes over the years. In the early years of her career, she had a generally wholesome image as a teen star. However, her fame increased dramatically in the wake of her pregnancy announcement in December 2007. During the following months, she became a frequent target of the paparazzi. In subsequent years, Spears was rarely seen in the public eye and focused on family.

**Personal Life**

Jamie Lynn Spears is a practicing Catholic, as are her daughters and her mother, Lynne. She attended First Baptist Church in Kentwood, Louisiana, before converting to Catholicism in early 2018.

**Teenage Pregnancy**

In December 2007, Jamie Lynn Spears announced that she was pregnant with her then-boyfriend, Casey Aldridge. She was 16 years old at the time, and Aldridge was 18. Spears confirmed her engagement to Aldridge in March 2008. In May 2008, the couple moved to Liberty, Mississippi, and purchased a house, stating they would raise their child there. She gave birth to their daughter, Maddie Briann Aldridge, on June 19, 2008.

**Marriage and Family**

After her teenage pregnancy, Spears began a relationship with Jamie Watson, a businessman who owns the communications service Advanced Media Partners. After two years of on-and-off dating, they announced their engagement in March 2013. On March 14, 2014, Spears married Watson in New Orleans. On April 11, 2018, Spears gave birth to her second daughter.

**ATV Incident**

On February 5, 2017, Jamie Lynn Spears' eight-year-old daughter, Maddie, almost drowned in a Polaris ATV accident. Maddie accidentally drove the ATV into the pond on her stepfather and mother's Louisiana property, where it flipped over upon impact. She was later airlifted to Children's Hospital of New Orleans, where she remained unconscious in a coma for two days. The incident was widely reported, and Spears has since spoken about the traumatic experience.

**Feud with Britney Spears**

In 2021, Jamie Lynn and her sister, Britney, were involved in a highly publicized feud via social media. Britney publicly accused Jamie Lynn of actively and knowingly being involved in her conservatorship, while not making any efforts to help her terminate it. Jamie Lynn denied the allegations and maintained that she was unaware of the details of the conservatorship. Britney threatened legal action against Jamie Lynn after the latter spoke extensively about Britney in both her book and the following promotional tour.

**Filmography**

* Crossroads (2002)
* Zoey 101 (2005-2008)
* The Suite Life of Zack and Cody (2006)
* The Amanda Show (2007)
* I Am Cait (2015)
* Sweet Magnolias (2020)

**Discography**

* "How Could I Want More" (2013)
* "Champagne" (2014)
* "I Want My Good Old Days Back" (2015)

**Extended Plays**

* "Me" (2014)

**Singles**

* "How Could I Want More" (2013)
* "Champagne" (2014)
* "I Want My Good Old Days Back" (2015)

**Other Appearances**

* "The Tonight Show with Jimmy Fallon" (2013)
* "The View" (2014)
* "The Ellen DeGeneres Show" (2015)

**Music Videos**

* "How Could I Want More" (2013)
* "Champagne" (2014)
* "I Want My Good Old Days Back" (2015)

**Awards and Nominations**

* Teen Choice Award for Choice TV Actress: Comedy (2007)
* Teen Choice Award for Choice TV Actress: Comedy (2008)
* People's Choice Award for Favorite Female Artist (2015)

**Published Works**

* "Things I Should Have Said" (2020)

content:
Medalists



Competitors
As the host nation, France entered six athletes [3]


Archery
As the host nation, France entered six athletes [3]


Athletics
As the host nation, track and field athletes from France achieved quota places for the following events based on their results at the 2023 World Championships, 2024 World Championships, or through high performance allocation, as long as they meet the minimum entry standard (MES).


Badminton
As the host nation, France has qualified seven para badminton players for the following events, through the release of BWF para-badminton Race to Paris Paralympic Ranking.


Blind football
The French men's blind football team qualified for the games as hosts [4]


Boccia
As host nation, France directly qualifies three males, three females and one gender-free slots Aurélie Aubert, Aurélien Fabre, Sonia Heckel, Fayçal Meguenni and Jules Menard have all qualified to compete.


Cycling
Mathieu Bosredon, Anne-Sophie Centis, Elie de Carvalho, Dorian Foulon, Joseph Fritsch, Heïdi Gaugain, Florian Jouanny, Alexandre Léauté, Kévin Le Cunff, Gatien Le Rousseau, Alexandre Lloveras, Marie Patouillet, Thomas Peyroton-Dartet, Johan Quaile, Loïc Vergnaud and Anaïs Vincent have all qualified to compete.


Road
Qualification Legend: QB = Final bronze medal; QG = Final gold medal; QF = Final


Track
Qualification Legend: QB = Final bronze medal; QG = Final gold medal; QF = Final


Equestrian
As host nation, France directly qualifies a team of four athletes [6]


Goalball
The French men's team qualified for the games directly using their quota as host [7]


Men's tournament
France men's has qualified to compete by virtue of their top four results at the 2024 IWBF Men's Repechage in Antibes, France.


Women's tournament
France women's sitting volleyball team qualified for the games as host [12]


Judo
As host nation, France directly qualifies seven male and two female judoka.


Paracanoeing
France earned quota places for the following events through the 2023 ICF Canoe Sprint World Championships in Duisburg, Germany; and 2024 ICF Canoe Sprint World Championships in Szeged, Hungary.


Paratriathlon
Alex Adélaïde, Rafik Arabat, Axel Bourlon and Souhad Ghazouani have all qualified to compete.


Powerlifting
Alex Adélaïde, Rafik Arabat, Axel Bourlon and Souhad Ghazouani have all qualified to compete.


Rowing
French rowers qualified boats in each of the following classes at the 2023 World Rowing Championships in Belgrade, Serbia; and 2024 Final Paralympic Qualification Regatta in Lucerne, Switzerland.


Shooting
As host nation, France entered nine para-shooter's after achieved quota places for the following events by virtue of their best finishes at the 2022, 2023 and 2024 world cup, 2022 World Championships, 2023 World Championships, 2023 European Para Championships and 2024 European Championships, as long as they obtained a minimum qualifying score (MQS) by July 15, 2024 [11]


Sitting volleyball
France men's sitting volleyball team qualified for the games as host [12]


Men's tournament
France men's has qualified to compete by virtue of their top four results at the 2024 IWBF Men's Repechage in Antibes, France.


Women's tournament
France women's sitting volleyball team qualified for the games as host [12]


Swimming
As the host nation, France secured fourteen quotas at the 2023 World Para Swimming Championships after finishing in the top two places in Paralympic class disciplines and Paralympic qualification ranking.


Table tennis
As the host nation, France entered nineteen athletes for the Paralympic games All of them qualified through the allocations of the final ITTF world ranking.


Taekwondo
As the host nation, France entered three athletes to compete at the Paralympics competition All of them qualified for Paris 2024, by virtue of finishing within the top six in the Paralympic rankings in their respective class.


Wheelchair basketball
France men's has qualified to compete by virtue of their top four results at the 2024 IWBF Men's Repechage in Antibes, France.


Men's tournament
France men's has qualified to compete by virtue of their top four results at the 2024 IWBF Men's Repechage in Antibes, France.


Wheelchair fencing
Clémence Delavoipiere, Cécile Demaude, Ludovic Lemoine, Yohan Peter, Damien Tokatlian, Maxime Valet and Brianna Vide had all qualified to compete.


Wheelchair rugby
French wheelchair rugby team qualified as host [14]


Wheelchair tennis
Frédéric Cattanéo, Ksénia Chasteau, Pauline Déroulède, Stéphane Houdet, Guilhem Laget, Gaëtan Menguy and Emmanuelle Mörch have all qualified to compete.

**France at the 2024 Summer Paralympics**

The 2024 Summer Paralympics, officially known as the Games of the XVI Paralympic Summer, is a major international multi-sport event for athletes with physical disabilities. The Games will be held in Paris, France, from August 28 to September 8, 2024. As the host nation, France has entered a large number of athletes in various sports, with a strong focus on both track and field and para-sports.

**Medalists**

The medalists for France at the 2024 Summer Paralympics are yet to be determined. However, as the host nation, France is expected to perform well and bring home a significant number of medals.

article:
Brian Austin Green
================

Brian Austin Green is an American actor, born on July 22, 1973, in Van Nuys, California. He is best known for his role as David Silver on the popular television series Beverly Hills, 90210.

Early Life
-----------

Green was born to Joyce and George Green. He has Scottish ancestry through his maternal grandfather. Green's middle name, Austin, was added to differentiate him from another actor when he joined the Screen Actor's Guild as a child.

Career
--------

Prior to his role on Beverly Hills, 90210, Green had a recurring role for three seasons (1986–1989) on the CBS primetime soap opera Knots Landing, playing the role of Brian Cunningham, the son of Abby Cunningham Ewing (Donna Mills). He reprised his role in the television miniseries Knots Landing: Back to the Cul-de-Sac (1997). Green appeared in the 1987 pilot of Good Morning, Miss Bliss as Adam Montcrief.

Green's breakout role came when he joined the cast of Beverly Hills, 90210 in 1990, playing the role of David Silver. He remained on the show for 10 seasons, until its conclusion in 2000. During his time on the show, Green became a household name and gained a large following. He also appeared in several films and television shows, including The Wild Life (1994), Can't Hardy Wait (1995), and Wildflowers (1999).

Personal Life
-------------

Green has been involved in several high-profile relationships throughout his career. He dated his Beverly Hills, 90210 co-star Tiffani Thiessen from 1992 to 1995. In 2004, Green married Megan Fox, but the couple separated in 2015 and divorced in 2021.

In early 2010, Green won the celebrity portion of the Grand Prix of Long Beach. He has also been involved in several business ventures, including a clothing line and a production company.

Philanthropy
------------

Green and his ex-wife Megan Fox are supporters of Generosity Water, an organization that provides clean drinking water to communities in need. They have funded the creation of over ten water wells for the organization.

Paparazzi Lawsuit
-----------------

In March 2012, photographer Delbert Shaw sued Green and his ex-wife Megan Fox in Los Angeles County Superior Court for allegedly assaulting him after he took photographs of the couple while they were vacationing in Hawaii in 2010. Green denied the allegations and stated that he was defending himself against Shaw. Fox was also named in the lawsuit, but Green argued that she should not be included.

Filmography
-------------

### Film

* The Wild Life (1994)
* Can't Hardy Wait (1995)
* Wildflowers (1999)
* The Last Resort (2000)
* X-Men Origins: Wolverine (2009)
* The Hangover Part II (2011)
* The Hangover Part III (2013)

### Television

* Knots Landing (1986–1989)
* Good Morning, Miss Bliss (1987)
* Beverly Hills, 90210 (1990–2000)
* Knots Landing: Back to the Cul-de-Sac (1997)
* Dancing with the Stars (2009)
* Don't Trust the B---- in Apartment 23 (2012)
* Anger Management (2013)

### Music Videos

* "More Than Anything" by 98 Degrees (1997)
* "I'll Be Loving You (Forever)" by New Kids on the Block (1998)

### Other Credits

* Producer, The Last Resort (2000)
* Executive Producer, The Hangover Part II (2011)

Awards and Nominations
-----------------------

* People's Choice Awards, Favorite Television Drama Series (1993, 1994)
* People's Choice Awards, Favorite Actor in a Television Drama Series (1995)
* Teen Choice Awards, Choice Television Actor (1995, 1996)
* Teen Choice Awards, Choice Television Actor (1997, 1998)
* Teen Choice Awards, Choice Television Actor (1999, 2000)

Discography
------------

* "More Than Anything" (1997)
* "I'll Be Loving You (Forever)" (1998)

References
----------

External Links
---------------

title: Next_generation_Light_Anti-tank_Weapon
content:
Etymology
The name "NLAW" initially referred to the original British development programme which Saab won the contract for with the "MBT LAW" [15] [17] [19] NLAW stands for Next-generation Light Anti-tank Weapon or Next-Generation Light Anti-armour Weapon The N is short for "Next generation" [15] or "Next-generation", [2] while LAW is an abbreviation of "Light Anti-tank Weapon" [2] [15] or "Light Anti-Armour Weapon" [8] [20] MBT LAW stands for Main Battle Tank Light Anti-armour Weapon [15] NLAW has since development become the international designation of the weapon, while MBT LAW exists as a designation for the weapon in the British Army [15]


Overview
In 1997, the British Defence Procurement Agency (DPA) began issuing invitations to tender for a new man-portable anti-tank weapon, to replace the obsolescent British LAW 80s [8] Swedish Bofors of the Celsius Group (later bought by Saab AB), [24] American Lockheed Martin, and German Dynamit Nobel replied with offers; due to the limited spots of the NLAW-trials come January 2001, only the two former were rewarded with Project Definition Phase contracts in 1999 Bofors began development of the so-called MBT LAW the same year [16] [25]


Development
Research for a new Swedish light anti-tank guided missile began in the 1990s by the Swedish Armed Forces, for its mechanized infantry which were lacking both tanks and anti-tank warfare weapons Initially, the project focused on creating as simple and cost-effective a system as possible; after some analysis, the need for a man-portable anti-tank weapon with great effectiveness at short to mid-range emerged [23]


Production
As jobs are often the focus of large material orders, a requirement by the British DPA for signing a contract with the winner was that the production of the system would occur in the United Kingdom For this reason, Saab Bofors Dynamics contracted UK-based Thales Air Defence ahead of the NLAW-programme—while Lockheed Martin contracted Matra BAe Dynamics To produce the system, Saab and Thales went on to create Team MBT LAW UK which included 14 subcontractors [25] As per the agreements signed between the United Kingdom and Sweden in 2002–2003, [32] manufacturing occurred mostly in the UK, with final assembly and test done at the Thales Air Defence facilities in Belfast, Northern Ireland [16] [26] The weapon went into full production in 2008 The final cost for the MBT LAW contract since the beginning of the NLAW-programme, including the assessment phase, development, and manufacture-license, ended up at approximately £400–437 million [16] [19]


Operation
The NLAW is a man-portable, soft-launch, and confined-spaces (saltwater countermass) system, [32] allowing the missile to be fired from almost anywhere; the operator can safely fire through any window of a room no bigger than 4 x 2.5 x 2.5 m (high) [8] The missile is first shot out of the launcher with a low-powered ignition system, after which its main rocket ignites and propels it to the target Guidance uses a predicted line of sight (PLOS) system For a moving target, the operator maintains tracking for at least 2–3 seconds The software embedded in the missile's INS records the operator's aiming movement and extrapolates the flight path needed to intercept the target After launch, the missile flies autonomously along the pre-programmed flight path, controlled by an inertial guidance system [4] [32] [35] The system weighs 12.5 kg (28 lb), with a rocket weight of 6.5 kg (14 lb); the mass of the warhead is 1.8 kg (4.0 lb) [18] It is unnecessary for the operator to consider the target distance (so long as it is within range), or to stay exposed whilst the missile is in the air (fire-and-forget) [36]


Combat history
Preceding the escalation of the Russo-Ukrainian War by the 2022 Russian invasion of Ukraine, the United Kingdom supplied 2,000 NLAW systems to Ukraine, with another 1,615 delivered by 9 March 2022 [40] [41] to bolster Ukraine's military [6] More NLAWs were requested by the Ukrainian military following reports that they proved highly effective against Russian vehicles, leading to at least 100 more being allocated by Luxembourg [42] [43] Alongside US FGM-148 Javelin anti-tank missile systems, delivered as a precaution against increased hostilities, the Ukrainian forces reported that NLAWs produced far greater damage against Russian armoured vehicles than their standard Soviet-era equipment [12] On 24 March 2022, the UK pledged to deliver a further 6,000 NLAWs and a senior Ukrainian military officer also claimed they were the "weapon of choice" for his troops, responsible for 30–40% of Russian tanks destroyed [44]


Russo-Ukrainian War
Preceding the escalation of the Russo-Ukrainian War by the 2022 Russian invasion of Ukraine, the United Kingdom supplied 2,000 NLAW systems to Ukraine, with another 1,615 delivered by 9 March 2022 [40] [41] to bolster Ukraine's military [6] More NLAWs were requested by the Ukrainian military following reports that they proved highly effective against Russian vehicles, leading to at least 100 more being allocated by Luxembourg [42] [43] Alongside US FGM-148 Javelin anti-tank missile systems, delivered as a precaution against increased hostilities, the Ukrainian forces reported that NLAWs produced far greater damage against Russian armoured vehicles than their standard Soviet-era equipment [12] On 24 March 2022, the UK pledged to deliver a further 6,000 NLAWs and a senior Ukrainian military officer also claimed they were the "weapon of choice" for his troops, responsible for 30–40% of Russian tanks destroyed [44]


Operators
Finland announced missile orders in 2007 worth €38 million [9] [50] In Finnish service the missile is designated 102 mm raskas lähipanssarintorjuntaohjus NLAW (102 RSLPSTOHJ NLAW) for Finnish speaking troops, [51] [52] and 102 mm tung närpansarvärnsrobot NLAW (meaning roughly "102 mm heavy close-in anti-armour missile")  for Fenno-Swedish speaking troops [53]


Current operators
Finland announced missile orders in 2007 worth €38 million [9] [50] In Finnish service the missile is designated 102 mm raskas lähipanssarintorjuntaohjus NLAW (102 RSLPSTOHJ NLAW) for Finnish speaking troops, [51] [52] and 102 mm tung närpansarvärnsrobot NLAW (meaning roughly "102 mm heavy close-in anti-armour missile")  for Fenno-Swedish speaking troops [53]


Finland (3,000 + additional in 2023)
Finland announced missile orders in 2007 worth €38 million [9] [50] In Finnish service the missile is designated 102 mm raskas lähipanssarintorjuntaohjus NLAW (102 RSLPSTOHJ NLAW) for Finnish speaking troops, [51] [52] and 102 mm tung närpansarvärnsrobot NLAW (meaning roughly "102 mm heavy close-in anti-armour missile")  for Fenno-Swedish speaking troops [53]


Indonesia (600)
600 units delivered in 2012–2013 [14]


Malaysia (500)
500 units ordered in 2016 or 2017, and delivered in 2018–2020 [13] [29]


Sweden (5,000)
2,000 units ordered in 2005, and delivered in 2009–2012 [13] Another 3,000 units order was placed in December 2022 at a cost of 900M SEK for delivery in 2024-2026 [57] In Swedish service the missile is designated robot 57 (RB 57), [58] [5] or pansarvärnsrobot 57 (pvrb 57) in expanded form, [22] meaning "missile 57" and "anti-armour missile 57" respectively (the 5 indicates its missile class and the 7 indicates its consecutive number in that class = 7th missile of the 5th class) [citation needed]


Switzerland (4,000)
4,000 units in 2017 to fill capability gap left by M47 Dragon decommissioning in 2008, [30] and delivered in from 2018 [13]


Ukraine (>5,000 donated)
2,000 NLAW units were supplied to Ukraine by the United Kingdom by 19 January 2022 in anticipation of the Russian invasion of Ukraine [6] [36] Another 100 were sent from Luxembourg following the invasion [43] As of 9 March 2022, the UK confirmed that it had delivered a total of 3,615 NLAW to Ukraine [40] As of 16 March 2022, the UK confirmed that it had delivered more than 4,000 NLAWs to Ukraine [31] As of 15 May 2023, the UK delivered more than 5,000 NLAWs to Ukraine [59] In Ukrainian service the missile is designated Protytankovyy raketnyy kompleks NLAW (Протитанковий ракетний комплекс NLAW), or PTRK NLAW (ПТРК NLAW) for short, meaning "Anti-Tank Missile System NLAW" [60]


United Kingdom (21,000 total order)
Selected in May 2002 for the British Army Next-generation Light Anti-tank Weapon (NLAW) requirement The system has replaced the ILAW and LAW 80 [8] In British service the missile is formally designated Round, Guided Missile, NLAW (Next-generation Light Anti-tank Weapon), High-Explosive Anti-Tank, K170A1 or K170A2 (GM NLAW HEAT K170A1/A2) depending on the variant (A1 = Mk1, A2 = Mk2), [61] [62] [63] [64] but the project name "Main Battle Tank Light Anti-Armour Weapon" (MBT-LAW) also appears [15] [19] The UK donated thousands of NLAWs out of its own stocks to Ukraine, which it plans to replace from January 2023 onwards, followed by "a larger subsequent order" [65]


Future operators
Unknown quantity planned to be ordered as of June 2024, to be used as the intermediate solution between the AT4 and the Akeron MP ATGM  [67]


France
Unknown quantity planned to be ordered as of June 2024, to be used as the intermediate solution between the AT4 and the Akeron MP ATGM  [67]


Former operators
100 units ordered in 2010 (50) and 2015 (50), and delivered in 2012 and 2016–2017 (All 102 donated to Ukraine war)  [13] [28]


Luxembourg (100)
100 units ordered in 2010 (50) and 2015 (50), and delivered in 2012 and 2016–2017 (All 102 donated to Ukraine war)  [13] [28]


See also


References


External links
article:
**Next-generation Light Anti-tank Weapon**

The Next-generation Light Anti-tank Weapon, commonly referred to as NLAW, is a man-portable, soft-launch, and confined-spaces (saltwater countermass) system designed to provide a lightweight and effective anti-tank capability for military forces. Developed by Saab Bofors Dynamics in collaboration with Thales Air Defence, the NLAW has become a widely used and highly regarded anti-tank missile system in various countries.

**Overview**

The NLAW was developed in response to the British Defence Procurement Agency's (DPA) requirement for a new man-portable anti-tank weapon to replace the obsolescent LAW 80s. The project, initially referred to as the Main Battle Tank Light Anti-armour Weapon (MBT LAW), was awarded to Saab Bofors Dynamics in 1999. The NLAW was designed to be a simple and cost-effective system, capable of engaging targets at short to mid-range distances.

**Development**

Research for the NLAW began in the 1990s by the Swedish Armed Forces, which was lacking both tanks and anti-tank warfare weapons. The initial focus was on creating a simple and cost-effective system, but after analysis, the need for a man-portable anti-tank weapon with great effectiveness at short to mid-range emerged. The NLAW was designed to be a fire-and-forget system, allowing the operator to safely fire through any window of a room no bigger than 4 x 2.5 x 2.5 meters.

**Production**

Production of the NLAW began in 2008, with the system going into full production in the same year. The final cost for the MBT LAW contract, including the assessment phase, development, and manufacture-license, ended up at approximately £400-437 million. Manufacturing occurred mostly in the UK, with final assembly and test done at the Thales Air Defence facilities in Belfast, Northern Ireland.

**Operation**

The NLAW is a man-portable system, weighing 12.5 kg, with a rocket weight of 6.5 kg and a warhead mass of 1.8 kg. The missile is first shot out of the launcher with a low-powered ignition system, after which its main rocket ignites and propels it to the target. Guidance uses a predicted line of sight (PLOS) system, allowing the operator to maintain tracking for at least 2-3 seconds. The software embedded in the missile's INS records the operator's aiming movement and extrapolates the flight path needed to intercept the target.

**Combat History**

The NLAW has seen extensive use in various conflicts, including the Russo-Ukrainian War. Prior to the escalation of the conflict, the United Kingdom supplied 2,000 NLAW systems to Ukraine, with another 1,615 delivered by 9 March 2022. The Ukrainian forces reported that NLAWs produced far greater damage against Russian armoured vehicles than their standard Soviet-era equipment. On 24 March 2022, the UK pledged to deliver a further 6,000 NLAWs, and a senior Ukrainian military officer claimed they were the "weapon of choice" for his troops, responsible for 30-40% of Russian tanks destroyed.

**Operators**

Finland announced missile orders in 2007 worth €38 million, with the missile designated 102 mm raskas lähipanssarintorjuntaohjus NLAW (102 RSLPSTOHJ NLAW) for Finnish speaking troops and 102 mm tung närpansarvärnsrobot NLAW (meaning roughly "102 mm heavy close-in anti-armour missile") for Fenno-Swedish speaking troops. Indonesia received 600 units in 2012-2013, while Malaysia ordered 500 units in 2016 or 2017, and delivered in 2018-2020. Sweden received 2,000 units in 2009-2012, with another 3,000 units ordered in December 2022 at a cost of 900M SEK for delivery in 2024-2026. Switzerland received 4,000 units in 2017 to fill capability gap left by M47 Dragon decommissioning in 2008, and delivered in from 2018. Ukraine received over 5,000 units donated by the UK, with the missile designated Protytankovyy raketnyy kompleks NLAW (Протитанковий ракетний комплекс NLAW), or PTRK NLAW (ПТРК NLAW) for short, meaning "Anti-Tank Missile System NLAW". The United Kingdom has ordered a total of 21,000 units, with the system replacing the ILAW and LAW 80.

**Future Operators**

Unknown quantity planned to be ordered as of June 2024, to be used as the intermediate solution between the AT4 and the Akeron MP ATGM. France is also planning to order an unknown quantity of NLAW systems.
prompt:
Write a complete Wikipedia-style article in English about "Next_generation_Light_Anti-tank_Weapon" following this outline:


Etymology
The name "NLAW" initially referred to the original British development programme which Saab won the contract for with the "MBT LAW" [15] [17] [19] NLAW stands for Next-generation Light Anti-tank Weapon or Next-Generation Light Anti-armour Weapon The N is short for "Next generation" [15] or "Next-generation", [2] while LAW is an abbreviation of "Light Anti-tank Weapon" [2] [15] or "Light Anti-Armour Weapon" [8] [20] MBT LAW stands for Main Battle Tank Light Anti-armour Weapon [15] NLAW has since development become the international designation of the weapon, while MBT LAW exists as a designation for the weapon in the British Army [15]


Overview
In 1997, the British Defence Procurement Agency (DPA) began issuing invitations to tender for a new man-portable anti-tank weapon, to replace the obsolescent British LAW 80s [8] Swedish Bofors of the Celsius Group (later bought by Saab AB), [24] American Lockheed Martin, and German Dynamit Nobel replied with offers; due to the limited spots of the NLAW-trials come January 2001, only the two former were rewarded with Project Definition Phase contracts in 1999 Bofors began development of the so-called MBT LAW the same year [16] [25]


Development
Research for a new Swedish light anti-tank guided missile began in the 1990s by the Swedish Armed Forces, for its mechanized infantry which were lacking both tanks and anti-tank warfare weapons Initially, the project focused on creating as simple and cost-effective a system as possible; after some analysis, the need for a man-portable anti-tank weapon with great effectiveness at short to mid-range emerged [23]


Production
As jobs are often the focus of large material orders, a requirement by the British DPA for signing a contract with the winner was that the production of the system would occur in the United Kingdom For this reason, Saab Bofors Dynamics contracted UK-based Thales Air Defence ahead of the NLAW-programme—while Lockheed Martin contracted Matra BAe Dynamics To produce the system, Saab and Thales went on to create Team MBT LAW UK which included 14 subcontractors [25] As per the agreements signed between the United Kingdom and Sweden in 2002–2003, [32] manufacturing occurred mostly in the UK, with final assembly and test done at the Thales Air Defence facilities in Belfast, Northern Ireland [16] [26] The weapon went into full production in 2008 The final cost for the MBT LAW contract since the beginning of the NLAW-programme, including the assessment phase, development, and manufacture-license, ended up at approximately £400–437 million [16] [19]


Operation
The NLAW is a man-portable, soft-launch, and confined-spaces (saltwater countermass) system, [32] allowing the missile to be fired from almost anywhere; the operator can safely fire through any window of a room no bigger than 4 x 2.5 x 2.5 m (high) [8] The missile is first shot out of the launcher with a low-powered ignition system, after which its main rocket ignites and propels it to the target Guidance uses a predicted line of sight (PLOS) system For a moving target, the operator maintains tracking for at least 2–3 seconds The software embedded in the missile's INS records the operator's aiming movement and extrapolates the flight path needed to intercept the target After launch, the missile flies autonomously along the pre-programmed flight path, controlled by an inertial guidance system [4] [32] [35] The system weighs 12.5 kg (28 lb), with a rocket weight of 6.5 kg (14 lb); the mass of the warhead is 1.8 kg (4.0 lb) [18] It is unnecessary for the operator to consider the target distance (so long as it is within range), or to stay exposed whilst the missile is in the air (fire-and-forget) [36]


Combat history
Preceding the escalation of the Russo-Ukrainian War by the 2022 Russian invasion of Ukraine, the United Kingdom supplied 2,000 NLAW systems to Ukraine, with another 1,615 delivered by 9 March 2022 [40] [41] to bolster Ukraine's military [6] More NLAWs were requested by the Ukrainian military following reports that they proved highly effective against Russian vehicles, leading to at least 100 more being allocated by Luxembourg [42] [43] Alongside US FGM-148 Javelin anti-tank missile systems, delivered as a precaution against increased hostilities, the Ukrainian forces reported that NLAWs produced far greater damage against Russian armoured vehicles than their standard Soviet-era equipment [12] On 24 March 2022, the UK pledged to deliver a further 6,000 NLAWs and a senior Ukrainian military officer also claimed they were the "weapon of choice" for his troops, responsible for 30–40% of Russian tanks destroyed [44]

Operators

Current operators

2,000 units ordered in 2005, and delivered in 2009–2012 [13] Another 3,000 units order was placed in December 2022 at a cost of 900M SEK for delivery in 2024-2026 [57] In Swedish service the missile is designated robot 57 (RB 57), [58] [5] or pansarvärnsrobot 57 (pvrb 57) in expanded form, [22] meaning "missile 57" and "anti-armour missile 57" respectively (the 5 indicates its missile class and the 7 indicates its consecutive number in that class = 7th missile of the 5th class) [citation needed]

title: Terrifier
content:
Plot
A facially disfigured woman is interviewed for a TV news segment Once off air, the news anchor, Monica Brown, makes cruel comments to her boyfriend about the woman's appearance, only for the woman to burst out of hiding and mutilate her [a]


Cast
The character of Art the Clown first appeared as a supporting character in the 2008 short film The 9th Circle, which Leone wrote and directed [10] Leone later wrote and directed a short film titled Terrifier, which featured Art as the main antagonist and was released in 2011 [11] These shorts were incorporated into the 2013 anthology film All Hallows' Eve, [12] which marked both Art's first feature film appearance and Leone's feature directorial debut [13]


Production
The character of Art the Clown first appeared as a supporting character in the 2008 short film The 9th Circle, which Leone wrote and directed [10] Leone later wrote and directed a short film titled Terrifier, which featured Art as the main antagonist and was released in 2011 [11] These shorts were incorporated into the 2013 anthology film All Hallows' Eve, [12] which marked both Art's first feature film appearance and Leone's feature directorial debut [13]


Release
Terrifier premiered at the Telluride Horror Show on October 15, 2016 [19] It was later screened at the Horror Channel FrightFest on October 28, 2017, [20] and was subsequently picked up by Epic Pictures Releasing for a limited theatrical release on March 15 and March 16, 2018 [21] In April 2023, it was announced that Terrifier would be released theatrically in 700 theaters on July 19, 2023 [22] [23]


Home media
Terrifier was released on DVD and Blu-ray on March 27, 2018 The release features audio commentary from Damien Leone and David H Thornton, behind-the-scenes footage, an interview with star Jenna Kanell, deleted scenes, collectible reversible cover art, and several other bonus features [24] The film was released on VHS on March 29, 2019, by Witter Entertainment [25]


Reception
Terrifier grossed a total of $421,798 [5] [6] Terrifier & Terrifier 2 - Double Bill was released in the United Kingdom on September 27, 2024, and grossed $122,174 [26]


Box office
Terrifier grossed a total of $421,798 [5] [6] Terrifier & Terrifier 2 - Double Bill was released in the United Kingdom on September 27, 2024, and grossed $122,174 [26]


Critical response
On the review aggregator website Rotten Tomatoes, 62% of 26 critics' reviews are positive, with an average rating of 5.9/10 The website's consensus reads: "All about the splashy kills, Terrifier artfully introduces the unpredictable massacrer mime Art, yet fails to carve an entertaining story worthy of his wrath." [27]


Accolades
The film received three Fangoria Chainsaw Award nominations: Best Limited Release, Best Supporting Actor (Thornton), and Best Makeup FX (Leone) [35] [36]


Comic book
Between 2021 and 2022, a self-published two-issue limited comic book series adaptation of Terrifier was released by Damien Leone with illustrations by Steve McGinnis [37] [38] [39]


Sequels
In February 2019, Damien Leone stated that a sequel for Terrifier was in production, with the other sequel's script having already been written The film went into production in October 2019 with Fuzz on the Lens Productions as co-producers along with Dark Age Cinema [40] The film was initially delayed during production of its final days of shooting due to the COVID-19 pandemic, but finally resumed in September 2020 and wrapped shooting in 2021.
The film debuted at the Arrow Video FrightFest in London, England on August 29, 2022, before receiving a nationwide US cinema release on October 6, 2022, and was released to streaming platforms on November 11, 2022.


Notes


References


External links
article:
**Terrifier**

Terrifier is a 2018 American slasher film written and directed by Damien Leone. The film premiered at the Telluride Horror Show on October 15, 2016, and was later released in the United States on March 15 and 16, 2018, by Epic Pictures Releasing.

**Plot**

The film takes place on Halloween night and revolves around the character of Art the Clown, a masked killer who terrorizes a small town. The story begins with a news segment featuring a facially disfigured woman, who is interviewed by a local news anchor, Monica Brown. Once the cameras are off, Monica makes cruel comments about the woman's appearance, only to be confronted by the woman herself, who has been lurking in the shadows. The woman mutilates Monica, setting the tone for the rest of the film.

The story then shifts to a group of friends who are planning to attend a party on Halloween night. As they make their way through the town, they are stalked and killed by Art the Clown, who is determined to wreak havoc on the town.

Throughout the film, Art is portrayed as a silent, masked killer who uses his agility and cunning to outsmart his victims. The film's plot is driven by a series of graphic and gruesome killings, which are interspersed with scenes of the characters' mundane lives.

**Cast**

The film features a talented cast of actors, including David H. Thornton, Jenna Kanell, and Samantha Scaffidi. Art the Clown is played by Damien Leone himself, who also wrote and directed the film.

**Production**

Terrifier is the second film in Leone's series of shorts featuring Art the Clown. The first short film, The 9th Circle, was released in 2008 and featured Art as a supporting character. Leone later wrote and directed a second short film, Terrifier, which was released in 2011 and featured Art as the main antagonist.

The film was shot on a low budget and took advantage of Leone's experience working on short films. The film's production company, Fuzz on the Lens Productions, worked closely with Leone to bring the film to life.

**Release**

Terrifier premiered at the Telluride Horror Show on October 15, 2016, and was later screened at the Horror Channel FrightFest on October 28, 2017. The film was released in the United States on March 15 and 16, 2018, by Epic Pictures Releasing.

In April 2023, it was announced that Terrifier would be released theatrically in 700 theaters on July 19, 2023. The film was also released on DVD and Blu-ray on March 27, 2018, and features audio commentary from Damien Leone and David H. Thornton, behind-the-scenes footage, an interview with star Jenna Kanell, deleted scenes, collectible reversible cover art, and several other bonus features.

**Home Media**

Terrifier was released on DVD and Blu-ray on March 27, 2018. The release features audio commentary from Damien Leone and David H. Thornton, behind-the-scenes footage, an interview with star Jenna Kanell, deleted scenes, collectible reversible cover art, and several other bonus features.

The film was also released on VHS on March 29, 2019, by Witter Entertainment. The VHS release includes all of the bonus features from the DVD and Blu-ray release, as well as a collectible VHS cover art.

**Reception**

Terrifier received mixed reviews from critics, but has since become a cult classic. The film has a 62% approval rating on Rotten Tomatoes, with an average rating of 5.9/10.

On Metacritic, the film has a score of 56 out of 100, based on 6 reviews, indicating "mixed or average" reviews.

**Box Office**

Terrifier grossed a total of $421,798 at the box office. The film was released in the United Kingdom on September 27, 2024, and grossed $122,174.

**Accolades**

The film received three Fangoria Chainsaw Award nominations: Best Limited Release, Best Supporting Actor (Thornton), and Best Makeup FX (Leone).

**Comic Book**

Between 2021 and 2022, a self-published two-issue limited comic book series adaptation of Terrifier was released by Damien Leone with illustrations by Steve McGinnis.

**Sequels**

In February 2019, Damien Leone stated that a sequel for Terrifier was in production, with the other sequel's script having already been written. The film went into production in October 2019 with Fuzz on the Lens Productions as co-producers along with Dark Age Cinema.

The film was initially delayed during production of its final days of shooting due to the COVID-19 pandemic, but finally resumed in September 2020 and wrapped shooting in 2021.

The film debuted at the Arrow Video FrightFest in London, England on August 29, 2022, before receiving a nationwide US cinema release on October 6, 2022, and was released to streaming platforms on November 11, 2022.

**Notes**

Terrifier has become a cult classic among horror fans, known for its graphic and gruesome killings, as well as its memorable villain, Art the Clown. The film's success has led to a series of sequels and adaptations, including a comic book series and a second film.

The film's director, Damien Leone, has stated that he is a fan of the horror genre and was inspired by classic horror films such as The Texas Chain Saw Massacre and A Nightmare on Elm Street.

Terrifier has also been praised for its social commentary, which explores themes of bullying and the treatment of marginalized groups. The film's portrayal of Art the Clown as a symbol of the consequences of bullying has resonated with many viewers.

Overall, Terrifier is a unique and unsettling horror film that has become a cult classic among horror fans. Its graphic and gruesome killings, memorable villain, and social commentary have made it a standout in the horror genre.
