title: Downton_Abbey
content:
Plot overview
The first series, comprising seven episodes, explores the lives of the fictional Crawley family, the hereditary Earl of Grantham, and their domestic servants The storyline centres on the fee tail, or "entail", governing the titled elite, which endows title and estate exclusively to male heirs As part of the backstory, the main character, Robert Crawley, Earl of Grantham, had resolved his father's past financial difficulties by marrying Cora Levinson, an American heiress Her considerable dowry is now contractually incorporated into the committal entail in perpetuity; however, Robert and Cora have three daughters and no son.


Series 1 (2010)
The first series, comprising seven episodes, explores the lives of the fictional Crawley family, the hereditary Earl of Grantham, and their domestic servants The storyline centres on the fee tail, or "entail", governing the titled elite, which endows title and estate exclusively to male heirs As part of the backstory, the main character, Robert Crawley, Earl of Grantham, had resolved his father's past financial difficulties by marrying Cora Levinson, an American heiress Her considerable dowry is now contractually incorporated into the committal entail in perpetuity; however, Robert and Cora have three daughters and no son.


Series 2 (2011)
The second series comprises eight episodes and runs from the Battle of the Somme in 1916 to the 1918 Spanish flu pandemic During the war, Downton Abbey is temporarily converted into an officers' convalescent hospital.


Series 3 (2012)
In episode one of the third series, covering 1920 to 1921, preparations are underway for Mary and Matthew's wedding Tom and Sybil Branson arrive from Ireland, where they now live, to attend the wedding Also arriving to attend the wedding of her granddaughter is Cora's mother, Martha Levinson, from America Robert (Lord Grantham) learns that the bulk of the family's fortune (including Cora's dowry) has been lost due to his impetuous investment in the Grand Trunk Railway Meanwhile Edith has fallen for Sir Anthony Strallan, whom Robert discourages from marrying Edith due to his age and crippled arm At Edith's insistence, Robert gives in and welcomes Sir Anthony, but even though he loves her, Strallan cannot accept that the Grantham family disapproves of the match, and at the altar announces that he cannot go through with the wedding, devastating Edith Strallan flees the church and is never heard from again.


Series 4 (2013)
In series four, covering 1922 to 1923, O'Brien leaves to serve Lady Flintshire in British India Cora hires Edna Braithwaite, who had previously been fired for her interest in Tom Eventually the situation blows up, and Edna is replaced by Phyllis Baxter.


Series 5 (2014)
In series five, covering the year 1924, a Russian exile, Prince Kuragin, wishes to renew his past affections for the Dowager Countess (Violet) Violet instead locates his wife in British Hong Kong and reunites the Prince and his estranged wife Scotland Yard and the local police investigate Green's death Violet learns that Marigold is Edith's daughter Meanwhile, Mrs Drewe, not knowing Marigold's true parentage, resents Edith's constant visits To increase his chances with Mary, Charles Blake plots to reunite Gillingham and his ex-fiancée, Mabel After Edith inherits Michael Gregson's publishing company, she removes Marigold from the Drewes and relocates to London Simon Bricker, an art expert interested in one of Downton's paintings, shows his true intentions toward Cora and is thrown out by Robert, causing a temporary rift between the couple.


Series 6 (2015)
In series six, changes are once again afoot at Downton Abbey as the middle class rises and more bankrupted aristocrats are forced to sell off their large estates Downton must do more to ensure its future survival; reductions in staff are considered, forcing Barrow to look for a job elsewhere Having formed a close bond with young George, Barrow realises that Downton has become the first real home he has ever had, but feels unwanted Mary defies a blackmailer, who is thwarted by Robert With Tom's departure to Boston, Mary becomes the estate agent Edith is more hands-on in running her magazine and hires a female editor Violet and Isobel once again draw battle lines as a government take-over of the local hospital is considered Mary begins seeing Henry Talbot, a racing driver, and Edith begins seeing Bertie Pelham, a cousin of the owner of Brancaster Castle.


Cast and characters
The main cast of the Crawley family is led by Hugh Bonneville as Robert Crawley, the Earl of Grantham, and Elizabeth McGovern as his wife Cora Crawley, the Countess of Grantham Their three daughters are depicted by Michelle Dockery as Lady Mary Crawley (Talbot), Laura Carmichael as Lady Edith Crawley (Pelham) and Jessica Brown Findlay as Lady Sybil Crawley (Branson) Maggie Smith is Robert Crawley's mother Violet, Dowager Countess of Grantham Samantha Bond portrays Lady Rosamund Painswick, Robert's sister who resides in Belgrave Square, London Dan Stevens portrays Matthew Crawley, the new heir, along with Penelope Wilton as his mother, Isobel Crawley, who are brought to Downton Allen Leech as Tom Branson begins the series as the family chauffeur, but falls in love with Lady Sybil, marries her and later becomes the agent for the estate David Robb portrays Dr Richard Clarkson, the local town doctor.


Crawley family
The series is set in Downton Abbey, a Yorkshire country house, which is the home and seat of the Earl and Countess of Grantham, along with their three daughters and other family members Each series follows the lives of the aristocratic Crawley family, their friends, and their servants during the reign of King George V.


Production
Gareth Neame of Carnival Films conceived the idea of an Edwardian-era TV drama set in a country house and approached Fellowes, who had won an Academy Award for Best Writing (Original Screenplay) for Gosford Park The TV series Downton Abbey – written and created by Fellowes – was originally planned as a spin-off of Gosford Park, but instead was developed as a stand-alone property inspired by the film, set decades earlier [8] Although Fellowes was reluctant to work on another project resembling Gosford Park, within a few weeks he returned to Neame with an outline of the first series Influenced by Edith Wharton's The Custom of the Country, [9] Fellowes wrote the scripts; and his wife, Emma, acted as an informal story editor [10]


Filming locations
Highclere Castle in north Hampshire is used for exterior shots of Downton Abbey and most of the interior filming [11] [12] [13] [14] The kitchen, servants' quarters and working areas, and some of the "upstairs" bedrooms were constructed and filmed at Ealing Studios [15] Bridgewater House in the St James area of London served as the family's London home.


Opening theme music
The opening music of Downton Abbey, titled "Did I Make the Most of Loving You?", [41] was composed by John Lunn [42]


Broadcasts
The rights to broadcast Downton Abbey have been acquired in over 220 countries and territories, and the series has been viewed by a global audience of an estimated 120 million people [45]


United Kingdom
The series first aired on the ITV network in the United Kingdom beginning on 26 September 2010, and received its first Britain-wide broadcast when shown on ITV3 beginning in February 2011.


United States
In the United States, Downton Abbey was first broadcast in January 2011 on PBS, as part of the 40th season of Masterpiece [50] The programme was aired in four 90-minute episodes, controversially requiring PBS to alter the beginning and endpoints of each episode and make other small changes, slightly altering each episode's structure to fit the programme precisely into the allotted running-time [51] [a] [b] As part of Masterpiece, episodes shown on PBS also featured Masterpiece host (Laura Linney), who introduced each episode, explaining matters such as "the entail" and "Buccaneers" [c] for the benefit of American viewers; this was perceived as condescending by some American critics [51] PBS editing for broadcasts in the United States continued in the subsequent seasons [52] The final and sixth season aired in 2016 PBS continued to repeat episodes until 2020, when NBC Universal took over the US broadcasting rights for its streaming service Peacock The series became available on Netflix in 2021 The series also aired on the E! network in 2022.


Canada
In Canada, VisionTV began airing the programme on 7 September 2011; CBC Television repeated the whole series in 2021; Downton Abbey was aired in French on Ici Radio-Canada Télé [53]


Australia and New Zealand
In Australia, the first series was broadcast on the Seven Network beginning on 29 May 2011; [54] the second series was broadcast beginning on 20 May 2012; [55] and the third series beginning on 10 February 2013 [56] In New Zealand, Prime began airing the first series on 10 May 2011, the second series on 18 October 2011 and the third series on 18 October 2012 [57]


Ireland
In Ireland, independent television channel TV3 aired the first series in January and February 2011 [58]


France
Downton Abbey was broadcast on TMC in France beginning in 11 December 2011 [59]


Reception
At Metacritic, which assigns a rating out of 100 to reviews from mainstream critics, the first series received an average score of 91, based on 16 reviews, which indicates "universal acclaim" [66] This result earned the show a Guinness World Record in 2011 for "Highest critical review ratings for a TV show", making Downton Abbey the critically best received TV show in the world [67] Season 4 of Breaking Bad surpassed Downton Abbey's record later in the year, with a score of 96, making the first series of Downton Abbey the second highest rated show of 2011 [68]


Critical response
At Metacritic, which assigns a rating out of 100 to reviews from mainstream critics, the first series received an average score of 91, based on 16 reviews, which indicates "universal acclaim" [66] This result earned the show a Guinness World Record in 2011 for "Highest critical review ratings for a TV show", making Downton Abbey the critically best received TV show in the world [67] Season 4 of Breaking Bad surpassed Downton Abbey's record later in the year, with a score of 96, making the first series of Downton Abbey the second highest rated show of 2011 [68]


Ratings
The first episode of Downton Abbey had a consolidated British audience of 9.2 million viewers, a 32% audience share—making it the most successful new drama on any channel since Whitechapel was launched on ITV in February 2009 The total audience for the first episode, including repeats and ITV Player viewings, exceeded 11.6 million viewers This was beaten by the next episode, with a total audience of 11.8 million viewers—including repeats and ITV Player views Downton Abbey broke the record for a single episode viewing on ITV Player [88]


Awards and nominations
Although Julian Fellowes supports a united Ireland, [99] there has been criticism of the stereotypical Irish characters used in the show, specifically the character of Tom Branson's brother, Kieran, portrayed as a rude and boorish drunk [100] Allen Leech, who plays Tom Branson, defended the series, stating that the show did not portray Irish characters in a pejorative fashion [100] Branson's character took some criticism in Ireland from The Irish Times, which described the character as "an Irish republican turned Downtonian toff." [101]


Cultural reaction
Although Julian Fellowes supports a united Ireland, [99] there has been criticism of the stereotypical Irish characters used in the show, specifically the character of Tom Branson's brother, Kieran, portrayed as a rude and boorish drunk [100] Allen Leech, who plays Tom Branson, defended the series, stating that the show did not portray Irish characters in a pejorative fashion [100] Branson's character took some criticism in Ireland from The Irish Times, which described the character as "an Irish republican turned Downtonian toff." [101]


Authenticity
Fellowes has said he tries to be as authentic in his depiction of the period as he can [10] Despite this, the show features many linguistic anachronisms [104] The accents of characters have also been questioned, with the Received Pronunciation of the actors who play the wealthy characters described as "slightly more contemporary" than would be expected among early-20th-century aristocrats; however, this "elicited more natural and unaffected performances from the cast" [105]


Home media
The series was made available in its entirety on Netflix in June 2021 It has also been made available on Amazon Prime Video, Peacock, the PBS app and PBS.org with a PBS Passport subscription [113] [114]


Streaming
The series was made available in its entirety on Netflix in June 2021 It has also been made available on Amazon Prime Video, Peacock, the PBS app and PBS.org with a PBS Passport subscription [113] [114]


Blu-ray and DVD
On 16 September 2011, two days before the UK premiere of the second series, it was reported by Amazon.com that the first series of Downton Abbey had become the highest selling DVD boxset of all time on the online retailer's website, surpassing popular American programmes such as The Sopranos, Friends and The Wire [115]


Books
The World of Downton Abbey, a book featuring a behind-the-scenes look at Downton Abbey and the era in which it is set, was released on 15 September 2011 It was written by Jessica Fellowes (the niece of Julian Fellowes) and published by HarperCollins [116] [117]


Soundtracks
A soundtrack, featuring music from the series and also new songs, was released by Decca in September 2011 Music by John Lunn and Don Black features, with vocals from Mary-Jess Leaverland and Alfie Boe [116] A second soundtrack was released on 19 November 2012 entitled Downton Abbey: The Essential Collection [119] and a third and final soundtrack, containing two discs, was released on 15 January 2016 entitled Downton Abbey: The Ultimate Collection and featured music spanning from all six seasons of the series including some from the first soundtrack [120]


Cultural impact
Some of the fashion items worn by characters on the show have seen a strong revival of interest in the UK and elsewhere during the show's run, including starched collars, midi skirts, beaded gowns, and hunting plaids [121]


Other media
Due to the show's popularity, there have been a number of references and spoofs on it, such as Family Guy episode "Chap Stewie", which has Stewie Griffin reborn in a household similar to Downton Abbey, and How I Met Your Mother episode "The Fortress", where the gang watch a television show called Woodworthy Manor, which is remarkably similar to Downton Abbey [128]


The Gilded Age
Julian Fellowes's The Gilded Age, which debuted on HBO in 2022, portrays New York in the 1880s and how its old New York society coped with the influx of newly wealthy families [129] [130] While a separate series, a young Cora, Countess of Grantham, could [when?] make an appearance on the new show [131]


Film adaptations
On 13 July 2018, a feature-length film was confirmed, with production commencing mid-2018 [132] The film was written by Julian Fellowes and is a continuation of the TV series, with direction by Brian Percival It was distributed by Focus Features and Universal Pictures International [133] The film was released in the United Kingdom on 13 September 2019, with the United States following one week later on 20 September 2019 [134] Filming of a sequel began in April 2021 [135] The film was finally released in the UK on 29 April 2022, and in the US on 20 May [136]


See also


Notes


References


Further reading


External links
article:
Downton Abbey

Introduction

Downton Abbey is a British period drama television series created by Julian Fellowes. The show is set in the fictional Downton Abbey, a Yorkshire country house, and follows the lives of the aristocratic Crawley family and their servants from the early 20th century to the 1920s. The series has gained widespread critical acclaim and has been praised for its portrayal of the social class system, relationships, and historical events during that era.

Plot Overview

The first series, comprising seven episodes, explores the lives of the fictional Crawley family, the hereditary Earl of Grantham, and their domestic servants. The storyline centres on the fee tail, or "entail", governing the titled elite, which endows title and estate exclusively to male heirs. As part of the backstory, the main character, Robert Crawley, Earl of Grantham, had resolved his father's past financial difficulties by marrying Cora Levinson, an American heiress. Her considerable dowry is now contractually incorporated into the committal entail in perpetuity; however, Robert and Cora have three daughters and no son.

Series 1 (2010)

The first series, comprising seven episodes, explores the lives of the fictional Crawley family, the hereditary Earl of Grantham, and their domestic servants. The storyline centres on the fee tail, or "entail", governing the titled elite, which endows title and estate exclusively to male heirs. As part of the backstory, the main character, Robert Crawley, Earl of Grantham, had resolved his father's past financial difficulties by marrying Cora Levinson, an American heiress. Her considerable dowry is now contractually incorporated into the committal entail in perpetuity; however, Robert and Cora have three daughters and no son.

Series 2 (2011)

The second series comprises eight episodes and runs from the Battle of the Somme in 1916 to the 1918 Spanish flu pandemic. During the war, Downton Abbey is temporarily converted into an officers' convalescent hospital.

Series 3 (2012)

In episode one of the third series, covering 1920 to 1921, preparations are underway for Mary and Matthew's wedding. Tom and Sybil Branson arrive from Ireland, where they now live, to attend the wedding. Also arriving to attend the wedding of her granddaughter is Cora's mother, Martha Levinson, from America. Robert (Lord Grantham) learns that the bulk of the family's fortune (including Cora's dowry) has been lost due to his impetuous investment in the Grand Trunk Railway. Meanwhile Edith has fallen for Sir Anthony Strallan, whom Robert discourages from marrying Edith due to his age and crippled arm. At Edith's insistence, Robert gives in and welcomes Sir Anthony, but even though he loves her, Strallan cannot accept that the Grantham family disapproves of the match, and at the altar announces that he cannot go through with the wedding, devastating Edith. Strallan flees the church and is never heard from again.

Series 4 (2013)

In series four, covering 1922 to 1923, O'Brien leaves to serve Lady Flintshire in British India. Cora hires Edna Braithwaite, who had previously been fired for her interest in Tom. Eventually the situation blows up, and Edna is replaced by Phyllis Baxter.

Series 5 (2014)

In series five, covering the year 1924, a Russian exile, Prince Kuragin, wishes to renew his past affections for the Dowager Countess (Violet). Violet instead locates his wife in British Hong Kong and reunites the Prince and his estranged wife. Scotland Yard and the local police investigate Green's death. Violet learns that Marigold is Edith's daughter. Meanwhile, Mrs Drewe, not knowing Marigold's true parentage, resents Edith's constant visits. To increase his chances with Mary, Charles Blake plots to reunite Gillingham and his ex-fiancée, Mabel. After Edith inherits Michael Gregson's publishing company, she removes Marigold from the Drewes and relocates to London. Simon Bricker, an art expert interested in one of Downton's paintings, shows his true intentions toward Cora and is thrown out by Robert, causing a temporary rift between the couple.

Series 6 (2015)

In series six, changes are once again afoot at Downton Abbey as the middle class rises and more bankrupted aristocrats are forced to sell off their large estates. Downton must do more to ensure its future survival; reductions in staff are considered, forcing Barrow to look for a job elsewhere. Having formed a close bond with young George, Barrow realises that Downton has become the first real home he has ever had, but feels unwanted. Mary defies a blackmailer, who is thwarted by Robert. With Tom's departure to Boston, Mary becomes the estate agent. Edith is more hands-on in running her magazine and hires a female editor. Violet and Isobel once again draw battle lines as a government take-over of the local hospital is considered. Mary begins seeing Henry Talbot, a racing driver, and Edith begins seeing Bertie Pelham, a cousin of the owner of Brancaster Castle.

Cast and Characters

The main cast of the Crawley family is led by Hugh Bonneville as Robert Crawley, the Earl of Grantham, and Elizabeth McGovern as his wife Cora Crawley, the Countess of Grantham. Their three daughters are depicted by Michelle Dockery as Lady Mary Crawley (Talbot), Laura Carmichael as Lady Edith Crawley (Pelham), and Jessica Brown Findlay as Lady Sybil Crawley (Branson). Maggie Smith is Robert Crawley's mother Violet, Dowager Countess of Grantham. Samantha Bond portrays Lady Rosamund Painswick, Robert's sister who resides in Belgrave Square, London. Dan Stevens portrays Matthew Crawley, the new heir, along with Penelope Wilton as his mother, Isobel Crawley, who are brought to Downton. Allen Leech as Tom Branson begins the series as the family chauffeur, but falls in love with Lady Sybil, marries her, and later becomes the agent for the estate. David Robb portrays Dr Richard Clarkson, the local town doctor.

Crawley Family

The series is set in Downton Abbey, a Yorkshire country house, which is the home and seat of the Earl and Countess of Grantham, along with their three daughters and other family members. Each series follows the lives of the aristocratic Crawley family, their friends, and their servants during the reign of King George V.

Production

Gareth Neame of Carnival Films conceived the idea of an Edwardian-era TV drama set in a country house and approached Fellowes, who had won an Academy Award for Best Writing (Original Screenplay) for Gosford Park. The TV series Downton Abbey—written and created by Fellowes—was originally planned as a spin-off of Gosford Park, but instead was developed as a stand-alone property inspired by the film, set decades earlier. Although Fellowes was reluctant to work on another project resembling Gosford Park, within a few weeks he returned to Neame with an outline of the first series. Influenced by Edith Wharton's The Custom of the Country, Fellowes wrote the scripts; and his wife, Emma, acted as an informal story editor.

Filming Locations

Highclere Castle in north Hampshire is used for exterior shots of Downton Abbey and most of the interior filming. The kitchen, servants' quarters, and working areas, and some of the "upstairs" bedrooms were constructed and filmed at Ealing Studios. Bridgewater House in the St James area of London served as the family's London home.

Opening Theme Music

The opening music of Downton Abbey, titled "Did I Make the Most of Loving You?", was composed by John Lunn.

Broadcasts

The rights to broadcast Downton Abbey have been acquired in over 220 countries and territories, and the series has been viewed by a global audience of an estimated 120 million people.

Critical Response

At Metacritic, which assigns a rating out of 100 to reviews from mainstream critics, the first series received an average score of 91, based on 16 reviews, which indicates "universal acclaim". This result earned the show a Guinness World Record in 2011 for "Highest critical review ratings for a TV show", making Downton Abbey the critically best received TV show in the world.

Ratings

The first episode of Downton Abbey had a consolidated British audience of 9.2 million viewers, a 32% audience share—making it the most successful new drama on any channel since Whitechapel was launched on ITV in February 2009. The total audience for the first episode, including repeats and ITV Player viewings, exceeded 11.6 million viewers. This was beaten by the next episode, with a total audience of 11.8 million viewers—including repeats and ITV Player views. Downton Abbey broke the record for a single episode viewing on ITV Player.

Awards and Nominations

Although Julian Fellowes supports a united Ireland, there has been criticism of the stereotypical Irish characters used in the show, specifically the character of Tom Branson's brother, Kieran, portrayed as a rude and boorish drunk. Allen Leech, who plays Tom Branson, defended the series, stating that the show did not portray Irish characters in a pejorative fashion. Branson's character took some criticism in Ireland from The Irish Times, which described the character as "an Irish republican turned Downtonian toff."

Cultural Reaction

Although Julian Fellowes supports a united Ireland, there has been criticism of the stereotypical Irish characters used in the show, specifically the character of Tom Branson's brother, Kieran, portrayed as a rude and boorish drunk. Allen Leech, who plays Tom Branson, defended the series, stating that the show did not portray Irish characters in a pejorative fashion. Branson's character took some criticism in Ireland from The Irish Times, which described the character as "an Irish republican turned Downtonian toff."

Authenticity

Fellowes has said he tries to be as authentic in his depiction of the period as he can. Despite this, the show features many linguistic anachronisms. The accents of characters have also been questioned, with the Received Pronunciation of the actors who play the wealthy characters described as "slightly more contemporary" than would be expected among early-20th-century aristocrats; however, this "elicited more natural and unaffected performances from the cast."

Home Media

The series was made available in its entirety on Netflix in June 2021. It has also been made available on Amazon Prime Video, Peacock, the PBS app, and PBS.org with a PBS Passport subscription.

Streaming

The series was made available in its entirety on Netflix in June 2021. It has also been made available on Amazon Prime Video, Peacock, the PBS app, and PBS.org with a PBS Passport subscription.

Blu-ray and DVD

On 16 September 2011, two days before the UK premiere of the second series, it was reported by Amazon.com that the first series of Downton Abbey had become the highest selling DVD boxset of all time on the online retailer's website, surpassing popular American programmes such as The Sopranos, Friends, and The Wire.

Books

The World of Downton Abbey, a book featuring a behind-the-scenes look at Downton Abbey and the era in which it is set, was released on 15 September 2011. It was written by Jessica Fellowes (the niece of Julian Fellowes) and published by HarperCollins.

Soundtracks

A soundtrack, featuring music from the series and also new songs, was released by Decca in September 2011. Music by John Lunn and Don Black features, with vocals from Mary-Jess Leaverland and Alfie Boe. A second soundtrack was released on 19 November 2012 entitled Downton Abbey: The Essential Collection. A third and final soundtrack, containing two discs, was released on 15 January 2016 entitled Downton Abbey: The Ultimate Collection and featured music spanning from all six seasons of the series, including some from the first soundtrack.

Cultural Impact

Some of the fashion items worn by characters on the show have seen a strong revival of interest in the UK and elsewhere during the show's run, including starched collars, midi skirts, beaded gowns, and hunting plaids.

Other Media

Due to the show's popularity, there have been a number of references and spoofs on it, such as Family Guy episode "Chap Stewie", which has Stewie Griffin reborn in a household similar to Downton Abbey, and How I Met Your Mother episode "The Fortress", where the gang watch a television show called Woodworthy Manor, which is remarkably similar to Downton Abbey.

The Gilded Age

Julian Fellowes's The Gilded Age, which debuted on HBO in 2022, portrays New York in the 1880s and how its old New York society coped with the influx of newly wealthy families. While a separate series, a young Cora, Countess of Grantham, could make an appearance on the new show.

Film Adaptations

On 13 July 2018, a feature-length film was confirmed, with production commencing mid-2018. The film was written by Julian Fellowes and is a continuation of the TV series, with direction by Brian Percival. It was distributed by Focus Features and Universal Pictures International. The film was released in the United Kingdom on 13 September 2019, with the United States following one week later on 20 September 2019. Filming of a sequel began in April 2021. The film was finally released in the UK on 29 April 2022, and in the US on 20 May.

Fellowes has said he tries to be as authentic in his depiction of the period as he can [10] Despite this, the show features many linguistic anachronisms [104] The accents of characters have also been questioned, with the Received Pronunciation of the actors who play the wealthy characters described as "slightly more contemporary" than would be expected among early-20th-century aristocrats; however, this "elicited more natural and unaffected performances from the cast" [105]


Home media
The series was made available in its entirety on Netflix in June 2021 It has also been made available on Amazon Prime Video, Peacock, the PBS app and PBS.org with a PBS Passport subscription [113] [114]


Streaming
The series was made available in its entirety on Netflix in June 2021 It has also been made available on Amazon Prime Video, Peacock, the PBS app and PBS.org with a PBS Passport subscription [113] [114]


Blu-ray and DVD
On 16 September 2011, two days before the UK premiere of the second series, it was reported by Amazon.com that the first series of Downton Abbey had become the highest selling DVD boxset of all time on the online retailer's website, surpassing popular American programmes such as The Sopranos, Friends and The Wire [115]


Books
The World of Downton Abbey, a book featuring a behind-the-scenes look at Downton Abbey and the era in which it is set, was released on 15 September 2011 It was written by Jessica Fellowes (the niece of Julian Fellowes) and published by HarperCollins [116] [117]


Soundtracks
A soundtrack, featuring music from the series and also new songs, was released by Decca in September 2011 Music by John Lunn and Don Black features, with vocals from Mary-Jess Leaverland and Alfie Boe [116] A second soundtrack was released on 19 November 2012 entitled Downton Abbey: The Essential Collection [119] and a third and final soundtrack, containing two discs, was released on 15 January 2016 entitled Downton Abbey: The Ultimate Collection and featured music spanning from all six seasons of the series including some from the first soundtrack [120]


Cultural impact
Some of the fashion items worn by characters on the show have seen a strong revival of interest in the UK and elsewhere during the show's run, including starched collars, midi skirts, beaded gowns, and hunting plaids [121]


Other media
Due to the show's popularity, there have been a number of references and spoofs on it, such as Family Guy episode "Chap Stewie", which has Stewie Griffin reborn in a household similar to Downton Abbey, and How I Met Your Mother episode "The Fortress", where the gang watch a television show called Woodworthy Manor, which is remarkably similar to Downton Abbey [128]


The Gilded Age
Julian Fellowes's The Gilded Age, which debuted on HBO in 2022, portrays New York in the 1880s and how its old New York society coped with the influx of newly wealthy families [129] [130] While a separate series, a young Cora, Countess of Grantham, could [when?] make an appearance on the new show [131]


Film adaptations
On 13 July 2018, a feature-length film was confirmed, with production commencing mid-2018 [132] The film was written by Julian Fellowes and is a continuation of the TV series, with direction by Brian Percival It was distributed by Focus Features and Universal Pictures International [133] The film was released in the United Kingdom on 13 September 2019, with the United States following one week later on 20 September 2019 [134] Filming of a sequel began in April 2021 [135] The film was finally released in the UK on 29 April 2022, and in the US on 20 May [136]

article:
# Charlotte Church

Charlotte Church is a Welsh singer, actress, and writer who has gained international recognition for her classical and pop music talents. Born and raised in Cardiff, Wales, Church has been a prominent figure in the music industry since her early teenage years.

## Early Life

Charlotte Maria Reed was born on February 21, 1986, in Llandaff, a district of Cardiff, Wales, to Maria and computer engineer Stephen Reed. Her parents separated when she was two years old, and she was raised by her mother, who brought her up as a Roman Catholic. In 1992, Maria married her second husband, James Church, who adopted Charlotte in 1999. Church has four siblings: two younger half-brothers, through her biological father, and two older step-siblings from her adoptive father's previous marriage.

## Music Career

As a classical music singer, Church sang in English, Welsh, Latin, Italian, and French. She was introduced to the Cardiff impresario Jonathan Shalit, who became her manager and negotiated a contract with Sony Music. Her first album, _Voice of an Angel_ (1998), was a collection of arias, sacred songs, and traditional pieces that sold millions worldwide and made her the youngest artist with a No 1 album on the British classical crossover charts.

## 1998-2002: Classical Career

During this period, Church continued to sing classical music and released several albums, including _Enchantment_ (1999) and _Dream a Dream_ (2000). She also sang at various high-profile events, including the 1999 Brit Awards and the 2000 Eurovision Song Contest.

## 2003-2009: Pursuing Pop Career; Tissues and Issues

In 2003, Church teamed up with trance music producer Jurgen Vries to sing vocals on his track "The Opera Song (Brave New World)". She was credited on the records as CMC (her initials) as it was her first foray into pop music. The song reached number three in the UK Singles Chart, Church's second-highest-charting single and Vries' highest. Church's subsequent albums, _Tissues and Issues_ (2005) and _Back to Scratch_ (2007), saw her experimenting with pop and electronic music styles.

## 2010-2011: Return to Music and Back to Scratch

In 2010, Church appeared on _Friday Night with Jonathan Ross_ on 13 March 2010, where she confirmed that she had already begun writing and recording her sixth studio album. Church stated that the album was of a different sound to previous ones, more mature with a "kooky" vibe. The album, _Back to Scratch_, was released in 2011 and marked a departure from her previous work.

## Since 2012: One, Two, Three, and Four

On 26 May 2012, Church premiered three new songs "The Rise", "How Not to be Surprised When You're a Ghost", and "Say It's True" on BBC Radio with Bethan Elfyn. Church released her first EP _ONE_ on 4 September 2012. In 2013, Church gave the BBC 6 Music's John Peel Lecture at The Lowry in Salford, in which she criticised the music industry for what she described as a culture of sexism that pressures female artists to project a sexualised image of themselves.

## Acting and Television Career

Church has made a number of cameo appearances on television. She appeared in the CBS series _Touched by an Angel_, appeared in the 1999 Christmas special of _Heartbeat_, and in 2002, 2003, and 2012 she appeared on episodes of _Have I Got News for You_ (the first time as the show's youngest-ever panellist; the second time as host). In 2005, she played herself in an episode of _The Catherine Tate Show_, in a sketch with the fictional character Joanie Taylor ("Nan"). In 2008, Church appeared briefly in a sketch in Katy Brand's Big Ass Show.

## Writing

Church released an autobiography titled _Voice of an Angel (My Life So Far)_ in October 2000, aged 14. She released a second autobiography titled _Keep Smiling_ in late 2007.

## Personal Life

Church's personal life and relationships were reported on by UK tabloid newspapers, inspiring the song "Let's Be Alone" on her album _Tissues and Issues_ (2005).

## Discography

* _Voice of an Angel_ (1998)
* _Enchantment_ (1999)
* _Dream a Dream_ (2000)
* _Tissues and Issues_ (2005)
* _Back to Scratch_ (2007)
* _ONE_ (2012)

## Television and Film

* _Touched by an Angel_ (TV series, 2001)
* _Heartbeat_ (TV series, 1999)
* _Have I Got News for You_ (TV series, 2002, 2003, 2012)
* _The Catherine Tate Show_ (TV series, 2005)
* _Katy Brand's Big Ass Show_ (TV series, 2008)

## Awards and Nominations

* Winner: Brit Award for Best British Female Solo Artist (2000)
* Winner: Brit Award for Best British Album (2000)
* Nominated: Brit Award for Best British Single (2003)
* Nominated: MOBO Award for Best Female Act (2005)

## See Also

* Music industry
* Female artists
* Sexism in the music industry
* Welsh culture

## External Links

* Official website of Charlotte Church
* Charlotte Church on Twitter
* Charlotte Church on Instagram

title: Justin_J._Pearson
content:
Early life and education
Pearson was born in Memphis, Tennessee [3] [4] His father was a preacher and his mother a teacher [5] When he was 11 years old, his family moved to the Washington, D.C area while his father pursued a master's degree at Howard University [5] Four years later, the family returned to Memphis, where Justin was shocked by the contrast between his previous high school in Centreville, Virginia and his new school, which was conspicuously underfunded [5] At Mitchell High School in inner-city Memphis, Pearson became active in student government, lobbied for textbooks and Advanced Placement classes, and joined the debate team [5] He graduated as valedictorian of his high school class [6]


Environmental activism
In 2020, Pearson co-founded the environmental advocacy group Memphis Community Against Pollution (originally Memphis Community Against the Pipeline), one of two local groups that joined in a successful effort to cancel construction of the Byhalia Pipeline [6] [8] A portion of the 49-mile-long (79 km) pipeline would pass through poor black neighborhoods in south Memphis, as well as over the Memphis sand aquifer, which provides water to residents in the Memphis area [9]


Political career
Pearson ran in the January 24, 2023 Democratic primary for a special election to succeed Barbara Cooper in the Tennessee House of Representatives  Cooper died on October 25, 2022; in November 2022, she was posthumously re-elected with 74% of the vote [10] Because no Republicans or independents filed to run for the seat, the primary victor was ensured victory in the special general election [11] Pearson won the ten-person primary with 52.3% of the vote [12] The next day, he was unanimously appointed and sworn into the vacant office by the Memphis City Council as the interim representative prior to the uncontested March 24, 2023 special general election [13] Pearson became the second youngest lawmaker currently serving in the Tennessee House of Representatives [14] [6] [15]


Protest and expulsion
After the 2023 Covenant School shooting in Nashville that killed three nine-year-olds and three employees, Pearson joined a March 30 protest for gun control reform at the state capitol alongside Gloria Johnson and Justin Jones [22] Pearson, Johnson and Jones were dubbed by their supporters as "The Tennessee Three", and the Tennessee House voted on whether to expel the three members, which requires a two-thirds majority or 66 votes [23] Pearson was expelled by a vote of 69–26; Jones, who is also black, was expelled by 72–25 Johnson, who is white, was spared her ouster by just one vote, 65–30 [24] In his final address to the House before his expulsion, Pearson compared his removal from the chamber to the crucifixion of Jesus Christ [25] On April 7, 2023, Vice President Kamala Harris visited with the trio, echoing President Joe Biden who had called them earlier, saying, "Punishing lawmakers who joined thousands of peaceful protesters calling for action" is "shocking, undemocratic, and without precedent." [26]

article:
# Justin J. Pearson

Justin J. Pearson is an American politician and environmental activist who has served as a member of the Tennessee House of Representatives since 2023. He was born in Memphis, Tennessee, and grew up in a family that valued education and community service. Pearson has been a vocal advocate for environmental justice and has worked to address issues such as pollution and climate change in his community.

## Early Life and Education

Justin J. Pearson was born in Memphis, Tennessee, to a family of educators. His father was a preacher and his mother a teacher, and they instilled in him a strong sense of social responsibility from a young age. When Pearson was 11 years old, his family moved to the Washington, D.C. area, where his father pursued a master's degree at Howard University. Four years later, the family returned to Memphis, where Pearson attended Mitchell High School in inner-city Memphis.

Pearson's experience in high school was marked by a stark contrast between his previous education in Centreville, Virginia, and his new school in Memphis. The school in Memphis was underfunded and lacked resources, which motivated Pearson to become involved in student government and to lobby for textbooks and Advanced Placement classes. He also joined the debate team and became a strong advocate for his community.

Pearson graduated as valedictorian of his high school class, a testament to his hard work and dedication to his studies. His experiences in high school prepared him for a career in public service, where he could use his skills and knowledge to make a positive impact in his community.

## Environmental Activism

In 2020, Pearson co-founded the environmental advocacy group Memphis Community Against Pollution (originally Memphis Community Against the Pipeline), one of two local groups that joined in a successful effort to cancel construction of the Byhalia Pipeline. A portion of the 49-mile-long pipeline would have passed through poor black neighborhoods in south Memphis, as well as over the Memphis sand aquifer, which provides water to residents in the Memphis area.

The proposed pipeline was met with fierce opposition from local residents, who were concerned about the potential environmental and health impacts of the project. Pearson and his group worked tirelessly to raise awareness about the issue and to build a coalition of local organizations and community leaders who shared their concerns.

Through their efforts, Pearson and his group were able to mobilize public support against the pipeline, which ultimately led to its cancellation. This victory was a significant achievement for Pearson and his community, and it demonstrated the power of grassroots activism in shaping public policy.

## Political Career

In 2023, Pearson ran in the Democratic primary for a special election to succeed Barbara Cooper in the Tennessee House of Representatives. Cooper had passed away in October 2022, and her seat was left vacant. Despite the fact that no Republicans or independents filed to run for the seat, the primary was still hotly contested, with ten candidates vying for the nomination.

Pearson won the primary with 52.3% of the vote, earning him the right to run in the special general election. Because the seat was unopposed, Pearson was virtually guaranteed victory, and he was sworn into office on January 25, 2023.

As a member of the Tennessee House of Representatives, Pearson has been a vocal advocate for environmental justice and has worked to address issues such as pollution and climate change in his community. He has also been a strong supporter of education and has worked to increase funding for public schools.

## Protest and Expulsion

On March 30, 2023, Pearson joined a protest for gun control reform at the state capitol alongside Gloria Johnson and Justin Jones. The protest was in response to the 2023 Covenant School shooting in Nashville, which killed three nine-year-olds and three employees.

Pearson, Johnson, and Jones were dubbed by their supporters as "The Tennessee Three," and their participation in the protest was seen as a bold move to push for change in the state. The Tennessee House of Representatives voted on whether to expel the three members, which requires a two-thirds majority or 66 votes.

Pearson was expelled by a vote of 69-26, Jones was expelled by 72-25, and Johnson was spared her ouster by just one vote, 65-30. In his final address to the House before his expulsion, Pearson compared his removal from the chamber to the crucifixion of Jesus Christ.

The expulsion of Pearson and his colleagues was widely criticized by politicians and activists, who saw it as a move to silence dissenting voices and to stifle public debate. Vice President Kamala Harris visited with the trio on April 7, 2023, echoing President Joe Biden who had called them earlier, saying, "Punishing lawmakers who joined thousands of peaceful protesters calling for action" is "shocking, undemocratic, and without precedent."

## Electoral History

Justin J. Pearson's electoral history is marked by his successful bid for the Tennessee House of Representatives in 2023. He won the Democratic primary with 52.3% of the vote and went on to win the special general election unopposed.

Pearson's election to the Tennessee House of Representatives was seen as a significant achievement for environmental activists and progressive groups in the state. His win marked a shift in the balance of power in the state legislature and set him up for a potentially influential role in shaping public policy.

As a member of the Tennessee House of Representatives, Pearson has been a vocal advocate for environmental justice and has worked to address issues such as pollution and climate change in his community. He has also been a strong supporter of education and has worked to increase funding for public schools.

Pearson's expulsion from the House of Representatives was a setback for his efforts to push for change in the state, but he has vowed to continue advocating for his community's interests through other channels. His legacy as a grassroots activist and politician will likely continue to inspire others to take up the fight for social justice and environmental protection.

title: Billions_(TV_series)
content:
Plot
U.S Attorney for the Southern District of New York Chuck Roades (Giamatti) goes after hedge fund owner Bobby "Axe" Axelrod (Lewis) A collision course, with each using all of their considerable smarts and influence to outmaneuver the other, looms.


Cast and characters
The series was ordered by Showtime in March 2015, [22] and the first season premiered January 17, 2016 [23] On January 26, 2016, the series was renewed for a second season, [24] which premiered on February 19, 2017 [25] Showtime confirmed in April 2017 that Asia Kate Dillon, who is non-binary, would be a series regular in the third season [9] Billions is considered to be the first American TV series to have a non-binary character [8]

Development
The series was ordered by Showtime in March 2015, [22] and the first season premiered January 17, 2016 [23] On January 26, 2016, the series was renewed for a second season, [24] which premiered on February 19, 2017 [25] Showtime confirmed in April 2017 that Asia Kate Dillon, who is non-binary, would be a series regular in the third season [9] Billions is considered to be the first American TV series to have a non-binary character [8]


Broadcast
The first episode was made available on January 1, 2016, via video on demand services in the U.S and via CraveTV in Canada [33] [34] It premiered on Stan in Australia on January 27, 2016, and in Canada on The Movie Network on January 17, 2016, simultaneous with the American broadcast [35]


Depiction of BDSM
The show captured the attention of the BDSM community, as it features numerous depictions of BDSM activity, and the two main characters of Charles "Chuck" Rhoades, Jr and his wife Wendy Rhoades engage in BDSM scenes numerous times in the early seasons of the show In addition, season 4 of the show depicts the character of Chuck Rhoades coming out as a practitioner of BDSM in a public political speech The show's producers retained the services of noted BDSM lifestyle expert Olivia Troy as a consultant to help ensure the activities are portrayed both accurately and safely [36]


Reception
On Rotten Tomatoes, the series holds an overall approval rating of 86%, with a rating of 78% for season 1, 89% for season 2, 93% for season 3, 97% for season 4, 91% for season 5, 100% for season 6, and 60% for season 7 [51] The site's critical consensus for the first season reads: "Despite a lack of likable characters, Billions' soapy melodrama and larger-than-life canvas offer plenty of repeat viewing potential." article:
**Billions**

**Introduction**

Billions is a drama television series that premiered in 2016 on Showtime. The show was created by Brian Koppelman, David Levien, and Andrew Ross Sorkin, and it follows the cat-and-mouse game between two characters, Chuck Rhoades, a U.S. Attorney for the Southern District of New York, and Bobby "Axe" Axelrod, a hedge fund owner. The series explores the world of high finance and the consequences of the characters' actions.

**Cast and Characters**

The series features a talented ensemble cast, including Paul Giamatti as Chuck Rhoades, Damian Lewis as Bobby Axelrod, Maggie Siff as Wendy Rhoades, and Malin Åkerman as Lara Axelrod. Asia Kate Dillon, who is non-binary, plays the role of Taylor Mason, a non-binary character who is a series regular in the third season. The show also features a number of recurring characters, including David Costabile, Condola Rashad, and Jeffrey DeMunn.

**Main Plot**

The series follows the story of Chuck Rhoades, a ruthless and cunning U.S. Attorney who is determined to bring down Bobby Axelrod, a wealthy and powerful hedge fund owner. Axelrod is a master of manipulation and is willing to do whatever it takes to stay ahead of the law. As the series progresses, the two characters engage in a game of cat and mouse, each trying to outmaneuver the other.

**Recurring Themes**

Throughout the series, a number of recurring themes are explored, including the corrupting influence of power, the consequences of greed, and the blurred lines between right and wrong. The show also explores the personal lives of the characters, including their relationships and their struggles with addiction.

**Episodes**

The series consists of seven seasons, with a total of 75 episodes. Each episode is approximately 60 minutes long and features a self-contained storyline, although there are also ongoing storylines throughout the series.

**Production**

The series was produced by Showtime and was created by Brian Koppelman, David Levien, and Andrew Ross Sorkin. The show features a talented cast and crew, including director Neil Burger and cinematographer Chris Manley. The series was filmed on location in New York City and features a number of real-life locations, including the New York Stock Exchange and the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

**Development**

The idea for the series was conceived by Brian Koppelman, who was inspired by his own experiences working in the financial industry. Koppelman teamed up with David Levien and Andrew Ross Sorkin to develop the show, which was pitched to Showtime in 2014. The series was greenlit in 2015 and premiered in 2016.

**Broadcast**

The series premiered on January 17, 2016, and was made available on video on demand services in the U.S. and Canada. The show was also broadcast on The Movie Network in Canada and Stan in Australia. The series was well-received by critics and audiences alike, and it has since become one of Showtime's most popular series.

**Depiction of BDSM**

The show features a number of depictions of BDSM activity, particularly in the early seasons. **Reception**

The series has received widespread critical acclaim, with many praising the show's complex characters, engaging storylines, and thought-provoking themes. The show has been praised for its portrayal of the financial industry and its exploration of the consequences of greed and power. The show has also been praised for its diverse cast and its inclusion of non-binary characters.

**Accolades**

The series has been nominated for a number of awards, including several Primetime Emmy Awards and a Golden Globe Award. The show has won a number of awards, including a Golden Globe Award for Best Actor in a Drama Series for Paul Giamatti's performance.

**Lawsuits**

The series has faced several lawsuits regarding copyright infringement and defamation. In 2019, the show's producers were sued by a number of individuals who claimed that the show had infringed on their copyrights. The lawsuit was settled out of court.

article:
Cameron Norrie

Cameron Norrie is a British professional tennis player who has been competing at the highest level since turning pro in 2017. He has made a significant impact in the sport, winning several titles and becoming the first British male player to reach the top 10 in the ATP rankings since Greg Rusedski in 1998.

Early and personal life
------------------------

Cameron Norrie was born in 1995 in Johannesburg, South Africa, to British microbiologist parents, David and Helen Norrie. His father is from Glasgow, Scotland, and his mother is from Cardiff, Wales. Norrie's early life was marked by a passion for tennis, which he developed at a young age. He began playing tennis at the age of 6 and quickly demonstrated a natural talent for the sport.

Junior career
-------------

As a junior, Norrie represented New Zealand, becoming the No 10 in the world. However, he received limited financial support from Tennis New Zealand, and his parents had to finance his overseas travel. At 15, he toured the ITF's European junior circuit for five months, competing against the best junior players from around the world.

University career
-----------------

In 2011, Norrie received a sports scholarship to study sociology at Texas Christian University (TCU) in Fort Worth, Texas. He joined the Horned Frogs university team, where he became the top-ranked male college tennis player in the US, a feat that had never been achieved before by a TCU player. In addition to his individual success, Norrie was ranked All-American three times.

2014-17
---------

During his time at TCU, Norrie continued to excel on the court, winning several titles and becoming a leader on the team. He also maintained a strong academic record, graduating with a degree in sociology. In 2017, he turned pro, completing three years of his four-year university course.

Davis Cup
----------

In 2018, Norrie made his debut for the British Davis Cup team, competing in the World Group first-round match against Spain. He recorded the biggest win of his career, coming from two sets down to defeat world No 23 Roberto Bautista Agut in five sets. This impressive performance earned him a spot in the British team for the World Group quarterfinals.

Senior career
-------------

Norrie's senior career has been marked by several notable achievements. In 2019, he reached his first ATP final at the Auckland Open, where he lost to Tennys Sandgren in straight sets. He also reached his first ATP 500 semi-final at the 2019 Indian Wells Masters, where he lost to Rafael Nadal.

2020-21
---------

In 2020, Norrie reached his first ATP title at the 2020 Delray Beach Open, defeating Reilly Opelka in the final. He also reached his first Masters 1000 final at the 2020 Cincinnati Open, where he lost to Dominic Thiem. In 2021, he won his first Masters 1000 title at the 2021 Indian Wells Masters, defeating Nikoloz Basilashvili in the final.

Playing style and coaching
-------------------------

Norrie is a counter-puncher with consistent but unorthodox ground-strokes. He hits a heavy topspin forehand with a long back-swing, in contrast to the short take-back on his flat backhand. His playing style has been influenced by his coaches, including his current coach, Albert Portas.

Career statistics
-----------------

As of the 2024 US Open, Norrie's career statistics are as follows:

* ATP titles: 10
* ATP finals: 15
* Masters 1000 titles: 2
* Grand Slam performance: reached the semi-finals at Wimbledon and the quarter-finals at the Australian Open

Grand Slam tournament performance timeline
------------------------------------------

* Australian Open: reached the quarter-finals (2022)
* French Open: reached the second round (2021)
* Wimbledon: reached the semi-finals (2022)
* US Open: reached the third round (2021)

Significant finals
------------------

* ATP titles: 10
* Masters 1000 titles: 2
* Grand Slam semi-finals: 1

Masters 1000 finals
-------------------

* Singles: 1 (1 title)

External links
---------------

* Cameron Norrie at the Association of Tennis Professionals
* Cameron Norrie at the International Tennis Federation

title: Julie_Powell
content:
Early life and education
Powell was born April 20, 1973, to John Landrum and Kay Elaine (née Carradine) Foster [2] [3] She had a brother named Jordan Foster [2] She was raised in Austin, Texas She graduated from Amherst College in 1995 with a double major in theater and creative writing [4]


Career
While working for the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation in August 2002, Powell began the Julie/Julia Project, a blog on Salon chronicling her attempt to cook all the recipes in Julia Child's Mastering the Art of French Cooking [1] [5] The blog quickly gained a large following, and Powell signed a book deal with Little, Brown and Company The resulting book, Julie and Julia: 365 Days, 524 Recipes, 1 Tiny Apartment Kitchen, was published in 2005 [6] The paperback edition was retitled Julie and Julia: My Year of Cooking Dangerously.


Julie & Julia: 365 Days, 524 Recipes, 1 Tiny Apartment Kitchen
While working for the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation in August 2002, Powell began the Julie/Julia Project, a blog on Salon chronicling her attempt to cook all the recipes in Julia Child's Mastering the Art of French Cooking [1] [5] The blog quickly gained a large following, and Powell signed a book deal with Little, Brown and Company The resulting book, Julie and Julia: 365 Days, 524 Recipes, 1 Tiny Apartment Kitchen, was published in 2005 [6] The paperback edition was retitled Julie and Julia: My Year of Cooking Dangerously.


Film
The film Julie & Julia directed by Nora Ephron was released August 7, 2009 The film was based on both Julie Powell's book and Julia Child's autobiography My Life in France Amy Adams starred as Julie Powell and Meryl Streep as Julia Child Julie's husband, Eric, was portrayed by Chris Messina Julia's husband, Paul, was portrayed by Stanley Tucci [14]


Cleaving: a Story of Marriage, Meat, and Obsession
Powell's second book, Cleaving: a Story of Marriage, Meat, and Obsession, details her experiences learning to butcher at Fleisher's butcher shop in Kingston, New York, and the effects of affairs by both her and her husband on their marriage It was published on November 30, 2009 [15] [16] The work received several negative reviews based on the content of the book and Powell's openness about the affairs [17] [18]


Return to Salon
In 2022, Powell started writing a series of commentary pieces for Salon about The Julia Child Challenge, a Food Network reality television show in which Powell was not involved [19]


Personal life and death
Julie married Eric Powell, an editor for the magazine Archaeology, in 1998 [20] Powell experienced COVID-19 in late 2022 She died of cardiac arrest at her home in Olivebridge, New York, on October 26, 2022, at age 49 [21] [22] In addition to her husband, Powell was survived by her brother, Jordan, and her parents, John and Kay.

article:
# Julie Powell

Julie Powell was an American author and blogger who gained international recognition for her culinary endeavors and her writing about food, marriage, and personal struggles. Her life and work were marked by a unique blend of creativity, culinary passion, and introspection.

## Early Life and Education

Julie Powell was born on April 20, 1973, to John Landrum and Kay Elaine (née Carradine) Foster. She had a brother named Jordan Foster, and the family lived in Austin, Texas. Powell's early life and education laid the groundwork for her future endeavors. She was an inquisitive and creative child who developed a strong interest in the arts and writing. Her parents encouraged her creative pursuits, and she began to explore her passion for theater and creative writing.

Powell's academic journey took her to Amherst College, where she graduated in 1995 with a double major in theater and creative writing. Her time at Amherst College was instrumental in shaping her writing skills and her passion for the arts. The college's rigorous academic environment and diverse student body exposed Powell to a wide range of perspectives and ideas, which would later influence her writing and culinary pursuits.

## Career

After graduating from Amherst College, Powell began her career in the arts and writing. She worked in various roles, including as a technical writer and a marketing specialist. However, it was her blog, the Julie/Julia Project, that brought her international recognition and acclaim. Launched in 2002, the blog chronicled Powell's attempt to cook all the recipes in Julia Child's Mastering the Art of French Cooking. The project was a massive undertaking that required Powell to spend hours in the kitchen, experimenting with new recipes and techniques.

The Julie/Julia Project quickly gained a large following, and Powell's writing was praised for its wit, humor, and vulnerability. Her blog posts were a reflection of her passion for food, her love of learning, and her struggles with her own identity and relationships. title: Lorenzen_Wright
content:
Early life and college
Raised in Oxford, Mississippi, Wright played for Lafayette High School [4] in Mississippi before moving to Memphis, where he spent his senior year playing for Booker T Washington High School [5] He played all levels of basketball in Memphis – high school, collegiate, and professional His father, Herb, was a professional basketball player who competed in Finland, and once had a tryout with the Utah Jazz When Wright was seven years old, Herb was working for the Memphis Police Department when he was paralyzed by a gunshot to the back [6]


Professional career
Wright was selected seventh overall by the Los Angeles Clippers in the 1996 NBA draft out of the University of Memphis On April 26, 1997, as a rookie, Wright scored what would be a postseason career-high 17 points in a Game 2 loss against the Utah Jazz [7] The Clippers would go on to lose the series The following season, on December 26, 1997, Wright scored a season-high 32 points and grabbed 15 rebounds in an overtime loss to the Los Angeles Lakers [8]  Wright moved on to the Atlanta Hawks in 1999, and averaged a career high 12.4 points per game with them during the 2000-01 NBA season [9] He was traded to the Memphis Grizzlies on June 27, 2001 On January 6, 2003, Wright scored 20 points and grabbed 14 rebounds in a 106–102 win over the New Orleans Hornets [10] Wright returned to the Hawks in 2006.


Personal life
In 2000, Wright and three native-Memphis NBA players, Todd Day, Penny Hardaway and Elliot Perry, provided financial assistance to Travis Butler, a Memphis orphan whose tragic story garnered national attention [12]


Disappearance and death
On July 18, 2010, Wright left his ex-wife's home in Collierville, Tennessee This was the last time he was seen alive [13] His family filed a missing-persons report on July 22, 2010 [14] [15] Wright's body was found six days later in a wooded area on Callis-Cutoff Road, just west of Hacks Cross Road.

article:
**Lorenzen Wright**

Lorenzen Wright was an American professional basketball player who played in the National Basketball Association (NBA) for 13 seasons. He was a multi-talented player who played all levels of basketball in Memphis, from high school to collegiate and professional levels. Wright's life was marked by both athletic success and personal struggles, ultimately culminating in a tragic and untimely death.

**Early life and college**

Lorenzen Wright was born in 1975 in Memphis, Tennessee. He grew up in Oxford, Mississippi, where he played basketball for Lafayette High School. Wright's father, Herb, was a professional basketball player who competed in Finland and had a tryout with the Utah Jazz. When Wright was seven years old, his father was working for the Memphis Police Department when he was paralyzed by a gunshot to the back. This incident had a profound impact on Wright's life and motivated him to succeed in basketball.

Wright's family moved to Memphis, where he spent his senior year playing basketball for Booker T. Washington High School. He played all levels of basketball in Memphis, including high school, collegiate, and professional levels. Wright's hard work and dedication paid off when he was selected to play for the University of Memphis, where he played college basketball.

**Professional career**

Wright was selected seventh overall by the Los Angeles Clippers in the 1996 NBA draft out of the University of Memphis. As a rookie, Wright played in 64 games, averaging 7.8 points and 4.4 rebounds per game. On April 26, 1997, Wright scored a postseason career-high 17 points in a Game 2 loss against the Utah Jazz. The Clippers would go on to lose the series.

The following season, Wright scored a season-high 32 points and grabbed 15 rebounds in an overtime loss to the Los Angeles Lakers on December 26, 1997. Wright's performance earned him recognition as one of the top young players in the league. However, the Clippers struggled to make the playoffs, and Wright's future with the team remained uncertain.

In the summer of 1999, Wright was traded to the Atlanta Hawks. He played two seasons with the Hawks, averaging 8.5 points and 5.1 rebounds per game. Wright's time in Atlanta was marked by inconsistency, and he failed to live up to expectations. However, he remained a valuable contributor to the team.

On June 27, 2001, Wright was traded to the Memphis Grizzlies. He played four seasons with the Grizzlies, averaging 8.6 points and 6.3 rebounds per game. Wright's time in Memphis was marked by a resurgence in his career, as he became a key contributor to the team.

**Personal life**

In 2000, Wright and three native-Memphis NBA players, Todd Day, Penny Hardaway, and Elliot Perry, provided financial assistance to Travis Butler, a Memphis orphan whose tragic story garnered national attention. Wright's generosity and commitment to giving back to his community earned him recognition as a positive role model.

Wright's personal life was also marked by a high-profile relationship with his ex-wife, Sherra Wright. The couple had a daughter together, and their relationship was subject to intense media scrutiny.

**Disappearance and death**

On July 18, 2010, Wright left his ex-wife's home in Collierville, Tennessee. This was the last time he was seen alive. His family filed a missing-persons report on July 22, 2010. Wright's body was found six days later in a wooded area on Callis-Cutoff Road, just west of Hacks Cross Road.

Wright's death was ruled a homicide, and an investigation was launched. The case remains unsolved to this day. Wright's family and friends have been left to pick up the pieces and come to terms with the tragic loss of a talented and vibrant young man.

content:
Plot
Bala Singham is a crime boss who sends a container of ₹10,000 crore (US$1.2 billion) to India to bribe the MLAs to place his father, Guru Singham as the next CM Pooja is a criminologist who learns about Mohan Gandhi as a part of her research, who was convicted of killing his whole family, except for his daughter She meets him in the prison, but he refuses to talk to her While seeing him and his daughter's bond, she promises to help him get bail if he narrates his story, to which Gandhi agrees.


Cast
Ravi Teja was reported to play dual roles in the film [5] Meenakshi Chaudhary and Dimple Hayathi are cast as the leads [6] Principal photography of the film began in November 2020 [7] Few action scenes were shot in Italy in April–May 2021 [8] The second schedule of the film began in June 2021, after a break due to the second wave of COVID-19 pandemic in India [9]


Production
Ravi Teja was reported to play dual roles in the film [5] Meenakshi Chaudhary and Dimple Hayathi are cast as the leads [6] Principal photography of the film began in November 2020 [7] Few action scenes were shot in Italy in April–May 2021 [8] The second schedule of the film began in June 2021, after a break due to the second wave of COVID-19 pandemic in India [9]


Music
The soundtrack and score of the film is composed by Devi Sri Prasad [13] The audio rights were acquired by Aditya Music.

The film's release was originally scheduled for 28 May 2021 [14] Owing to the COVID-19 pandemic in India, the film's release was then postponed indefinitely [15] The makers soon announced that the film would be released in theatres only [16] The film was released on 11 February 2022 along with its Hindi dubbed version [17] [18]

Khiladi received mixed to negative reviews from critics and audience, who praised Ravi Teja's performance but criticised the direction and screenplay [19]

In early June 2021, actor Salman Khan acquired the remake rights for the film's Hindi version [25] [26]

article:
**Khiladi (2022 film)**

Khiladi is a 2022 Indian action thriller film directed by Ramesh Varma and produced by Ramabrahmam Sunkara under the banner of AKA Entertainments. The film stars Ravi Teja in dual roles alongside Meenakshi Chaudhary and Dimple Hayathi in the lead roles. The film's music is composed by Devi Sri Prasad, and the audio rights were acquired by Aditya Music.

**Plot**

The film revolves around two main characters, Bala Singham and Mohan Gandhi. Bala Singham is a crime boss who sends a container of ₹10,000 crore (US$1.2 billion) to India to bribe the MLAs to place his father, Guru Singham, as the next Chief Minister. Meanwhile, Mohan Gandhi is a convict who was sentenced to life imprisonment for killing his entire family, except for his daughter. The story takes a turn when Pooja, a criminologist, meets Mohan Gandhi in prison and learns about his story. She promises to help him get bail if he narrates his story, to which Gandhi agrees. As the story unfolds, Pooja discovers a complex web of deceit and corruption that leads her to Bala Singham and his father.

**Cast**

Ravi Teja was reported to play dual roles in the film. Meenakshi Chaudhary and Dimple Hayathi are cast as the leads in the film. The film also stars Anu Emmanuel, Dayanandan, and Sathya in supporting roles.

**Production**

The principal photography of the film began in November 2020. Few action scenes were shot in Italy in April-May 2021. The second schedule of the film began in June 2021, after a break due to the second wave of COVID-19 pandemic in India.

**Music**

The soundtrack and score of the film is composed by Devi Sri Prasad. The audio rights were acquired by Aditya Music. The music of the film received mixed reviews from critics and audience.

**Release**

The film's release was originally scheduled for 28 May 2021. Owing to the COVID-19 pandemic in India, the film's release was then postponed indefinitely. The makers soon announced that the film would be released in theatres only. The film was released on 11 February 2022 along with its Hindi dubbed version.

**Reception**

Khiladi received mixed to negative reviews from critics and audience. The film was praised for Ravi Teja's performance, but criticized for the direction and screenplay. The film's plot was also panned by many critics.

**Remake**

In early June 2021, actor Salman Khan acquired the remake rights for the film's Hindi version. The remake is expected to be released in the near future.

**Impact**

The film's release was a major commercial success, despite receiving mixed reviews from critics and audience. The film's success can be attributed to Ravi Teja's performance and the film's engaging plot. The film's music and action sequences were also praised by many critics and audience.

**Conclusion**

Khiladi is a 2022 Indian action thriller film directed by Ramesh Varma and produced by Ramabrahmam Sunkara. The film stars Ravi Teja in dual roles alongside Meenakshi Chaudhary and Dimple Hayathi in the lead roles. The film's music is composed by Devi Sri Prasad, and the audio rights were acquired by Aditya Music. The film received mixed to negative reviews from critics and audience, but was a commercial success. The film's remake rights were acquired by Salman Khan in early June 2021.
