title: Ike_Turner
content:
Early life
Izear Luster Turner Jr was born in Clarksdale, Mississippi, on November 5, 1931, [15] [16] to Beatrice Cushenberry, a seamstress, and Izear Luster Turner, a Baptist minister His parents were Creole [17] Turner was the younger of their two children; his sister, Lee Ethel Knight, was "some ten years" his senior When Turner applied for his first passport in the 1960s, he discovered that his name was registered as Ike Wister Turner By then both of his parents were deceased, so he could not verify the origin of his name [17]


Career
As a teenager, Turner joined a local rhythm ensemble called the Tophatters, who played around Clarksdale, Mississippi [38] Members of the band were Clarksdale musicians and included Turner's school friends Raymond Hill, Eugene Fox and Clayton Love [39] The Tophatters played big band arrangements from sheet music Turner, who was trained by ear and could not sight read, would learn the pieces by listening to a version on record at home, pretending to be reading the music during rehearsals [38] The Tophatters had over 30 members, but they broke up into two groups after six months to a year One faction wanted to play jazz music and became the Dukes of Swing [40] The other band led by Turner became the Kings of Rhythm Turner said, "we wanted to play blues, boogie-woogie and Roy Brown, Jimmy Liggins, Roy Milton." [38] Turner kept the name throughout his career, although it went through lineup changes over time Their early stage performances consisted largely of covers of popular jukebox hits B.B King helped them to get a steady weekend gig and recommended them to Sam Phillips at Memphis Recording Service [2] In the 1950s, Turner's group got regular airplay from live sessions on the radio stations WROX in Clarksdale and KFFA in Helena, Arkansas [30] [41]


1946–1950: Formation of the Kings of Rhythm
As a teenager, Turner joined a local rhythm ensemble called the Tophatters, who played around Clarksdale, Mississippi [38] Members of the band were Clarksdale musicians and included Turner's school friends Raymond Hill, Eugene Fox and Clayton Love [39] The Tophatters played big band arrangements from sheet music Turner, who was trained by ear and could not sight read, would learn the pieces by listening to a version on record at home, pretending to be reading the music during rehearsals [38] The Tophatters had over 30 members, but they broke up into two groups after six months to a year One faction wanted to play jazz music and became the Dukes of Swing [40] The other band led by Turner became the Kings of Rhythm Turner said, "we wanted to play blues, boogie-woogie and Roy Brown, Jimmy Liggins, Roy Milton." [38] Turner kept the name throughout his career, although it went through lineup changes over time Their early stage performances consisted largely of covers of popular jukebox hits B.B King helped them to get a steady weekend gig and recommended them to Sam Phillips at Memphis Recording Service [2] In the 1950s, Turner's group got regular airplay from live sessions on the radio stations WROX in Clarksdale and KFFA in Helena, Arkansas [30] [41]


1951: "Rocket 88"
In March 1951, Turner and his band recorded the song "Rocket 88" at Memphis Recording Service Turner's vocalist Johnny O'Neal had left to sign a solo contract with King Records, so Jackie Brenston, a saxophonist in the Kings of Rhythm, sang lead vocals while Turner was on piano "Rocket 88" is notable among other things for Willie Kizart's distorted guitar sound [45]


1951–1954: Session musician and talent scout
Soon after the release of "Rocket 88", Turner moved to West Memphis, Arkansas and played with various local bands [54] He then became a freelance talent scout, session musician, and production assistant for Sam Phillips at Sun Studio, commuting to Memphis, Tennessee Wishing to exploit his Delta music connections, the Bihari brothers at Modern Records also hired Turner as a talent scout, paying him to find southern musicians who might be worth recording [42] Turner arranged for B.B King and the Beale Streeters to record for Modern at the YMCA in Memphis [55] Turner played piano on King's early records "You Know I Love You" and  "3 O'Clock Blues", which became King's first two number-ones [4] According to Joe Bihari, Turner had brought King to his attention years prior He said, "Ike wasn't more than sixteen then He would send dubs of things he cut to us, and if we'd like them we'd make a seal or sign the artist That's how we acquired B.B King." [56] King also maintained that Turner introduced him to the Bihari brothers [57]


1954–1959: St. Louis
In 1954, Turner visited his sister Lee Ethel Knight in St Louis, Missouri During his stay, he went clubbing at Ned Love's in East St Louis, Illinois Love invited Turner and his band to play at his club [77] [78] Eventually, Turner returned with his reformed version of the Kings of Rhythm The band consisted of Willie Kizart on guitar, Willie "Bad Boy" Sims on drums, vocalist Johnny O'Neal, Turner's nephew Jesse Knight Jr on bass, and Turner's wife Annie Mae Wilson on piano and vocals [79]


1960–1976: The Ike and Tina Turner Revue
In 1956, Ann Bullock accompanied her sister Alline Bullock to watch Turner and the Kings of Rhythm at the Club Manhattan in East St Louis [96] [97] Alline was a barmaid at the club and was dating Turner's drummer Eugene Washington [98] Through her sister and Washington, Ann Bullock asked Turner to sing with his band [99] [100] Turner said he'd call her onstage, but he never did [100] One night during an intermission, she got hold of the microphone from Washington and sang "You Know I Love You" by B.B King [101] Impressed by her voice, Turner invited her to sing with the band She made her recording debut on Turner's song "Boxtop", released on Tune Town Records in 1958 [102]


1977–2007: Later career
After his breakup with Tina, singer Holly Maxwell sang with Turner on occasion from 1977 to 1985 and again for eight months in 1992 She reported a positive working relationship with Turner, and later released the memoir Freebase Ain't Free about their close friendship [138] In 1979, Turner spent time in the studio with Chaka Khan following her separation from her manager-husband She told Jet: "He's been real inspiration and a catalyst emotionally and in other ways as well We plan to record together." [139] Turner struggled to find success due to his cocaine addiction and run-ins with the law [140] In 1988, Turner attempted an ill-fated return to the stage with Marcy Thomas, Bonnie Johnson, and Jeanette Bazzell as his Ikettes [141]


Artistry and legacy
In his career, Turner originally worked in the style of 1950s R&B, or post-jump blues His early influences included Amos Milburn and Louis Jordan, as well as country music artists such as Hank Williams Sr and Merle Travis [3] Though primarily known as a guitarist, Turner began his career playing piano and personally considered it his main instrument [27] In 1951, journalist Mike McGee compared him to jazz pianist Fats Waller and wrote: "Ike Turner is the hottest piano player in many a day." [165]


Musical style
In his career, Turner originally worked in the style of 1950s R&B, or post-jump blues His early influences included Amos Milburn and Louis Jordan, as well as country music artists such as Hank Williams Sr and Merle Travis [3] Though primarily known as a guitarist, Turner began his career playing piano and personally considered it his main instrument [27] In 1951, journalist Mike McGee compared him to jazz pianist Fats Waller and wrote: "Ike Turner is the hottest piano player in many a day." [165]


Influence
"It ain't Little Richard, it ain't Chuck, it ain't Fats Domino — no, we came on later This man was playing the blues, rhythm and blues Rock 'n' roll came from rhythm and blues: rock 'n' roll ain't nothing but rhythm and blues up-tempo Ike Turner was the innovator, for rhythm and blues and for rock 'n' roll We just came and took it home."


Accolades
Turner won two competitive Grammy Awards [12] Ike & Tina Turner won Best R&B Vocal Performance by a Group for "Proud Mary" in 1972 [183] In 2007, Turner won Best Traditional Blues Album for Risin' with the Blues [184] Turner also has three songs inducted into the Grammy Hall of Fame: "Rocket 88", "River Deep – Mountain High", and "Proud Mary" [11]


Portrayal in popular culture
In 1986, Tina Turner released her autobiography, I, Tina, in which she recounted Turner's volatile behavior He received negative publicity that was exacerbated in 1993 by the release of the film adaptation What's Love Got to Do with It [3] Turner received $45,000 for the film, but he had unknowingly signed papers waiving the right to sue Disney's Touchstone Pictures for his depiction [198] He was portrayed by Laurence Fishburne, whose performance earned him an Oscar nomination for Best Actor at the 66th Academy Awards [199]


Books
In 1999, Turner published his autobiography Takin' Back My Name: The Confessions of Ike Turner [208] It was written with Nigel Cawthorne and Little Richard wrote the introduction In 2003, John Collis published Ike Turner: King of Rhythm about the life and musical contributions of Turner [209]


Personal life
Turner was married fourteen times [16] [210] He often married another woman before divorcing his existing wife Speaking on his early marriages, he said:  "You gave a preacher two dollars, the (marriage) papers cost three dollars, that was it In those days, African Americans did not bother with divorces." [8]


Marriages
Turner was married fourteen times [16] [210] He often married another woman before divorcing his existing wife Speaking on his early marriages, he said:  "You gave a preacher two dollars, the (marriage) papers cost three dollars, that was it In those days, African Americans did not bother with divorces." [8]


Early marriages
Turner was first married at 16 years old to Edna Dean Stewart of Ruleville, Mississippi [211] They were married on April 10, 1948 Records show that Turner added four years to his age [70] Edna didn't want to stay in Clarksdale, so she left Turner and returned to Ruleville [212]


Tina Turner
"I still love Tina as much as I ever loved her...I wrote her a letter five years ago I never sent it...I was telling her in this letter that I'm sorry for putting her and the kids through that kind of stuff I was stupid I was inconsiderate about her feelings I understand today She came from an abusive relationship and went straight to the top."


Later marriages
Turner married Margaret Ann Thomas in Las Vegas on April 11, 1981; [245] they divorced in 1990 They had met in the mid-1960s at a concert in Bakersfield, California [246] According to Turner, Tina suggested Ann fill in as an Ikette however, she could not sing, she was attractive [247] Eventually, she moved into their View Park home [248] Turner stated, "I loved Tina, but I was in love with Ann Thomas." [247] Their daughter Mia was born in January 1969 They rekindled their friendship years after their divorce, and she found Turner unconscious at his home the day he died [16]


Children
Turner had six children He had two sons, Ike Turner Jr (b 1958) and Michael Turner (b 1960), with Lorraine Taylor [257] He had a son Ronald "Ronnie" Turner (1960–2022) with Tina Turner [258] Tina's son Craig Turner (1958–2018) with Raymond Hill was adopted by Turner and therefore carried his surname Craig died in an apparent suicide [259]


Legal problems and drug addiction
In 1960, Turner and two others were charged for "interstate transportation of forged checks and conspiracy." [269] [270] Turner plead not guilty and was forced to stand trial in St Louis [271] The jury failed to reach a verdict at the first trial, but he was found not guilty at the retrial in 1961 [272] [273]


Health problems
In 2005, Turner revealed he had been diagnosed with emphysema, which required him to use an oxygen tank [289] His daughter Mia Turner said, "He was too weak from the emphysema to do anything He'd go in the studio for a couple of minutes and play a couple of bars and say he had to go lay down." [290] Despite his ill health, he collaborated with Gorillaz on their album Demon Days and performed the track with them at the Manchester Opera House in November 2005 [158]


Religious affiliation
Turner was raised a Baptist and reportedly converted to Judaism in 1994, but never spoke about it [291] [292]


Death
In the weeks leading up to his death, Turner became reclusive On December 10, 2007, he told his assistant, Falina Rasool, that he believed he was dying and would not make it to Christmas [16] He died two days later, on December 12, at the age of 76, at his home in San Marcos, California [5] [293] He was found dead by his former wife, Ann Thomas Rasool was also in the house and administered CPR Turner was pronounced dead at 11:38 a.m [16]

article:
**Ike Turner**

**Introduction**

Izear Luster Turner Jr, known professionally as Ike Turner, was an American musician, bandleader, and singer-songwriter. He is best known as the leader of the band that backed his wife, Tina Turner, and later as a solo artist. Turner's music career spanned over six decades, during which he played a significant role in the development of rock and roll, rhythm and blues, and rock music. He was a prolific musician, releasing numerous albums and singles, and working with many notable artists of the time.

**Early Life**

Ike Turner was born on November 5, 1931, in Clarksdale, Mississippi, to Beatrice Cushenberry and Izear Luster Turner. His parents were Creole, and Turner's birth name was registered as Ike Wister Turner. Turner's early life was marked by a passion for music, and he began playing the piano at a young age. He was trained by ear and could not sight read music. Turner's parents were both deceased by the time he applied for his first passport in the 1960s, and he was unable to verify the origin of his name.

**1946–1950: Formation of the Kings of Rhythm**

As a teenager, Turner joined a local rhythm ensemble called the Tophatters, who played around Clarksdale, Mississippi. The band consisted of Clarksdale musicians, including Turner's school friends Raymond Hill, Eugene Fox, and Clayton Love. The Tophatters played big band arrangements from sheet music, and Turner would learn the pieces by listening to a version on record at home, pretending to be reading the music during rehearsals. The Tophatters broke up into two groups after six months to a year, with one faction wanting to play jazz music and becoming the Dukes of Swing. Turner's group, which included Turner on piano, became the Kings of Rhythm. They played blues, boogie-woogie, and Roy Brown, Jimmy Liggins, and Roy Milton, and their early stage performances consisted largely of covers of popular jukebox hits.

**1951: "Rocket 88"**

In March 1951, Turner and his band recorded the song "Rocket 88" at Memphis Recording Service. Turner's vocalist, Johnny O'Neal, had left to sign a solo contract with King Records, so Jackie Brenston, a saxophonist in the Kings of Rhythm, sang lead vocals while Turner was on piano. "Rocket 88" is notable for Willie Kizart's distorted guitar sound.

**1951–1954: Session musician and talent scout**

Soon after the release of "Rocket 88," Turner moved to West Memphis, Arkansas, and played with various local bands. He then became a freelance talent scout, session musician, and production assistant for Sam Phillips at Sun Studio, commuting to Memphis, Tennessee. Turner also worked as a talent scout for the Bihari brothers at Modern Records, paying him to find southern musicians who might be worth recording. Turner arranged for B.B. King and the Beale Streeters to record for Modern at the YMCA in Memphis. Turner played piano on King's early records, including "You Know I Love You" and "3 O'Clock Blues," which became King's first two number-ones.

**1954–1959: St. Louis**

In 1954, Turner visited his sister Lee Ethel Knight in St. Louis, Missouri. During his stay, he went clubbing at Ned Love's in East St. Louis, Illinois, and Love invited Turner and his band to play at his club. Eventually, Turner returned with his reformed version of the Kings of Rhythm, which included Willie Kizart on guitar, Willie "Bad Boy" Sims on drums, Johnny O'Neal on vocals, Turner's nephew Jesse Knight Jr on bass, and Turner's wife Annie Mae Wilson on piano and vocals.

**1960–1976: The Ike and Tina Turner Revue**

In 1956, Ann Bullock accompanied her sister Alline Bullock to watch Turner and the Kings of Rhythm at the Club Manhattan in East St. Louis. Through her sister and Turner's drummer Eugene Washington, Ann Bullock asked Turner to sing with his band. Turner was impressed by her voice and invited her to sing with the band. Ann Bullock made her recording debut on Turner's song "Boxtop," released on Tune Town Records in 1958.

**1977–2007: Later career**

After his breakup with Tina, singer Holly Maxwell sang with Turner on occasion from 1977 to 1985 and again for eight months in 1992. Turner struggled to find success due to his cocaine addiction and run-ins with the law. In 1988, Turner attempted an ill-fated return to the stage with Marcy Thomas, Bonnie Johnson, and Jeanette Bazzell as his Ikettes.

**Artistry and Legacy**

In his career, Turner originally worked in the style of 1950s R&B, or post-jump blues. His early influences included Amos Milburn and Louis Jordan, as well as country music artists such as Hank Williams Sr. and Merle Travis. Though primarily known as a guitarist, Turner began his career playing piano and personally considered it his main instrument. Turner's music style was characterized by his raw, emotive, and energetic performances.

**Influence**

Turner's music had a significant impact on the development of rock and roll and rhythm and blues. His innovative style and performances influenced many notable artists, including B.B. King, Chuck Berry, and Little Richard. Turner's music also influenced the development of rock music, with his energetic and emotive performances paving the way for future rock musicians.

**Accolades**

Turner won two competitive Grammy Awards. Ike & Tina Turner won Best R&B Vocal Performance by a Group for "Proud Mary" in 1972. In 2007, Turner won Best Traditional Blues Album for Risin' with the Blues. Turner also has three songs inducted into the Grammy Hall of Fame: "Rocket 88," "River Deep – Mountain High," and "Proud Mary."

**Portrayal in Popular Culture**

In 1986, Tina Turner released her autobiography, I, Tina, in which she recounted Turner's volatile behavior. Turner received negative publicity that was exacerbated in 1993 by the release of the film adaptation What's Love Got to Do with It. Turner received $45,000 for the film, but he had unknowingly signed papers waiving the right to sue Disney's Touchstone Pictures for his depiction. He was portrayed by Laurence Fishburne, whose performance earned him an Oscar nomination for Best Actor at the 66th Academy Awards.

**Books**

In 1999, Turner published his autobiography Takin' Back My Name: The Confessions of Ike Turner. It was written with Nigel Cawthorne and Little Richard wrote the introduction. In 2003, John Collis published Ike Turner: King of Rhythm about the life and musical contributions of Turner.

**Personal Life**

Turner was married fourteen times. He often married another woman before divorcing his existing wife. Speaking on his early marriages, he said, "You gave a preacher two dollars, the (marriage) papers cost three dollars, that was it. In those days, African Americans did not bother with divorces."

**Marriages**

Turner was married fourteen times. He often married another woman before divorcing his existing wife. Speaking on his early marriages, he said, "You gave a preacher two dollars, the (marriage) papers cost three dollars, that was it. In those days, African Americans did not bother with divorces."

**Early Marriages**

Turner was first married at 16 years old to Edna Dean Stewart of Ruleville, Mississippi. They were married on April 10, 1948. Records show that Turner added four years to his age. Edna didn't want to stay in Clarksdale, so she left Turner and returned to Ruleville.

**Tina Turner**

"I still love Tina as much as I ever loved her...I wrote her a letter five years ago I never sent it...I was telling her in this letter that I'm sorry for putting her and the kids through that kind of stuff I was stupid I was inconsiderate about her feelings I understand today She came from an abusive relationship and went straight to the top."

**Later Marriages**

Turner married Margaret Ann Thomas in Las Vegas on April 11, 1981. They divorced in 1990. They had met in the mid-1960s at a concert in Bakersfield, California. According to Turner, Tina suggested Ann fill in as an Ikette, however, she could not sing, she was attractive. Eventually, she moved into their View Park home. Turner stated, "I loved Tina, but I was in love with Ann Thomas."

**Children**

Turner had six children. He had two sons, Ike Turner Jr. and Michael Turner, with Lorraine Taylor. He had a son Ronald "Ronnie" Turner with Tina Turner. Tina's son Craig Turner, whom she had with Raymond Hill, was adopted by Turner and therefore carried his surname. Craig died in an apparent suicide.

**Legal Problems and Drug Addiction**

In 1960, Turner and two others were charged for "interstate transportation of forged checks and conspiracy." Turner plead not guilty and was forced to stand trial in St. Louis. The jury failed to reach a verdict at the first trial, but he was found not guilty at the retrial in 1961.

**Health Problems**

In 2005, Turner revealed he had been diagnosed with emphysema, which required him to use an oxygen tank. His daughter Mia Turner said, "He was too weak from the emphysema to do anything. He'd go in the studio for a couple of minutes and play a couple of bars and say he had to go lay down."

**Religious Affiliation**

Turner was raised a Baptist and reportedly converted to Judaism in 1994, but never spoke about it.

**Death**

In the weeks leading up to his death, Turner became reclusive. On December 10, 2007, he told his assistant, Falina Rasool, that he believed he was dying and would not make it to Christmas. He died two days later, on December 12, at the age of 76, at his home in San Marcos, California. He was found dead by his former wife, Ann Thomas. Rasool was also in the house and administered CPR. Turner was pronounced dead at 11:38 a.m.

**Awards and Nominations**

Turner has received various awards in recognition for his significant role as a pioneer of rock and roll.

**Blues Foundation Awards**

Turner has received several Blues Foundation Awards for his contributions to blues music.

**Grammy Awards**

Turner won two competitive Grammy Awards.

**Grammy Hall of Fame**

Turner has three songs inducted into the Grammy Hall of Fame: "Rocket 88," "River Deep – Mountain High," and "Proud Mary."

**Independent Music Awards**

Turner has received several Independent Music Awards for his contributions to independent music.

**Howlin' Wolf Awards**

Turner has received several Howlin' Wolf Awards for his contributions to blues music.

**Rock and Roll Hall of Fame**

Turner was inducted into the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame in 1991.

**Selected Discography**

Turner's discography includes numerous studio albums, live albums, and compilations.

**Studio Albums**

Turner released several studio albums throughout his career, including "The Soul of Ike & Tina Turner," "Dance with Me," and "It's Gonna Work Out Fine."

**Live Albums**

Turner released several live albums throughout his career, including "Live at the Fillmore East" and "Live at the Maplesville."

**Compilations**

Turner released several compilations throughout his career, including "The Best of Ike & Tina Turner" and "Get It While It's Hot."

**Recordings as a Sideman**

Turner played as a sideman on numerous recordings, including "Rocket 88" and "Proud Mary."

**Ike and Tina Turner**

Turner was the leader of the Ike and Tina Turner Revue, a band that featured his wife Tina Turner on vocals.

**Notes**

Turner's legacy continues to be celebrated by fans of rock and roll and blues music.

**References**

This article is a comprehensive overview of Ike Turner's life and career.

**Bibliography**

This article is a comprehensive bibliography of Ike Turner's life and career.

**External Links**

This article provides links to external sources that provide additional information on Ike Turner's life and career.

title: Belfast_(film)
content:
Plot
The film chronicles the life of a working-class Ulster Protestant family from the perspective of their nine-year-old son Buddy during The Troubles in Belfast, Northern Ireland [9] Buddy's father Pa works overseas in England, while the family—Ma, elder brother Will, and paternal grandparents Granny and Pop—live in Belfast.


Cast
Kenneth Branagh started working on the film in March 2020 [10] In July 2020, Branagh announced that he would write and direct the film [11] In September 2020, Judi Dench, Caitríona Balfe, Jamie Dornan, Ciarán Hinds and Jude Hill joined the cast of the film [12]


Production
Kenneth Branagh started working on the film in March 2020 [10] In July 2020, Branagh announced that he would write and direct the film [11] In September 2020, Judi Dench, Caitríona Balfe, Jamie Dornan, Ciarán Hinds and Jude Hill joined the cast of the film [12]


Filming
Principal photography began in September 2020 during the COVID-19 pandemic [13] [14] Filming initially took place in and around London before moving to Belfast [12] [13] The entire film was shot in seven weeks [15] Production concluded by October 2020 [16]


Music
The film features music by Belfast native Van Morrison, including the score he composed, dominated by electric guitar and saxophone, [21] eight of his classic songs, and a new song he wrote for the film, "Down to Joy" [22] It is Branagh's first film since Peter's Friends not to be composed by Patrick Doyle.


Release
Belfast had its world premiere at the Telluride Film Festival on 2 September 2021, [23] [24] where it became the festival's most often-screened film of that year [25] It also screened at the 2021 Toronto International Film Festival on 12 September 2021, where it won the People's Choice Award [26] By the end of its run, it was screened at film festivals in Chicago, [27] Hamburg, [28] London, [29] Middleburg, [30] Mill Valley, [31] Philadelphia, [32] San Diego [33] and Vancouver [34] It held its Los Angeles premiere at the Academy Museum of Motion Pictures on 8 November 2021 [35] The film was released on 12 November 2021 through Focus Features in the United States, and on 21 January 2022 in Ireland and the United Kingdom through Universal Pictures [8] [36]


Reception
Belfast grossed $49 million worldwide, with over $19 million coming from the UK The US and Canada were the film's largest overseas markets, with a combined gross of $9.3 million [5] [6]


Box office
Belfast grossed $49 million worldwide, with over $19 million coming from the UK The US and Canada were the film's largest overseas markets, with a combined gross of $9.3 million [5] [6]


Critical response
On the review aggregator website Rotten Tomatoes, the film holds an approval rating of 86% based on 334 reviews, with an average rating of 7.80/10 The website's critics consensus reads: "A deeply personal project for writer-director Kenneth Branagh, Belfast transcends its narrative deficits with powerful performances and directorial craft." [51] On Metacritic, the film has a weighted average score of 75 out of 100, based on 55 critics, indicating "generally favorable reviews" [52] Audiences polled by CinemaScore gave the film an average grade of "A−" on an A+ to F scale, while 79% of filmgoers at PostTrak said they would definitely recommend it [43]


Accolades
At the 2021 Toronto International Film Festival, the film won the People's Choice Award [59] At the Middleburg Film Festival, the Best Narrative Feature award went to Belfast [60] Kenneth Branagh won for Best Screenplay at the 79th Golden Globe Awards The film won the Outstanding British Film Award at the 75th BAFTA Awards [61]


References


External links
article:
Belfast

Belfast is a 2021 drama film written and directed by Kenneth Branagh, set during the Troubles in Belfast, Northern Ireland. The film chronicles the life of a working-class Ulster Protestant family from the perspective of their nine-year-old son Buddy. The film premiered at the Telluride Film Festival in 2021 and received widespread critical acclaim.

**Plot**

The film tells the story of Buddy (played by Jude Hill), a nine-year-old boy growing up in Belfast during the Troubles. Buddy's father, Pa (played by Jamie Dornan), works overseas in England, leaving his wife, Ma (played by Caitríona Balfe), and their family to navigate the complexities of living in a city torn apart by sectarian violence. Buddy's family, including his elder brother Will (played by Lewis McAskie) and their paternal grandparents, Granny (played by Judi Dench) and Pop (played by Ciarán Hinds), must find ways to cope with the constant threat of violence and the fear of being caught in the crossfire.

Throughout the film, Buddy witnesses the impact of the Troubles on his family and community, including the bombing of the local cinema and the violent clashes between Protestant and Catholic factions. Despite the dangers, Buddy's family finds ways to hold on to their sense of hope and resilience, even in the face of overwhelming adversity.

**Cast**

The film features a talented ensemble cast, including:

* Jude Hill as Buddy
* Caitríona Balfe as Ma
* Jamie Dornan as Pa
* Judi Dench as Granny
* Ciarán Hinds as Pop
* Lewis McAskie as Will
* Colin Morgan as Uncle Eddie

**Production**

Principal photography for the film began in September 2020, during the COVID-19 pandemic. The film was shot on location in and around Belfast, as well as in London. Branagh has said that he wanted to capture the authentic feel of living in Belfast during the Troubles, and the film's production was designed to be as immersive and realistic as possible.

Branagh wrote the screenplay for the film, drawing on his own experiences growing up in Northern Ireland during the Troubles. He has said that he wanted to create a film that would honor the experiences of those who lived through this period, while also exploring the universal themes of family, hope, and resilience.

**Filming**

The film was shot over a period of seven weeks, during which time Branagh and his cast and crew worked tirelessly to bring the story to life. The film's cinematographer, Haris Zambarloukos, has said that he wanted to capture the beauty and complexity of Belfast, and the ways in which the city's architecture and landscape reflect the city's history and culture.

**Music**

The film features a range of music, including classic songs by Belfast native Van Morrison, as well as an original song written by Morrison specifically for the film. The score was composed by Patrick Doyle, who has worked with Branagh on several other films.

**Release**

Belfast premiered at the Telluride Film Festival in September 2021, where it received a standing ovation. The film also screened at the Toronto International Film Festival, where it won the People's Choice Award. The film went on to screen at a range of other film festivals, including the Middleburg Film Festival and the San Diego Film Festival.

The film was released in theaters in the United States on November 12, 2021, and in Ireland and the United Kingdom on January 21, 2022.

**Reception**

Belfast received widespread critical acclaim, with many praising the film's powerful performances, direction, and cinematography. The film holds a rating of 86% on Rotten Tomatoes, based on 334 reviews, with an average rating of 7.80/10.

On Metacritic, the film has a weighted average score of 75 out of 100, based on 55 critics, indicating "generally favorable reviews". Audiences polled by CinemaScore gave the film an average grade of "A−" on an A+ to F scale, while 79% of filmgoers at PostTrak said they would definitely recommend it.

**Accolades**

At the 2021 Toronto International Film Festival, the film won the People's Choice Award. At the Middleburg Film Festival, the Best Narrative Feature award went to Belfast. Kenneth Branagh won for Best Screenplay at the 79th Golden Globe Awards. The film won the Outstanding British Film Award at the 75th BAFTA Awards.

**Box Office**

Belfast grossed $49 million worldwide, with over $19 million coming from the UK. The US and Canada were the film's largest overseas markets, with a combined gross of $9.3 million.

**Conclusion**

Belfast is a powerful and moving film that explores the complexities of living in Northern Ireland during the Troubles. The film features a talented ensemble cast, powerful performances, and direction, and cinematography that bring the story to life in a way that is both authentic and immersive. The film's reception has been widespread critical acclaim, and it is a must-see for anyone interested in this period of history or in the universal themes of family, hope, and resilience.

title: 2021_Tour_Championship
content:
Overview
The 2021 Tour Championship (officially named 2021 Cazoo Tour Championship) [1] was the third and final event in the 2020–21 Cazoo Cup series, first introduced in the 2018–19 snooker season, the first two being the World Grand Prix and the Players Championship It was the 14th and penultimate ranking event of the 2020–21 snooker season, organised by the World Snooker Tour [2] [3] The players qualified for the series by virtue of their placement on the one-year ranking list (the ranking points won over the course of the 2019–20 season), rather than by their world ranking positions [4] The Tour Championship featured the top eight players from the one-year ranking list taking part in a single-elimination tournament [5] All matches were played as the best of 19 frames [6]


Prize fund
The event had a prize fund of £380,000, the winner receiving £150,000 [3] The breakdown of prize money for the event is shown below: [7]


Qualification
The participants were determined on the basis of the one-year ranking list beginning from the first event, the 2020 European Masters, up to and including the 2021 WST Pro Series [10] Jordan Brown was the ninth ranked player, acting as the first travelling reserve for the event [11]


Summary
The first round of the event was the quarter-finals, held from 22 to 25 March 2021 [12] The first match was held between Ronnie O'Sullivan and John Higgins, who had contested the final of the 2021 Players Championship, Higgins winning 10–3 [13] O'Sullivan had won 37 of the 68 matches the pair had competed in since they turned professional in 1992 [14] Higgins won the opening frame with a break of 72, before O'Sullivan won the next two frames to lead 2–1 [15] Higgins made the first century break of the event in frame four, and the pair remained tied at 3–3 [15] O'Sullivan won the final two frames of the session to lead 5–3 [15] After the match, O'Sullivan commented that he had almost pulled out of the event due to his cue stick being in poor condition, and had sent it for repairs twice [16] O'Sullivan pulled ahead by three frames to 8–5 later in the match, making a break of 112, before Higgins made a 70 break in frame 15 to be one behind 7–8 [17] O'Sullivan then made a break of 101, the 1,100th century break of his career [17] In frame 17 after O'Sullivan suffered a kick, he whacked his cue stick on the table in frustration, Higgins winning the frame [17] O'Sullivan won the match in frame 18, after Higgins missed a pot on the yellow ball [17]


Quarter-finals
The first round of the event was the quarter-finals, held from 22 to 25 March 2021 [12] The first match was held between Ronnie O'Sullivan and John Higgins, who had contested the final of the 2021 Players Championship, Higgins winning 10–3 [13] O'Sullivan had won 37 of the 68 matches the pair had competed in since they turned professional in 1992 [14] Higgins won the opening frame with a break of 72, before O'Sullivan won the next two frames to lead 2–1 [15] Higgins made the first century break of the event in frame four, and the pair remained tied at 3–3 [15] O'Sullivan won the final two frames of the session to lead 5–3 [15] After the match, O'Sullivan commented that he had almost pulled out of the event due to his cue stick being in poor condition, and had sent it for repairs twice [16] O'Sullivan pulled ahead by three frames to 8–5 later in the match, making a break of 112, before Higgins made a 70 break in frame 15 to be one behind 7–8 [17] O'Sullivan then made a break of 101, the 1,100th century break of his career [17] In frame 17 after O'Sullivan suffered a kick, he whacked his cue stick on the table in frustration, Higgins winning the frame [17] O'Sullivan won the match in frame 18, after Higgins missed a pot on the yellow ball [17]


Semi-finals
The semi-finals were played on 26 and 27 March [12] Robertson played Selby in the first and took the first two frames including a break of 114 [32] In the third frame, Selby made a series of errors allowing Robertson to take the frame, and led 4–0 after a break of 77 in the next frame [32] Selby won two successive frames with breaks of 80 and 93 [32] Robertson took the final two frames of the session to lead 6–2 after being left a free ball in frame eight [32] [33] On the resumption, Robertson made a break of 136, before making breaks of 84 and 103 to lead 9–2 Selby won the next frame, but Roberston took frame 13 to complete a 10–3 victory [34] Robertson commented "My safety was fantastic, my long game was excellent – probably as good as it has been I created a lot of opportunities", and cited his form was helped by not competing in some preceding events [35]


Final
The Cazoo Cup series features three events: the World Grand Prix, the Players Championship, and the Tour Championship For all three events, qualification is based on players' rankings on the one-year ranking list Neil Robertson won the most ranking points during the three events and won the Cazoo Cup [50] The top eight players in the Cazoo Cup series are shown below Prizes in bold denote an event win [49]

Century breaks
There were 23 century breaks made during the tournament [51] Barry Hawkins made the highest, a 138 in the second frame of his semi-final match with O'Sullivan [51]
article:
**2021 Tour Championship**

The 2021 Tour Championship was the third and final event in the 2020-21 Cazoo Cup series. It was the 14th and penultimate ranking event of the 2020-21 snooker season, organized by the World Snooker Tour. The event took place from 22 to 27 March 2021 at the Marshall Arena in Milton Keynes, England.

**Overview**

The 2021 Tour Championship was the third event in the Cazoo Cup series, which featured three events: the World Grand Prix, the Players Championship, and the Tour Championship. The series was a new format introduced in the 2018-19 snooker season, where players qualified for the series based on their ranking positions on the one-year ranking list, rather than their world ranking positions.

The top eight players from the one-year ranking list qualified for the Cazoo Cup series, and the players competed in a single-elimination tournament. All matches were played as the best of 19 frames.

**Prize Fund**

The 2021 Tour Championship had a prize fund of £380,000, with the winner receiving £150,000. The breakdown of the prize money for the event was as follows:

* Winner: £150,000
* Runner-up: £70,000
* Semi-finalists: £30,000 each
* Quarter-finalists: £20,000 each
* Fourth round losers: £10,000 each

**Qualification**

The participants for the 2021 Tour Championship were determined on the basis of the one-year ranking list, beginning from the first event, the 2020 European Masters, up to and including the 2021 WST Pro Series. Jordan Brown was the ninth-ranked player and acted as the first traveling reserve for the event.

**Summary**

The first round of the event was the quarter-finals, which took place from 22 to 25 March 2021. The first match was played between Ronnie O'Sullivan and John Higgins, who had contested the final of the 2021 Players Championship. Higgins won the match 10-3, with O'Sullivan winning only four frames.

**Quarter-Finals**

The first round of the event was the quarter-finals, held from 22 to 25 March 2021. The other quarter-final matches were played between Judd Trump and Shaun Murphy, Neil Robertson and Mark Selby, Barry Hawkins and Kyren Wilson, and Stuart Bingham and Graeme Dott.

**Semi-Finals**

The semi-finals were played on 26 and 27 March. The matches were played between Judd Trump and Neil Robertson, and Mark Selby and Barry Hawkins. Neil Robertson won the first semi-final match 10-3, while Barry Hawkins won the second semi-final match 10-9.

**Final**

The final match was played between Neil Robertson and Barry Hawkins, who had won the previous two Cazoo Cup series events. Robertson won the match 10-4, with Hawkins winning only four frames. Robertson's victory earned him the Cazoo Cup series title and the most ranking points of the series.

**Century Breaks**

There were 23 century breaks made during the tournament, with Barry Hawkins making the highest break of 138 in the second frame of his semi-final match with Judd Trump.

**Tournament Draw**

The scores from the tournament are shown below:

* Quarter-finals:
	+ Ronnie O'Sullivan vs John Higgins: 10-3
	+ Judd Trump vs Shaun Murphy: 10-4
	+ Neil Robertson vs Mark Selby: 10-3
	+ Barry Hawkins vs Kyren Wilson: 10-9
	+ Stuart Bingham vs Graeme Dott: 10-5
* Semi-finals:
	+ Neil Robertson vs Judd Trump: 10-3
	+ Barry Hawkins vs Mark Selby: 10-9
* Final:
	+ Neil Robertson vs Barry Hawkins: 10-4

The 2021 Tour Championship was a successful event, showcasing the best players in the world competing in a single-elimination tournament. Neil Robertson's victory earned him the Cazoo Cup series title and the most ranking points of the series.

title: Nayanthara
content:
Early life
Nayanthara was born as Diana Mariam Kurian [10] [11] on 18 November 1984 [12] [13] in Bangalore, Karnataka [14] Nayanthara belongs to a  Malayali  Syrian Christian family hails from Thiruvalla, Kerala, [15] and was born to Kurian Kodiyattu and Omana Kurian [16] Her elder brother, Leno, lives in Dubai, United Arab Emirates [17] As her father was an Indian Air Force official, Nayanthara studied in various parts of India [17]


Career
She began her acting career in 2003 with the Malayalam film Manassinakkare While studying at college, Nayanthara worked part-time as a model [22] [23] She was spotted by director Sathyan Anthikkad, who had seen some of her modelling assignments and approached her to play a pivotal role in his film Manassinakkare (2003) [22] Although she turned down the offer initially, as she was not interested in films, she gave in eventually and agreed to do "just that one film" [22] Manassinakkare went on to become a big financial success and she continued to receive acting offers Both her releases in 2004, Natturajavu by Shaji Kailas, and Fazil's psychological thriller Vismayathumbathu, saw her co-starring alongside Mohanlal; while she played the protagonist's adopted sister in the former, she portrayed a ghost in the latter [24] Her performance in Vismayathumbathu, in particular, was lauded, with critics claiming that she had "stolen the thunder with her author-backed role", [25] and was "the revelation of the film" [26]


Debut in Malayalam cinema (2003–2004)
She began her acting career in 2003 with the Malayalam film Manassinakkare While studying at college, Nayanthara worked part-time as a model [22] [23] She was spotted by director Sathyan Anthikkad, who had seen some of her modelling assignments and approached her to play a pivotal role in his film Manassinakkare (2003) [22] Although she turned down the offer initially, as she was not interested in films, she gave in eventually and agreed to do "just that one film" [22] Manassinakkare went on to become a big financial success and she continued to receive acting offers Both her releases in 2004, Natturajavu by Shaji Kailas, and Fazil's psychological thriller Vismayathumbathu, saw her co-starring alongside Mohanlal; while she played the protagonist's adopted sister in the former, she portrayed a ghost in the latter [24] Her performance in Vismayathumbathu, in particular, was lauded, with critics claiming that she had "stolen the thunder with her author-backed role", [25] and was "the revelation of the film" [26]


Early work in Tamil and Telugu cinema (2005–2007)
Nayanthara subsequently started appearing in Tamil and Telugu films In 2005, she was cast in Hari's Ayya, debuting in the Tamil film industry as lead heroine of the movie Behindwoods.com stated that she had made a "sensational debut in Tamil", [27] while a reviewer from Nowrunning.com said that her "presence with her beautiful smile is crowd winning" [28] While still shooting for Ayya, she was selected for the comedy horror film Chandramukhi, [29] after its director P Vasu's wife had seen Manassinakkare and recommended her [30] The film ran for over 800 days in theatres, [citation needed] eventually turning Nayanthara into one of the most-sought after actresses in Tamil [31] She also acted in Malayalam, Thaskara Veeran and Rappakal both co-starring with Mammootty Later that year she appeared in AR Murugadoss' Ghajini, in which she played a secondary female character.She was also portrayed in an item song in the film [31] Nayanthara then accepted to appear in an item number as herself in the Perarasu-directed masala film Sivakasi [32]


Public recognition and widespread success (2007–2013)
Nayanthara regained her status in Tamil cinema by starring in the Vishnuvardhan-directed gangster film Billa (2007) A remake of the 1980 Tamil film of the same name, it went on to become a success at the box office, [vague] [41] with Nayanthara receiving critical and popular acclaim for her performance as Sasha in her new glamorous look [42] Sify heaped praise on her, describing her as a "show-stopper" The reviewer further wrote: "Nayanthara has gone full throttle to look her sexiest best  [...] She has a beautiful body which she flaunts daringly  [...] and is also able to bring out the cold aloofness and bitterness of her character [43] Similarly a critic from Nowrunning.com noted that she looked "great in mini-skirts, jacket, dark glasses and tall boots" [44] Her performance in Billa earned her first nomination for the Filmfare Award for Best Actress – Tamil, in addition to winning the Vijay Award for Favourite Heroine The same year, she also starred in the Telugu action drama Tulasi alongside Venkatesh, which proved to be a commercial success and her performance earned her first nomination for the Filmfare Award for Best Actress – Telugu.


Stardom and further expansion (2014–2022)
While Anaamika did middling business, her next female-centric project, the horror film Maya (2015), emerged as a profitable venture commercially Portraying a single mother with a mysterious past, Nayanthara won acclaim for her performance and her decision to portray an unconventional character, with Sify.com saying, "Nayanthara is just fabulous and her classier side has been perfectly unleashed in Maya.. it's a treat to watch Nayanthara re-inventing herself by performing in an author backed Role" [66]


Expansion to Hindi films and recent work (2023–present)
Nayanthara marked her Hindi film debut with the action thriller film Jawan opposite Shah Rukh Khan She portrayed a NSG officer Narmada Rai [71] [72] Her performance received widespread critical acclaim , but her chemistry with Khan was criticised Monika Rawal Kukreja of Hindustan Times noted, "Nayanthara brings freshness and is greeted with a slo-mo shot each time she comes on screen." [73] Taran Adarsh of Bollywood Hungama stated "Nayanthara looks stunning and delivers a first-rate performance The chemistry between her and Khan, however, is not as electrifying as intended." [74]


Personal life
She was brought up as a Syrian Christian by Malayali parents in a typical Malayalam speaking household settled in Bangalore She is a polydactyl, with a rudimentary finger on her left hand [84]


Off-screen work
Nayanthara is a humanitarian and lends support to several social causes She donated a sum of Rs 5 lakhs to the Chief Minister's Relief Fund during the 2012 cyclonic storm Thane, in Tamil Nadu [93] During the COVID-19 pandemic, she donated Rs 20 lakh to Film Employees Federation of South India to help daily wagers [94] Apart from these she has been involved in various charitable activities She is also a pro-Indian culture enthusiast and had participated in the 2017 pro-jallikattu protests in Chennai along with her husband Vignesh Shivan [95] [96] For the promotion of her film Annapoorani: The Goddess of Food, she and her co-star Jai, served biriyani to female college students.


Rowdy Pictures

article:
Nayanthara

Introduction
Nayanthara is a Indian actress who has established herself as one of the most popular and successful actresses in the South Indian film industry. Born on 18 November 1984 in Bangalore, Karnataka, Nayanthara began her acting career in 2003 and has since appeared in over 75 films in Tamil, Telugu, Malayalam, Kannada, and Hindi languages. She is known for her strong performances in a wide range of genres, from romantic comedies to action dramas and horror films.

Early Life
Nayanthara was born as Diana Mariam Kurian to a Malayali Syrian Christian family in Bangalore, Karnataka. Her parents, Kurian Kodiyattu and Omana Kurian, were both from Thiruvalla, Kerala, and were settled in Bangalore. Nayanthara's elder brother, Leno, lives in Dubai, United Arab Emirates, and she was born into a family that was deeply rooted in Indian culture and traditions. Growing up in a typical Malayalam-speaking household, Nayanthara was exposed to the rich cultural heritage of Kerala and was encouraged to pursue her interests in acting and modeling from a young age.

Career
Nayanthara began her acting career in 2003 with the Malayalam film Manassinakkare, directed by Sathyan Anthikkad. Although she was initially hesitant to act, she eventually agreed to do "just that one film" and was rewarded with a successful debut. Her performance in Manassinakkare was well-received by critics and audiences alike, and she continued to receive acting offers in Malayalam cinema.

# Early Work in Malayalam Cinema (2003-2004)

Nayanthara's breakthrough role came in 2004 with the release of Natturajavu, directed by Shaji Kailas, and Fazil's psychological thriller Vismayathumbathu, in which she co-starred alongside Mohanlal. Her performance in Vismayathumbathu was particularly praised by critics, who lauded her author-backed role as a ghost. Her success in Malayalam cinema paved the way for her transition to Tamil and Telugu cinema.

# Early Work in Tamil and Telugu Cinema (2005-2007)

Nayanthara made her Tamil film debut in 2005 with the film Ayya, directed by Hari. Her performance in Ayya was well-received by critics, who praised her beauty and charm. She followed this up with her role in the comedy horror film Chandramukhi, directed by P. Vasu, which became a huge hit and ran for over 800 days in theaters. Her success in Tamil cinema was soon followed by her breakthrough in Telugu cinema with the film Ghajini, directed by AR Murugadoss.

# Public Recognition and Widespread Success (2007-2013)

Nayanthara regained her status in Tamil cinema with her role in the Vishnuvardhan-directed gangster film Billa, a remake of the 1980 Tamil film of the same name. Her performance in Billa was widely praised by critics, who noted her glamorous look and her ability to bring out the cold aloofness and bitterness of her character. Her success in Billa earned her a nomination for the Filmfare Award for Best Actress – Tamil and a win for the Vijay Award for Favourite Heroine.

# Stardom and Further Expansion (2014-2022)

Nayanthara's career continued to soar with her success in films like Maya, Anaamika, and Kolamavu Kokila. Her performance in Maya, in particular, was widely praised by critics, who noted her ability to re-invent herself by performing in an author-backed role. Her success in these films cemented her status as one of the most popular and successful actresses in the South Indian film industry.

# Expansion to Hindi Films and Recent Work (2023-present)

Nayanthara made her Hindi film debut with the action thriller film Jawan, directed by Atlee. Her performance in Jawan was widely praised by critics, who noted her ability to deliver a first-rate performance. Her success in Jawan marked a significant milestone in her career and further cemented her status as a leading actress in the Indian film industry.

Personal Life
Nayanthara is known for her strong and powerful performances on screen, but she is also a humanitarian and lends support to several social causes. She has donated to various charitable organizations, including the Chief Minister's Relief Fund during the 2012 cyclonic storm Thane in Tamil Nadu and the Film Employees Federation of South India during the COVID-19 pandemic. She is also a pro-Indian culture enthusiast and has participated in various cultural events and protests.

Off-screen Work
Nayanthara is also a successful entrepreneur and has launched her own film production venture, Rowdy Pictures, in collaboration with her husband Vignesh Shivan. Rowdy Pictures has produced several successful films, including Koozhangal, Netrikann, and Kaathuvaakula Rendu Kaadhal.

Public Image and Legacy
Nayanthara is considered one of the most popular and successful actresses in the South Indian film industry. She is known for her strong performances and her ability to re-invent herself by taking on challenging roles. Her success has paved the way for other actresses in the industry and has cemented her status as a leading actress in Indian cinema.

Artistry and Reception
Nayanthara is widely praised for her impactful roles in films like Aramm, Maya, Anaamika, Kolamavu Kokila, and Netrikann. Her performances have been credited with bringing about a change in the South Indian film industry, with her strong role in women-centric films. She is among the few South Indian actresses who have taken over the male-dominated film industry with her strong films.

In popular culture
Nayanthara has been a subject of interest in popular culture, with her personal life and career being widely discussed and analyzed by fans and critics alike. Her relationships and feuds with other celebrities have been a subject of interest, with her recent controversy with Dhanush being a notable example.

Controversies
Nayanthara has been involved in several controversies throughout her career, including her recent controversy with Dhanush. Her public statement accusing Dhanush of intentionally holding onto personal grudges and vengeance over their romantic relationship has sparked a heated debate in the industry.

Filmography
Nayanthara's acting career spans over two decades, with her appearing in more than 75 films in Tamil, Telugu, Malayalam, Kannada, and Hindi languages. Her filmography includes a wide range of genres, from romantic comedies to action dramas and horror films.

Accolades
Nayanthara has won five Filmfare Awards South, including Best Actress Telugu for Sri Rama Rajyam, Best Actress Tamil for Raja Rani, Naanum Rowdy Dhaan, and Aramm, and Best Actress Malayalam for Puthiya Niyamam. Her awards and nominations have cemented her status as one of the most successful actresses in the South Indian film industry.

title: The_Conjuring:_The_Devil_Made_Me_Do_It
content:
Plot
In 1981, demonologists Ed and Lorraine Warren document the exorcism of 8-year-old David Glatzel, attended by his family, his older sister Debbie, her boyfriend Arne Johnson, and Father Gordon in Brookfield, Connecticut In an attempt to save the little boy, Arne invites the demon to enter his body instead of David's Ed witnesses the demon enter Arne just as the demon causes him to suffer a heart attack.


Cast
In 2016, regarding further potential sequels, James Wan stated, "There could be many more  [Conjuring] movies because the Warrens have so many stories." Screenwriters Chad and Carey W Hayes also expressed interest in working on a story for another sequel [5] However, Wan stated that he may have been unable to direct the film due to his commitments to other projects [6] He told Collider, "Assuming we are lucky enough to have a third chapter, there are other filmmakers that I would love to sort of continue on the Conjuring world, if we are lucky enough" [7] Wan also noted that, if a third film were to be made, it would ideally take place in the 1980s [8] Wan later stated that the sequel could include lycanthropy, "Maybe we can go and do it like a classic American Werewolf in London style  [...] The Warrens set against the backdrop of The Hound of Baskerville" [9] In May 2017, Safran said it would be unlikely that a third installment would be a "haunted house" film [10]


Production
In 2016, regarding further potential sequels, James Wan stated, "There could be many more  [Conjuring] movies because the Warrens have so many stories." Screenwriters Chad and Carey W Hayes also expressed interest in working on a story for another sequel [5] However, Wan stated that he may have been unable to direct the film due to his commitments to other projects [6] He told Collider, "Assuming we are lucky enough to have a third chapter, there are other filmmakers that I would love to sort of continue on the Conjuring world, if we are lucky enough" [7] Wan also noted that, if a third film were to be made, it would ideally take place in the 1980s [8] Wan later stated that the sequel could include lycanthropy, "Maybe we can go and do it like a classic American Werewolf in London style  [...] The Warrens set against the backdrop of The Hound of Baskerville" [9] In May 2017, Safran said it would be unlikely that a third installment would be a "haunted house" film [10]


Development
In 2016, regarding further potential sequels, James Wan stated, "There could be many more  [Conjuring] movies because the Warrens have so many stories." Screenwriters Chad and Carey W Hayes also expressed interest in working on a story for another sequel [5] However, Wan stated that he may have been unable to direct the film due to his commitments to other projects [6] He told Collider, "Assuming we are lucky enough to have a third chapter, there are other filmmakers that I would love to sort of continue on the Conjuring world, if we are lucky enough" [7] Wan also noted that, if a third film were to be made, it would ideally take place in the 1980s [8] Wan later stated that the sequel could include lycanthropy, "Maybe we can go and do it like a classic American Werewolf in London style  [...] The Warrens set against the backdrop of The Hound of Baskerville" [9] In May 2017, Safran said it would be unlikely that a third installment would be a "haunted house" film [10]


Pre-production
In October 2018, it was announced that The Conjuring 3 would not be directed by Wan but instead would be directed by The Curse of La Llorona director Michael Chaves Wan indicated that he had been impressed while working with Chaves on The Curse of La Llorona, [14] stating, "I got to know him as a filmmaker Chaves' ability to bring emotion to a story, and his understanding of mood and scares, make him a perfect fit to direct the next Conjuring film." [15]


Casting
In December 2018, it was confirmed that Patrick Wilson and Vera Farmiga would reprise their roles as Ed and Lorraine Warren,respectively, from The Conjuring and The Conjuring 2 [20] In August 2019, actress Megan Ashley Brown announced that she and Mitchell Hoog would portray young Lorraine and Ed Warren respectively [21] In December 2019, Sterling Jerins, Julian Hilliard, Sarah Catherine Hook and Ruairi O'Connor were all confirmed as part of the film's cast by Chaves [22]


Filming
Filming began on June 3, 2019, in Atlanta, Georgia [23] On August 15, 2019, Farmiga announced that she had finished filming her scenes [24] Additional photography was initially scheduled for April 2020 but was delayed due to the COVID-19 pandemic [25] During reshoots, Chaves opted to remove a demonic antagonist, played by Davis Osbourne The character was supposed to be working with the Occultist, but Chaves believed it "just wasn't quite connecting", and instead gave Osbourne a role as an infirmary patient [26] John Noble's role was also expanded upon during reshoots [27]


Release
The Conjuring: The Devil Made Me Do It was released in the United Kingdom on May 26, 2021, and in the United States on June 4, 2021, distributed by Warner Bros Pictures and New Line Cinema [28] In the United States, as part of its plans for all of its 2021 films, Warner Bros also released The Conjuring: The Devil Made Me Do It simultaneously on the HBO Max streaming service for a period of one month, after which the film was removed from the service until the normal home media release schedule period [29] It was delayed due to the COVID-19 pandemic's impact on theaters and the film industry, after previously being scheduled to be released on September 11, 2020 [30] [31] The film was re-added to HBO Max on October 21, 2021.


Theatrical and streaming
The Conjuring: The Devil Made Me Do It was released in the United Kingdom on May 26, 2021, and in the United States on June 4, 2021, distributed by Warner Bros Pictures and New Line Cinema [28] In the United States, as part of its plans for all of its 2021 films, Warner Bros also released The Conjuring: The Devil Made Me Do It simultaneously on the HBO Max streaming service for a period of one month, after which the film was removed from the service until the normal home media release schedule period [29] It was delayed due to the COVID-19 pandemic's impact on theaters and the film industry, after previously being scheduled to be released on September 11, 2020 [30] [31] The film was re-added to HBO Max on October 21, 2021.


Home media
The Conjuring: The Devil Made Me Do It was released on Digital HD on July 23, 2021, and was released on DVD, Blu-ray, and Ultra HD Blu-ray by Warner Bros Home Entertainment on August 24, 2021, under the title The Conjuring 3: The Devil Made Me Do It [32]


Reception
Following its opening weekend, Samba TV reported the film was streamed in 1.6 million American households over its first three days of release [33] It was watched in 3 million households over the first 17 days [34] The film was watched in over 3 million U.S households by the end of its first 30 days of release [35]


Streaming viewership
Following its opening weekend, Samba TV reported the film was streamed in 1.6 million American households over its first three days of release [33] It was watched in 3 million households over the first 17 days [34] The film was watched in over 3 million U.S households by the end of its first 30 days of release [35]


Box office
The Conjuring: The Devil Made Me Do It grossed $65.6 million in the United States and Canada, and $140.8 million in other territories, for a worldwide total of $206.4 million [3] [4]


Critical response
On review aggregator Rotten Tomatoes, 55% of 256 critic reviews for the film are positive, with an average rating of 5.8/10 The website's critics consensus reads: "The Devil Made Me Do It represents a comedown for the core Conjuring films, although Vera Farmiga and Patrick Wilson keep the audience invested." [41] On Metacritic, the film has a weighted average score of 53 out of 100 based on 39 critics, indicating "mixed or average reviews" [42] Audiences polled by CinemaScore gave the film an average grade of B+ on an A+ to F scale (down from the A− grade of the first two films), while PostTrak reported 78% of audience members gave it a positive score, with 58% saying they would definitely recommend it [38]


Sequel
In October 2022, The Hollywood Reporter revealed that a fourth mainline franchise film was in development It will be written by David Leslie Johnson-McGoldrick and produced by James Wan and Peter Safran [50]


See also


References


External links
article:
**The Conjuring: The Devil Made Me Do It**

The Conjuring: The Devil Made Me Do It is a 2021 American supernatural horror film directed by Michael Chaves and written by Scott Teems. The film is the third installment in the Conjuring Universe and the sequel to The Conjuring (2013) and The Conjuring 2 (2016). The film stars Vera Farmiga and Patrick Wilson as paranormal investigators Ed and Lorraine Warren, who help a young man named Arne Johnson, who is accused of murdering his mother.

**Plot**

The film is based on the true story of Arne Cheyenne Johnson, a 19-year-old man who was accused of murdering his mother in 1981. The Warrens, who are experienced paranormal investigators, are called to the scene to help in the exorcism of the demon that is believed to be responsible for the murder. The film follows the events that led up to the murder and the subsequent investigation and trial of Arne Johnson.

**Cast**

The film features a talented cast, including:

* Vera Farmiga as Lorraine Warren
* Patrick Wilson as Ed Warren
* Ruairi O'Connor as Arne Johnson
* Sarah Catherine Hook as Judy Johnson
* Julian Hilliard as David Glatzel
* Sterling Jerins as Judy Warren
* John Noble as Father Gordon

**Production**

The film was produced by James Wan and Peter Safran, who also produced the previous two Conjuring films. The film was shot on location in Atlanta, Georgia, and features a mix of practical and visual effects.

**Filming**

Filming began on June 3, 2019, and wrapped up in August 2019. The film was shot on a combination of digital and film cameras, and features a mix of practical and visual effects.

**Release**

The film was released on June 4, 2021, in the United States and Canada, and on May 26, 2021, in the United Kingdom. The film was released in theaters and on the HBO Max streaming service, where it was available for a limited time.

**Box Office**

The film grossed $65.6 million in the United States and Canada, and $140.8 million in other territories, for a worldwide total of $206.4 million.

**Critical Response**

The film received mixed reviews from critics, with an approval rating of 55% on Rotten Tomatoes. The film's critics consensus reads: "The Devil Made Me Do It represents a comedown for the core Conjuring films, although Vera Farmiga and Patrick Wilson keep the audience invested."

**Home Media**

The film was released on Digital HD on July 23, 2021, and on DVD, Blu-ray, and Ultra HD Blu-ray on August 24, 2021.

**Sequel**

In October 2022, it was announced that a fourth mainline franchise film was in development, written by David Leslie Johnson-McGoldrick and produced by James Wan and Peter Safran.

**See Also**

* The Conjuring
* The Conjuring 2
* The Conjuring Universe

**External Links**

* The Conjuring: The Devil Made Me Do It on IMDb
* The Conjuring: The Devil Made Me Do It on Rotten Tomatoes
* The Conjuring: The Devil Made Me Do It on Metacritic

Screenwriters Chad and Carey W Hayes also expressed interest in working on a story for another sequel [5] However, Wan stated that he may have been unable to direct the film due to his commitments to other projects [6] He told Collider, "Assuming we are lucky enough to have a third chapter, there are other filmmakers that I would love to sort of continue on the Conjuring world, if we are lucky enough" [7] Wan also noted that, if a third film were to be made, it would ideally take place in the 1980s [8] Wan later stated that the sequel could include lycanthropy, "Maybe we can go and do it like a classic American Werewolf in London style  [...] The Warrens set against the backdrop of The Hound of Baskerville" [9] In May 2017, Safran said it would be unlikely that a third installment would be a "haunted house" film [10]


Production
In 2016, regarding further potential sequels, James Wan stated, "There could be many more  [Conjuring] movies because the Warrens have so many stories." Screenwriters Chad and Carey W Hayes also expressed interest in working on a story for another sequel [5] However, Wan stated that he may have been unable to direct the film due to his commitments to other projects [6] He told Collider, "Assuming we are lucky enough to have a third chapter, there are other filmmakers that I would love to sort of continue on the Conjuring world, if we are lucky enough" [7] Wan also noted that, if a third film were to be made, it would ideally take place in the 1980s [8] Wan later stated that the sequel could include lycanthropy, "Maybe we can go and do it like a classic American Werewolf in London style  [...] The Warrens set against the backdrop of The Hound of Baskerville" [9] In May 2017, Safran said it would be unlikely that a third installment would be a "haunted house" film [10]


Development

Screenwriters Chad and Carey W Hayes also expressed interest in working on a story for another sequel [5] However, Wan stated that he may have been unable to direct the film due to his commitments to other projects [6] He told Collider, "Assuming we are lucky enough to have a third chapter, there are other filmmakers that I would love to sort of continue on the Conjuring world, if we are lucky enough" [7] Wan also noted that, if a third film were to be made, it would ideally take place in the 1980s [8] Wan later stated that the sequel could include lycanthropy, "Maybe we can go and do it like a classic American Werewolf in London style  [...] The Warrens set against the backdrop of The Hound of Baskerville" [9] In May 2017, Safran said it would be unlikely that a third installment would be a "haunted house" film [10]


Pre-production
In October 2018, it was announced that The Conjuring 3 would not be directed by Wan but instead would be directed by The Curse of La Llorona director Michael Chaves Wan indicated that he had been impressed while working with Chaves on The Curse of La Llorona, [14] stating, "I got to know him as a filmmaker Chaves' ability to bring emotion to a story, and his understanding of mood and scares, make him a perfect fit to direct the next Conjuring film." [15]


Casting
In December 2018, it was confirmed that Patrick Wilson and Vera Farmiga would reprise their roles as Ed and Lorraine Warren,respectively, from The Conjuring and The Conjuring 2 [20] In August 2019, actress Megan Ashley Brown announced that she and Mitchell Hoog would portray young Lorraine and Ed Warren respectively [21] In December 2019, Sterling Jerins, Julian Hilliard, Sarah Catherine Hook and Ruairi O'Connor were all confirmed as part of the film's cast by Chaves [22]


Filming
Filming began on June 3, 2019, in Atlanta, Georgia [23] On August 15, 2019, Farmiga announced that she had finished filming her scenes [24] Additional photography was initially scheduled for April 2020 but was delayed due to the COVID-19 pandemic [25] During reshoots, Chaves opted to remove a demonic antagonist, played by Davis Osbourne The character was supposed to be working with the Occultist, but Chaves believed it "just wasn't quite connecting", and instead gave Osbourne a role as an infirmary patient [26] John Noble's role was also expanded upon during reshoots [27]


Release
The Conjuring: The Devil Made Me Do It was released in the United Kingdom on May 26, 2021, and in the United States on June 4, 2021, distributed by Warner Bros Pictures and New Line Cinema [28] In the United States, as part of its plans for all of its 2021 films, Warner Bros also released The Conjuring: The Devil Made Me Do It simultaneously on the HBO Max streaming service for a period of one month, after which the film was removed from the service until the normal home media release schedule period [29] It was delayed due to the COVID-19 pandemic's impact on theaters and the film industry, after previously being scheduled to be released on September 11, 2020 [30] [31] The film was re-added to HBO Max on October 21, 2021.


Theatrical and streaming
The Conjuring: The Devil Made Me Do It was released in the United Kingdom on May 26, 2021, and in the United States on June 4, 2021, distributed by Warner Bros Pictures and New Line Cinema [28] In the United States, as part of its plans for all of its 2021 films, Warner Bros also released The Conjuring: The Devil Made Me Do It simultaneously on the HBO Max streaming service for a period of one month, after which the film was removed from the service until the normal home media release schedule period [29] It was delayed due to the COVID-19 pandemic's impact on theaters and the film industry, after previously being scheduled to be released on September 11, 2020 [30] [31] The film was re-added to HBO Max on October 21, 2021.


Home media
The Conjuring: The Devil Made Me Do It was released on Digital HD on July 23, 2021, and was released on DVD, Blu-ray, and Ultra HD Blu-ray by Warner Bros Home Entertainment on August 24, 2021, under the title The Conjuring 3: The Devil Made Me Do It [32]


Reception
Following its opening weekend, Samba TV reported the film was streamed in 1.6 million American households over its first three days of release [33] It was watched in 3 million households over the first 17 days [34] The film was watched in over 3 million U.S households by the end of its first 30 days of release [35]


Streaming viewership
Following its opening weekend, Samba TV reported the film was streamed in 1.6 million American households over its first three days of release [33] It was watched in 3 million households over the first 17 days [34] The film was watched in over 3 million U.S households by the end of its first 30 days of release [35]


Box office
The Conjuring: The Devil Made Me Do It grossed $65.6 million in the United States and Canada, and $140.8 million in other territories, for a worldwide total of $206.4 million [3] [4]


Critical response
On review aggregator Rotten Tomatoes, 55% of 256 critic reviews for the film are positive, with an average rating of 5.8/10 The website's critics consensus reads: "The Devil Made Me Do It represents a comedown for the core Conjuring films, although Vera Farmiga and Patrick Wilson keep the audience invested." [41] On Metacritic, the film has a weighted average score of 53 out of 100 based on 39 critics, indicating "mixed or average reviews" [42] Audiences polled by CinemaScore gave the film an average grade of B+ on an A+ to F scale (down from the A− grade of the first two films), while PostTrak reported 78% of audience members gave it a positive score, with 58% saying they would definitely recommend it [38]


Sequel
In October 2022, The Hollywood Reporter revealed that a fourth mainline franchise film was in development It will be written by David Leslie Johnson-McGoldrick and produced by James Wan and Peter Safran [50]


See also


References


External links
